used-plant-part: Leaves, harvested in autumn. Depending on light intensity, sassafras leaves can be divided in one, two or three lobes. The root is also rich in essential oil, but very bitter.
sensory-quality: A weak but fresh, lemon-like aroma. See also lemon myrtle about lemon odour.           Sassafras flowers           Sassafras opening bud
main-constitÂ­uents: Sassafras leaves contain approxiÂ­mately 0.4% of essential oil, the main comÂ­ponent of which is safrol (45%). Minor comÂ­ponents are camphor (30%), Î±-pinene, citral and phellÂ­andrene.  In the root (2%) and especially in the root bark (8%), an essential oil very high in safrol (80%) is found. Besides safrol, two more phenylÂ­propanoids (eugenol methylester, 5-methoxy eugenol) and terpenoids (camphor) are reported.  Safrol (older form safrole) occurs as a minor or trace component in many essential oils (e.â€‰g., star anise, nutmeg and even black pepper). It is the main aroma component of an exotic Mesoamerican spice, Mexican pepper-leaves. Despite its pleasant fragrance, safrole has proved to be a potent hepatotoxin and hepatoÂ­cancerogen in animals. Because of low safrol content of sassafras leaves and particularly filÃ¨ powder, these products are generally believed harmless in the culinary scale; yet culinary or medical usage of sassafras roots (which is much higher in safrol) is strongly discouraged.           Sassafras flowering branch developing young leaves
origin: Atlantic Northern America.
etymology: The name means stone breaker (Latin saxum fragans, but most probably transÂ­mitted via Spanish), which refers to the use of sassafras against kidney stones. The plant does truly exhibit some diuretic properties, but this usage is today fully obsolete.  German FenchelholzÂ­baum fennel wood tree refers to the fragrant wood of sassafras.

note: The name lemon myrtle is also apÂ­plied to a loosely related species, LeptoÂ­spermum citratum (Lemon tea tree) from Australia and New Zealand.
used-plant-part: Leaves (fresh or dried).
sensory-quality: Intensive, refreshing and very, very lemon-like; the odour has been described, without undue exaggeration, as more lemon than lemon. Taste is similar, very intensive, pleasant and warm.
main-constituents: The leaves contain much essential oil (typically, 4 to 5%), which is made up almost totally of terpenoid aldehydes: citral (90 to 95%), neral and geranial. Trace constituents are myrcene, linalool, citronellal, cyclocitral and methyl-heptenone.          Lemon myrtle branch  Origin The plant is native to Australia; it is a rare plant, restricted to QueensÂ­land, and conÂ­sidered enÂ­danÂ­gered. It is cultiÂ­vated since the early 90â€™ies. Two close relatives of lemon myrtle are also grown to produce essential oils: anise myrtle (Backhousia anisata) and cinnamon myrtle (Backhousia myrtifolia). Etymology See lime and myrtle. The genus Backhousia is named after a British botanist, James Backhouse  (1794Â â€“ 1869). The species name, citriodorus lemon-scented, is a neo-Latin formation (citrus and odor scent, smell). used-plant-part: Leaves.
plant-family: Monimiaceae. This family is closely related to the laurel family (Lauraceae).
sensory-quality: Aromatic (reminiscent to camphor and cinnamic acid) and slightly bitter.
main-constituents: The essential oil of boldo leaves (2%) is characterized by its content of ascaridol, a monoterpene peroxide with monocyclic carbon skeleton (40%); other terpene derivatives found in the essential oil include p-cymene, 1,8-cineol and linalool. Ascaridol smells somewhat disagreeable and is, therefore, only rarely found in plants used as spices (for another example, see epazote). Furthermore, the leaves  contain several different alkaloids of isoquinoline type, of which boldine (0.1%) before isocorydine and N-methyl laurotetanine is the most important.
origin: Chile (coastal region). The plant has also been introduced to the Mediterranean, and is sometimes found to grow wild there, particularly in North Africa.

note: In the above list, names referring to South East Asian long pepper, P. retrofractum, are marked with an asterisk. Names without asterisk are either generic or refer to the South Asian species P. longum alone.           Dried long pepper
used-plant-part: The tiny berries, which merge to a single, rod-like structure which bears some resemÂ­blance to catkins (flowers of trees like hazelnut or willow).
sensory-quality: Hot and warm, with sweet and somewhat earthy overtones (some compare it with moist hemp ropes). For accounts on sweet or pungent spices, see licorice and negro pepper, respectively.
main-constituents: In P. retrofractum, piperine, piperlonguminine, sylvatine, guineensine, piperlongumine, filfiline, sitosterol, methyl piperate and a series of piperine-analog retrofractamides are reported. (Phytochemistry, 24, 279, 1985) The content of piperine (about 6%) is slightly higher than in black pepper.           Long pepper plant (P. retrofractum) kanchanapisek.or.thÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Â© Thai Junior Encyclopedia   OnÂ theÂ other hand, long pepper contains less essential oil than its relatives (about 1%), which consists of sesquiÂ­terpene hydroÂ­carbons and ethers (bisabolene, Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene, caryoÂ­phyllene oxide, each 10 to 20%; Î±-zingiberene, 5%), and, surprisingly, saturated aliphatic hydrocarbons: 18% pentadecane, 7% tridecane, 6% heptadecane.
origin: The species Piper longum is of South Asian origin (Deccan peninsular), whereas the closely related Piper retrofractum comes from South East Asia and is mostly cultivated in Indonesia and Thailand. Both species are often not clearly distinguished in the spice trade.
etymology: Pepper and related words names in most other European tongues ultimately derive from the Sanskrit name of long pepper, pippali [à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¤¿, à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¥€] Long pepper reached Europe earlier than the now much more important black pepper, and thus the latter inherited the name of the former.  There is no known etymology for Sanskrit pippali, the word clearly being of non-Indoâ€“European origin. Note that pippala [à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²] is the Sanskrit names of the sacred fig (Ficus religiosa) which figures prominently in Buddhism because Siddharta Gautama got enlighted while sitting in the shadow of such a tree. That name occurs already in the early Rigveda and has been tentatively categorized as neither Indoâ€“European nor Dravidian nor Munda, but belonging to an ancient, now extinct language  X of Northern India that is visible only through some loan words in later tongues.  The first Europeans enjoying pepper were the Greeks. They called the spice peperi [Ï€á½³Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹], which is pretty close to the original Sanskrit word. When the dominion of the Mediterranean passed from the Greeks to the Romans, the latter also inherited the formerâ€™s rÃ´le as main pepper consumers. In fact, late Roman cuisine depended heavily  on Eastern spices in general, and both long and black pepper in particular (see also silphion). In Latin, pepper was called piper, still today the botanical genus name.           Ripe South East Asian long pepper fruits (P. retrofractum) kanchanapisek.or.thÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Â© Thai Junior Encyclopedia   LatinÂ piper is proÂ­genitor of almost all names of pepper in conÂ­temporary EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages. See black pepper for more inforÂ­mation.  Since words derived from Latin piper signify black pepper in all modern European languages, names of long pepper are usually formed with an adjective long, e.â€‰g., Turkish uzun biber, Russian dlinnyj perets [Ğ´Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµÑ†], Swedish lÃ¥ngpeppar and French poivre long, all meaning plainly long pepper; cf. also Slovak dlhÃ© korenie long spice, Chinese chang jiao [é•·æ¤’] long (Sichuan) pepper and Greek makropipero [Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ¿Ï€Î¯Ï€ÎµÏÎ¿] large pepper.  Some Indic tongues have, however, preserved two different words for long and black pepper. For example, in Urdu, long pepper is called pipul [Ù¾ÛŒÙ¾Ù„], whereas black pepper may be called with an Arabic loanword, filfil [ÙÙ„ÙÙ„]. Of course, both pipul and filfil ultimately derive from the same Sanskrit name, pippali. Black pepper has more names in Urdu, which are formed from another Aryan root; see black pepper for details. Another example is Marathi pimpali [à¤ªà¤¿à¤‚à¤ªà¤³à¥€] long pepper vs. mire [à¤®à¤¿à¤°à¥‡] black pepper; a similar pair exists in Gujarati: pipari [àªªà«€àªªàª°à«€] vs. mari [àª®àª°à«€].  Old European sources often had troubles to distinguish long pepper from chiles, both of which are pungent and have an elongated shape. The name long pepper was used for both spices in the 16.th century. Apparently, in modern Farsi, the name dar felfel [Ø¯Ø§Ø± ÙÙ„ÙÙ„] woody pepper may still denote either of the two, although it seems more fitting for long pepper than for chile.

used-plant-part: Leaves.
sensory-quality: Fresh and citrusy, like lemon or lemon grass. See also lemon myrtle.
main-constituents: Balm leaves contain no more than 0.1% of essential oil which is of complex and variable composition. Among the more than 50 aroma compounds yet identified, citronellal (dominantly the (R) enantiomer, see also kaffir lime), Î²-caryophyllene, neral, geranial, citronellol and geraniol amount to about 70% of the oil. The composition is similar to that of lemon grass, but balm oil can be identified by its typical pattern in chiral compounds; for example, enantiomerically almost pure (R)-(+)-methyl citronellate is a good indicator of true balm oil. Lastly, determination of carbon isotope ratio by IRMS (isotope ratio mass spectrometry) is also capable to distinguish between the two oils. (Pharmazie, 50, 60, 1995).           Flowering lemon balm           Bergamot
origin: Probably from Western Asia.
etymology: Balm is a shortÂ­ened form of balsam, deriving from Latin balsamum balsam tree, which was also used for the resin obtained therefrom (Balm of Mecca). The ultimate source of the word is Old Hebrew boshem (modern bossem) [×‘×©×], which  denotes the balsam tree (CommiÂ­phora opoÂ­balsamum syn. Amyris opoÂ­balsamum, BurserÂ­aceae/Rutales) and its resin, but also means fragrance or spice in general. It also appears as busma [Ü’Ü¤Ü¡Ü]  in the Aramaic New Testament.  The Latin species name melissa is shortened from Classical Greek melisso-phyllon [Î¼ÎµÎ»Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿-Ï†á½»Î»Î»Î¿Î½] bee-leaf; the plant is rich in nectar and commonly planted to feed bees. That name is akin to Latin mel honey and also the British term for orange rind jelly, marmalade.  Similar associations referring to bees are found in several European languages, e.â€‰g., Yiddish honik-melise [×”×Ö¸× ×™×§Ö¾××¢×œ×™×¡×¢] honey-balm, Dutch bijenkruid bee herb or Hungarian mÃ©hfÅ± (also mÃ©zfÅ±) bee grass. Cf. also Chinese xiang feng cao [é¦™èœ‚è‰] fragrant bee plant and English bee balm for the related plant bergamot, Monarda didyma.  Also the Bulgarian name matochina [Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°] refers to the bee feeding quality of lemon balm: Bulgarian matitsa [Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ†Ğ°] bee queen, derived from Common Slavonic MATâ€™ mother (in modern Bulgarian majka [Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¹ĞºĞ°]). Similar remarks apply to Czech meduÅˆka, Slovak medovka, Serbo-Croatian matiÄnjak [Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ‡ÑšĞ°Ğº] and related forms. Another Bulgarian name of lemon balm, pcheliak [Ğ¿Ñ‡ĞµĞ»ÑĞº], is directly derived from pchela [Ğ¿Ñ‡ĞµĞ»Ğ°] bee (from the Proto-Indoâ€“European noun bÊ°ei-, which also gives English bee).  Because of the prominent lemon fragrance, many names of balm contain an element referring to that citrus fruit. Often, this element is optional with emphasizing character, as in German Zitronenmelisse (actually, Melisse is the same plant); yet in other cases the lemon element is essential in the name, which then often translates to lemon plant or similar, e.â€‰g., Portuguese erva-cidreira, Hungarian citromfÅ±, Italian erba limona and Dutch citroenkruid lemon-herb; in the same spirit, there are Ukrainian lymonna trava [Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ½Ğ° Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ°] lemon-grass and Arabic raihan al-limun [Ø±ÙŠØ­Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ…ÙˆÙ†] lemon-basil (or lemon-fragrance, see basil). See lemon and lime for the etymologies of the names of lemon mentioned here.           Lemon balm flowering plant   TheÂ Spanish name of lemon balm, toronjil, appears to be related to Arabic turijan [ØªØ±ÙŠØ¬Ø§Ù†] lemon balm but I donâ€™t know any details. Perhaps, it is related to Arabic utruj [Ø£ØªØ±Ø¬] and its Hebrew cognate etrog [××ª×¨×•×’] citron. Note, however, that Spanish toronjil morado purple lemon balm, refers to Agastache mexicana, another herb of the same plant family which has a superb lemon fragrance. The latter plant is in English often termed Mexican Giant Hyssop or Lemon Hyssop, although it is no more related to hyssop than to lemon balm.  Swedish hjÃ¤rtansfrÃ¶jd heatâ€™s delight probably refers less to balmâ€™s pleasant fragrance, but more to the usage of lemon balm against  nervous heart diseases in folk medicine. The same holds true for the analogous German local name Herztrost.  In Japanese, lemon balm is known as seiyÅ-yama-hakka [è¥¿æ´‹å±±è–„è·, ã›ã„ã‚ˆã†ã‚„ã¾ã¯ã£ã‹]. This formidable compound can be broken down to hakka mint which is augmented by the element yama (see also Sichuan pepper for the readings of the Kanji å±±).  Thus, we get the compound name yamahakka (literally mountain mint) which denotes the native plant spurflower (Rabdosia inflexa). The second prefix seiyÅ means foreign. Incidentally, seiyÅ-hakka is the Japanese name of English-type peppermint.  The genus name of bergamot, Monarda, was given in honour of Nicholas Monardus, a Spanish botanist (1493â€“1588).

note: Indian and South-East Asian  names for the so-called sacred basil are marked with an asterisk in the list above. This cultivar (Ocimum sanctumÂ = O. tenuiflorum) is characterized by an intensive sweet-camphoraceous fragrance; in India, it is not much used as a culinary herb (although there are scattered reports of such usage), but has a strong religious meaning, being sacred to Vishnu [à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥] and symbolizing either his wife Lakshmi [à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¥€] or the wives of his various avatars. It is also planted inside of Shiva temples [à¤¶à¤¿à¤µ], and many Hindus have a plant at the entry to their home, because of the herbâ€™s auspicious connection with Lakhsmi, the goddess of riches and good luck.             Leaves of several different basil varieties: From left to right Mediterranean (sweet) basil, African Blue, lemon basil (O. americanum), spice basil, Thai basil (Siam Queen) and tree basil (O. gratissimum), upper and lower sides.             Mexican spice basil           Mexican spice basil flower           Mexican spice basil inflorescence
used-plant-part: Leaves; frequently, the entire herb (all aerial parts) is harvested. Best harvesting season is before flowering. Basil leaves should always be used fresh, as they lose most of their flavour within a few weeks after drying. However, in the Georgian spice mixture khmeli-suneli [áƒ®áƒ›áƒ”áƒšáƒ˜-áƒ¡áƒ£áƒœáƒ”áƒšáƒ˜], dried basil is employed (see blue fenugreek).  The seeds of basil have some use as thickening agent in Thailand. In their outmost layer, they contain mucous substance that, on absorbing water, developes into a thick slime surface with an intriguing, opalescent blueish hue. While these basil seeds lack any taste or fragrance of their own, they contribute an interesting texture, both soft and (by value of the core) crunchy. They are often employed in liquid sweets or sweet drinks.          Mexican spice basil flower
sensory-qualÂ­ity: Fresh basil leaves have a strong and characterÂ­istic aroma, not comparable to any other spice, although there is a hint of cloves traceÂ­able.  In addition to the MediÂ­terraÂ­nean type most common in the West, there is a plethora of other varieties or cultivars with different flavour, many of which are hybrids.  India has its Sacred Basil (O. sanctum = O. tenuiÂ­florum) with intensive, somewhat pungent smell; in Thailand, there is another sweet basil with a great licorice aroma (see also cicely). Varieties sold to gardeners in the West include cinnamon basil, camphor basil, anise basil and Mexican spice basil; the latter has a very pleasant, complex and warm flavour, with a wonderful sweet note more reminiscent to cinnamon than to anise; I have found basil of this type sold fresh on Georgian markets, to be used as a garnish.           African Blue Basil           African Blue Basil (O. kilimandscharicum Ã— O. basilicum)   AÂ lastÂ groupÂ of cultiÂ­vars is characÂ­terized by citrus odour: Thai lemon basil (O. citriÂ­odorum) has a distinct balm-like flavour, and then there are lime basil and another lemon basil (O. ameriÂ­canum) which has an exÂ­traÂ­orÂ­diÂ­nariÂ­ly pure and fresh lemon aroma (see also lemon myrtle on lemon fragrance in general).  Perennial basil species from Africa (Ocimum kilimandschariÂ­cum) and Asia (Ocimum canum) have recently been introÂ­duced to the EuroÂ­pean herb and garÂ­dening market. These species has a strong, but less pleasant flavour; hybrids between them and MediÂ­terranean basil are a recent inÂ­novation, with novel appearÂ­ance and flavour, and enjoy growing popuÂ­larity.  InÂ EnglishÂ language,Â theÂ comÂ­mon basil grown in Italy and other MediÂ­terranean countries is often termed sweet basil; this is, though, misÂ­leading, because Thai basil has much more of a sweet quality. Thus, I will avoid this term and speak of MediÂ­terranean type and Thai type instead.          Flowers of Indian Sacred Basil   AllÂ basilÂ vaÂ­rieties have in common that their dried leaves are much less aromatic than fresh ones;  deep-freezing the herb is the best method of preÂ­servation.          African Blue Basil (O. kilimandscharicum Ã— O. basilicum)   MainÂ constituÂ­ents The essential oil (less than 1%) is of complex and variable comÂ­position. Within the species, several difÂ­ferent chemical races exist, and furtherÂ­more climate, soil and time of harvest influence not only the amount but also the composition of the essential oil. The most important aroma components are 1,8 cineol, linalool, citral, methyl chavicol (estragole), eugenol and methyl cinnamate, although not necessarily in this order; typically, one or two of those dominate the oil, but hardly any basil contains all of these comÂ­pounds in significant amounts. African species often contain camphor. Some species are characterized by compounds outside of the mentioned spectrum, e.â€‰g. thymol.             Flowers of Indian Sacred Basil            Indian Sacred Basil (tulasi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€])            Wild form of Indian Sacred Basil            Flowers of Indian Sacred Basil   FurtherÂ monoÂ­terpenes (ocimene, geraniol, camphor), sesquiÂ­terpenes (bisabolene, caryoÂ­phyllene) and phenylÂ­propanoids (methyl eugenol) can be present in varying amounts and strongly influence the flavour. There is conÂ­siderable infra- and intraÂ­specific variÂ­ation, opening favourable perÂ­spectives for future plant breeding by selection. Prospects are enhanced by the fact that basil species hybridize easily.            Indian Sacred Basil (tulasi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€])            Wild form of Indian Sacred Basil    TheÂ qualityÂ traÂ­ded in Europe, Western Asia and North America (MediÂ­terraÂ­nean type, also known as French or EuroÂ­pean Basil) is characÂ­terized by 1,8 cineol and linalool, plus smaller amounts of estragole and eugenol. This deÂ­scription holds also for both green-leaved and red-leaved (anthoÂ­cyanin conÂ­taining) strains. Eastern EuroÂ­pean cultivars contain slightly more eugenol.          Sacred Thai Basil (kaprao [à¸à¸°à¹€à¸à¸£à¸²])   IndianÂ Sacred Basil (O.  sanctumÂ = O.  tenuiÂ­florum, called tulsi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€] in Hindi) owes its stronger, somewhat pungent taste to a sesquiÂ­terpenoid, Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene, and a phenylÂ­propanoid, methyl eugenol (both around 30%) plus minor amounts of methylÂ­chavicol (10%). The Sacred Basil of Thailand (ka prao) was found to also contain Î²-caryophyllene besides a phenylÂ­propanoid, eugenol and a sesquiterpene, Î²-elemene. Chemotypes centering on eugenol alone are rare; their odour closely resembles cloves or allspice (see below about O.  gratissimum).           Sacred Thai Basil (kaprao [à¸à¸°à¹€à¸à¸£à¸²])           Sacred Thai Basil flower           Sweet Thai basil (horapha [à¹‚à¸«à¸£à¸°à¸à¸²])   AÂ coupleÂ of chemoÂ­types are domiÂ­nated by estragol (methyl chavicol); these stand apart by their sweet anise or licorice fragrance (anise basil, sweet Thai basil). Also in this group belongs the New Guinea basil, an attracÂ­tive perÂ­ennial plant with red leaves and an intenÂ­sive fraÂ­grance; its botanÂ­ical affiliÂ­ations are unclear.          Sacred Thai Basil flower   Lemonâ€‘scented varieties (Ocimum americanum, O. citriÂ­odorum) contain mostly citral, a mixture of the two monoÂ­terpenoid aldehydes neral and geranial.  TheÂ African species, O. kiliÂ­mandschariÂ­cum (often known as camphor basil), is characterized by much camphor besides 1,8 cineol; camphor is also found, albeit in lesser quantities, in kiliÂ­mandschariÂ­cum hybrids with O. basilicum (e.â€‰g., African Blue).          Tree basil (O. gratissimum)   Lastly,Â cinnamon basil owes its scent to a chemical also found in cinÂ­namon and cassia, methyl cinÂ­namate. A most pleasantly scented cultivar called Mexican spice basil was found to contain methyl cinÂ­namate, Î²-bisaÂ­bolene, 1,8 cineol and estragole. LiteraÂ­ture deÂ­scribed both cultivars as beÂ­longing to the species O. basilicum, and I strongly suspect they are synonymous.           Tree basil (O. gratissimum)           Flowers of the East Indian  Tree Basil (O. gratissimum)           Flower of East Indian Tree basil   TheÂ wildÂ species Ocimum gratisÂ­simum (East Indian tree basil, also known as clove basil), growing in tropical Africa and Asia, appears to have a very complex chemism of its own. At least six chemoÂ­types are known, named after their impact respctive comÂ­pounds: eugenol, thymol, citral, ethyl cinÂ­namate, geraniol and linalool. The most common variety sold to EuroÂ­pean gardeners is very rich in eugenol, but contains also some thymol that makes for an attractive spicy, pungent flavour. Culinarily, this plant is generally underrated.           Flower of East Indian Tree basil   ThisÂ collection demonstrates clearly that basil has a remarkÂ­ably variÂ­able seconÂ­dary metaÂ­bolism, as is often found in the mint family: Perilla and mints show a similar genetic diÂ­versiÂ­ty.  For several related herbs like thyme, oregano and sage the comÂ­position of the essential oil is known to depend on climate, soil, genetic strain and season.           Flower of East Indian Tree basil           Wild growing East Indian tree basil (Sri Lanka)   TheÂ darkÂ red foliage of some basil varieties is caused by pigÂ­ments of anthoÂ­cyanin type, which are comÂ­monly found in reddish leaves. In wild species, red-leaved specimen are quite rare; but this strain can be easily selected and enÂ­hanced by breeding. For the formation of deep red leaves, intensive sunÂ­light is reÂ­quired in any case; if given maxiÂ­mum sunÂ­shine, red-leaved basil varieties may contain up to 200â€‰ppm anthoÂ­cyanins in their fresh leaves. See also annatto about vegetable colourants.             Wild basil found in South India            Lemon-scented Indian wild basil            Wild growing East Indian tree basil (Sri Lanka)  Origin Genus OciÂ­mum is wideÂ­spread over Asia, Africa and Central and Southern America; it apÂ­pears to have its center of diÂ­versiÂ­ty in Africa. Most species preÂ­fer tropical climate .  The culinary herb basil (O. basilicum) is a sun loving plant of the MediÂ­terranean region; its origin is, howÂ­ever, not known. It was usually assumed to originate from India, as there some of its close relatives grow wildly; however, as it is attested in the MediÂ­terranean since 3000 years (Egypt), some doubt may be raised. Newer literature openly speculates whether basil could be a native of West Asia. Today, basil is cultivated in many Asian and MediÂ­terranean countries; main exporters (for the EuroÂ­pean market) are France, Italy, Morocco and Egypt. There is also signiÂ­ficant basil production in California.          Lemon-scented Indian wild basil   TheÂ Sacred Basil (or Holy Basil) of India (O. tenuiÂ­florum) also has a long history of cultiÂ­vation, being deÂ­scribed in the Indic Vedas, roughly 3000 years ago. In the wild state, it is found in troÂ­pical Asia and Africa; mostly, an origin in India is assumed.  The species known as East-Indian tree basil (O. gratissimum) also has a distribution over  Africa and Asia, but in that case, the higher diversity makes it likely that the species originated in Africa. The names of basil in almost all EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages are related, alÂ­though they show some vowel variation: Icelandic basilÃ­ka, Belarusian bazylik [Ğ±Ğ°Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ»Ñ–Ğº], SerboÂ­croatian bosiljak [Ğ±Ğ¾ÑĞ¸Ñ™Ğ°Ğº], Albanian bozilok, Czech bazalka, Hungarian bazsalikom, Romanian busuioc, ProvenÃ§al baseli, Basque brasilla and Modern Greek vasilikos [Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»Î¹ÎºÏŒÏ‚]. main-constituÂ­ents: The essential oil (less than 1%) is of complex and variable comÂ­position. Within the species, several difÂ­ferent chemical races exist, and furtherÂ­more climate, soil and time of harvest influence not only the amount but also the composition of the essential oil. The most important aroma components are 1,8 cineol, linalool, citral, methyl chavicol (estragole), eugenol and methyl cinnamate, although not necessarily in this order; typically, one or two of those dominate the oil, but hardly any basil contains all of these comÂ­pounds in significant amounts. African species often contain camphor. Some species are characterized by compounds outside of the mentioned spectrum, e.â€‰g. thymol.             Flowers of Indian Sacred Basil            Indian Sacred Basil (tulasi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€])            Wild form of Indian Sacred Basil            Flowers of Indian Sacred Basil   FurtherÂ monoÂ­terpenes (ocimene, geraniol, camphor), sesquiÂ­terpenes (bisabolene, caryoÂ­phyllene) and phenylÂ­propanoids (methyl eugenol) can be present in varying amounts and strongly influence the flavour. There is conÂ­siderable infra- and intraÂ­specific variÂ­ation, opening favourable perÂ­spectives for future plant breeding by selection. Prospects are enhanced by the fact that basil species hybridize easily.            Indian Sacred Basil (tulasi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€])            Wild form of Indian Sacred Basil    TheÂ qualityÂ traÂ­ded in Europe, Western Asia and North America (MediÂ­terraÂ­nean type, also known as French or EuroÂ­pean Basil) is characÂ­terized by 1,8 cineol and linalool, plus smaller amounts of estragole and eugenol. This deÂ­scription holds also for both green-leaved and red-leaved (anthoÂ­cyanin conÂ­taining) strains. Eastern EuroÂ­pean cultivars contain slightly more eugenol.          Sacred Thai Basil (kaprao [à¸à¸°à¹€à¸à¸£à¸²])   IndianÂ Sacred Basil (O.  sanctumÂ = O.  tenuiÂ­florum, called tulsi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€] in Hindi) owes its stronger, somewhat pungent taste to a sesquiÂ­terpenoid, Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene, and a phenylÂ­propanoid, methyl eugenol (both around 30%) plus minor amounts of methylÂ­chavicol (10%). The Sacred Basil of Thailand (ka prao) was found to also contain Î²-caryophyllene besides a phenylÂ­propanoid, eugenol and a sesquiterpene, Î²-elemene. Chemotypes centering on eugenol alone are rare; their odour closely resembles cloves or allspice (see below about O.  gratissimum).           Sacred Thai Basil (kaprao [à¸à¸°à¹€à¸à¸£à¸²])           Sacred Thai Basil flower           Sweet Thai basil (horapha [à¹‚à¸«à¸£à¸°à¸à¸²])   AÂ coupleÂ of chemoÂ­types are domiÂ­nated by estragol (methyl chavicol); these stand apart by their sweet anise or licorice fragrance (anise basil, sweet Thai basil). Also in this group belongs the New Guinea basil, an attracÂ­tive perÂ­ennial plant with red leaves and an intenÂ­sive fraÂ­grance; its botanÂ­ical affiliÂ­ations are unclear.          Sacred Thai Basil flower   Lemonâ€‘scented varieties (Ocimum americanum, O. citriÂ­odorum) contain mostly citral, a mixture of the two monoÂ­terpenoid aldehydes neral and geranial.  TheÂ African species, O. kiliÂ­mandschariÂ­cum (often known as camphor basil), is characterized by much camphor besides 1,8 cineol; camphor is also found, albeit in lesser quantities, in kiliÂ­mandschariÂ­cum hybrids with O. basilicum (e.â€‰g., African Blue).          Tree basil (O. gratissimum)   Lastly,Â cinnamon basil owes its scent to a chemical also found in cinÂ­namon and cassia, methyl cinÂ­namate. A most pleasantly scented cultivar called Mexican spice basil was found to contain methyl cinÂ­namate, Î²-bisaÂ­bolene, 1,8 cineol and estragole. LiteraÂ­ture deÂ­scribed both cultivars as beÂ­longing to the species O. basilicum, and I strongly suspect they are synonymous.           Tree basil (O. gratissimum)           Flowers of the East Indian  Tree Basil (O. gratissimum)           Flower of East Indian Tree basil   TheÂ wildÂ species Ocimum gratisÂ­simum (East Indian tree basil, also known as clove basil), growing in tropical Africa and Asia, appears to have a very complex chemism of its own. At least six chemoÂ­types are known, named after their impact respctive comÂ­pounds: eugenol, thymol, citral, ethyl cinÂ­namate, geraniol and linalool. The most common variety sold to EuroÂ­pean gardeners is very rich in eugenol, but contains also some thymol that makes for an attractive spicy, pungent flavour. Culinarily, this plant is generally underrated.           Flower of East Indian Tree basil   ThisÂ collection demonstrates clearly that basil has a remarkÂ­ably variÂ­able seconÂ­dary metaÂ­bolism, as is often found in the mint family: Perilla and mints show a similar genetic diÂ­versiÂ­ty.  For several related herbs like thyme, oregano and sage the comÂ­position of the essential oil is known to depend on climate, soil, genetic strain and season.           Flower of East Indian Tree basil           Wild growing East Indian tree basil (Sri Lanka)   TheÂ darkÂ red foliage of some basil varieties is caused by pigÂ­ments of anthoÂ­cyanin type, which are comÂ­monly found in reddish leaves. In wild species, red-leaved specimen are quite rare; but this strain can be easily selected and enÂ­hanced by breeding. For the formation of deep red leaves, intensive sunÂ­light is reÂ­quired in any case; if given maxiÂ­mum sunÂ­shine, red-leaved basil varieties may contain up to 200â€‰ppm anthoÂ­cyanins in their fresh leaves. See also annatto about vegetable colourants.             Wild basil found in South India            Lemon-scented Indian wild basil            Wild growing East Indian tree basil (Sri Lanka)  Origin Genus OciÂ­mum is wideÂ­spread over Asia, Africa and Central and Southern America; it apÂ­pears to have its center of diÂ­versiÂ­ty in Africa. Most species preÂ­fer tropical climate .  The culinary herb basil (O. basilicum) is a sun loving plant of the MediÂ­terranean region; its origin is, howÂ­ever, not known. It was usually assumed to originate from India, as there some of its close relatives grow wildly; however, as it is attested in the MediÂ­terranean since 3000 years (Egypt), some doubt may be raised. Newer literature openly speculates whether basil could be a native of West Asia. Today, basil is cultivated in many Asian and MediÂ­terranean countries; main exporters (for the EuroÂ­pean market) are France, Italy, Morocco and Egypt. There is also signiÂ­ficant basil production in California.          Lemon-scented Indian wild basil   TheÂ Sacred Basil (or Holy Basil) of India (O. tenuiÂ­florum) also has a long history of cultiÂ­vation, being deÂ­scribed in the Indic Vedas, roughly 3000 years ago. In the wild state, it is found in troÂ­pical Asia and Africa; mostly, an origin in India is assumed.  The species known as East-Indian tree basil (O. gratissimum) also has a distribution over  Africa and Asia, but in that case, the higher diversity makes it likely that the species originated in Africa. The original Arabic form is al-habaqa [Ø§Ù„Ø­Ø¨Ù‚] the basil; cf. also Maltese Ä§abaq and Aramaic hauk [ÜšÜ˜ÜŸ], and see caper for more examples of Arabic vocabulary in Spanish and Portuguese.           African wild basil O. canum           Wild basil, O. canum pharm1.pharmazie.uni-greifswald.de   InÂ contempoÂ­rary Arabic as spoken in Asia and the Eastern MediÂ­terraÂ­nean, habaq [Ø­Ø¨Ù‚] has become rather unÂ­comÂ­mon and mostly supÂ­planted by ar-raihan [Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙŠØ­Ø§Ù†]. The latter name has close relatives in many lanÂ­guages of the Middle East, e.â€‰g., Turkish reyhan, Hebrew rehan [×¨×™×—×Ÿ], Georgian rehani [áƒ áƒ”áƒ°áƒáƒœáƒ˜], Kurdish dhaihan [Ø°Ø©ÛŒØ­Ø§Ù†] and Farsi rihan [Ø±ÛŒØ­Ø§Ù†]. Note, however, that Turkish daÄŸ reyhanÄ± mountain basil means savory.  RaihanÂ is derived from Arabic rih [Ø±ÙŠØ­] or riha [Ø±ÙŠØ­Ø©] odour, fraÂ­grance and origiÂ­nally did not mean basil but another aromatic MediÂ­terraÂ­nean plant, myrtle. This is still so in North African Arabic (and Maltese); moreover, the word has been transferred to medieval Spanish as arrayÃ¡n myrtle.  The genus name Ocimum is a latinized version of the Greek plant name okimon [á½¤ÎºÎ¹Î¼Î¿Î½], by which basil is referred to in the work of Dioskurides. It derives from the verb  ozein [á½„Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½] smell (cf. ozone the smelling one, directly from the Greek present participle ozon [á½„Î¶Î¿Î½]) and English odour).           African camphor basil, , O. kilimandscharicum   IndicÂ namesÂ for holy basil, e.â€‰g., Telugu tulsiÂ­chettu [à°¤à±à°³à°¸à°¿à°šà±†à°Ÿà±à°Ÿà±], Tamil tulasi [à®¤à¯à®³à®šà®¿] and Hindi tulsi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€], derive from Sanskrit tulasi [à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€]; for the latter name, no satisÂ­fying etymoÂ­logy is known. To distinÂ­guish holy basil more clearly from its wild relatives, comÂ­pound names are used, e.â€‰g., Hindi jangliÂ­tulsi [à¤œà¤‚à¤—à¤²à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€] forest basil to denote O. gratissimum.          African camphor basil, , O. kilimandscharicum   HinduÂ cultÂ preÂ­fers red-leaved variÂ­eties of Sacred Basil; and such strains are often reÂ­ferred to by colour adjecÂ­tives: Urdu kali tulsi [Ú©Ø§Ù„ÛŒ ØªÙ„Ø³ÛŒ] or Hindi krishna tulsi [à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£ à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€] dark/black basil. In Kerala, I have seen O. gratisÂ­simum being called ramaÂ­tulasi [à´°à´¾à´®à´¤àµà´³à´¸à´¿], which appears to be the unÂ­expected side-effect of a re-interÂ­pretion of the name of red-leaved Sacred Basil, krishnaÂ­tulasi [à´•àµƒà´·àµà´£à´¤àµà´³à´¸à´¿]: The latter was interÂ­preted to refer not to the colour but to the Hindu god Krishna (the eighth and most famous avatar of Vishnu), and thus the related but difÂ­ferent green plant got associated with Rama, the seventh avatar. In Nepal, the term ramtulsi [à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¸à¥€] may also mean a wild type of oregano.  The Vietnamese name  rau que [rau quáº¿] cinnamon plant (emphasized hung que [hÃºng quáº¿] cinnamon basil) alludes to the sweetâ€“aromatic odour of some cultivars like Thai horapha, although this is more close to anise than to cinnamon. There are indeed cinnamon-flavoured basil varieties, but these are, to my knowledge, not known in Vietnam. used-plant-part: There are two variants of Perilla frutescens grown in Japan: The var. crispa, called shiso [ç´«è˜‡, ã—ã], has attractive, crispate foliage and is grown for the aromatic leaves, which may be green (ao-jiso, [é’ç´«è˜‡, ã‚ãŠã˜ã]) or red (aka-jiso [èµ¤ç´«è˜‡, ã‚ã‹ã˜ã]). The leaves are always used fresh, but can be frozen.  The other variant is var. frutescens known as egoma. It is valued for the oil extracted from the seeds, which is used for Shintoist ceremonies, but also as an expensive food supplement. Occasionally, the dry seeds find use as a spice.
sensory-quality: Aromatic but difficult to describe; the fragrance reminds me of cinnamon and anise or licorice. The taste is similar, but with a marked astringent component. As with many other plant of the same family, olfactory characteristics are quite variable and depend, besides genetic factors, also on soil and climate.
main-constituents: Perilla leaves contain about 0.2% of an essential oil, which varies widely in composition. Several different chemotypes are known: PA (see below) is the only is the only one of culinary value; the others are PK (main component perilla ketone, minor components isoegomaketone and perillene), EK (main component elsholzia ketone, minor component naginata ketone), PL (main component perillene, minor components citral, perilla ketone, isoegomaketone), PP (phenylpropanoids: myristicin, dillapiol, elemicin, safrole) and C (main component citral, minor components perillene, perilla ketone, isoegomaketone). There is also a type rich in rosefurane, which might have potential as a cheaper substitute for rose oil in perfumery.           Perilla flowering plants   InÂ theÂ most freÂ­quently cultiÂ­vated chemoÂ­type (PA), the main comÂ­ponent is perillÂ­aldehyde  (p-menthaÂ­dien-1,8(9)-al(7), 75%) Its minor conÂ­stituents are limonene (13%), linalool, Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene, l-menthol, limonene, Î±-pinene, perillene (2-methyl-5-(3-oxolanyl)-2-pentene) and elemicin. PerillÂ­aldehyde  can cause skin allergies.  The C type is a potentially interesting source of citral, a pleasantly lemon-scented material much used in the flavour and perfume industries; see lemon myrtle for more on lemony flavours and citral.  The PP type may also gain importance as a source of simple phenylpropanoids in the pharmaceutical  industry. The high myristicin content makes this plant considerably toxic (see nutmeg on the hallucinogenic properties of myristicin).  The dominating constituents of the remaining types are monoterpenoid furanes, often ketones. Some of these, e.â€‰g., isoegomaketone, are severe pneumotoxins that have caused fatal poisoning in cattle repeatedly. The PK type must be considered a toxic plant that has no use in kitchen.  The oxime of perilla aldehyde  (perillartin) is about 2000 times sweeter than sucrose; it is used as an artificial sweetener in Japan.           Green-leaved Korean type of perilla www.flickr.com   PerillaÂ seedsÂ conÂ­tain a drying oil (40%) with high content of multiply unsaturated fatty acids (60% Î±-linolenic acid, 15% both linoleic and oleic acid); their medicinal value is sometimes matter of great exaggeration.  Lastly, perilla contains the pseudotannins and antioxidants typical for the mint family; see hyssop for details. The reddishâ€“purple colour of some cultivars is caused by an anthocyanin pigment called perillanin chloride. Origin The plant is native to South East and East Asia. Etymology I was not able to find out anything about the name perilla, although there might be a connection to pearl.  In Korea, where perilla is an important flavouring, the plant is known as tul-kkae [ë“¤ê¹¨]. This name literally means wild sesame plant, although perilla and sesame are not particularly closely related. Also kkaennip [ê¹»ì] (sesame leaf) is a common designation for perilla in Korean.  I do not know about the motivation behind those weird names; maybe, they refer to the fact that both plants have oil-rich seeds. Occasionally, names of the wild sesame type are found in Korean cookbooks published in English or German. It is to be suspected that the authors meant perilla and not a wild type of sesame.  Also, the Japanese name egoma [èèƒ¡éº», ãˆã”ã¾] for perilla seeds is derived from sesame (goma) and means sesame bean.  In some East Asian countries, perilla and rice paddy herb bear confusingly similar names. See there for details. used-plant-part: Stem bark. For cassia buds, see Ceylon cinnaÂ­mon.
sensory-quality: Strongly aromatic, sweet, warm, but slightly bitter and mucilagiÂ­nous. Compared to Ceylon cinnamon, cassia tastes slightly bitter and astringent, and it lacks the liveliness of cinnamon. On bitter spices, see also zedoary.
main-constituents: Similarly to Ceylon cinnamon, cassia contains max. 4% essential oil, 75 to 90% of which are composed by cinnamic aldehyde. There are only traces of eugenol is, but significant amounts (7%) of coumarin; therefore, analysis of eugenol and coumarin discriminates between Ceylon and Chinese cinnamon. Trace components of cassia oil are benzoic acid, cinnamic acid, salicylic acid and the corresponding esters and aldehydes. Cassia bark contains significantly more slime (11%) than Ceylon cinnamon bark. The leaf oil (0.3 to 0.8%) has a similar composition to the bark oil.  In fall 2006, Coumarin has become much-discussed in Germany, as it was revealed that some cassia-flavoured cookies exceed the legal limit of coumarin and might prove dangerous to health. The limit is very low in German law, 2â€‰ppm irrespective of the type of food, which would equal about half a gram of cassia per kilogram if a maximum coumarin content is assumed. Clearly, cassia-flavoured cookies easily lie above this threshold.  In contrast, the Federal Institute for Risk Assessment published an alternative limit of 0.1â€‰mg Coumarin per kg body mass and day, which is considered harmless as average intake. According to this scale, a person of 50â€‰kg could afford to eat 5â€‰mg coumarin or at least one gram of cassia per day. Other possible sources of coumarin, of course, have to enter the calculation separately (e.â€‰g., perfumes). See also tonka bean for more on the toxicity of coumarin.
origin: Southern China, Burma, Laos, Vietnam. Commercial cultivation is restricted to China and Vietnam.
etymology: The name cassia indirectly derives from Greek kasia [ÎºÎ±Ïƒá½·Î±], which is probably a loan from Semitic traders (cf. Old Hebrew qetsiiah [×§×¦×™×¢×”]); its ultimate origin is not fully clear, but the name might well derive, as the spice itself, from China in a larger sense. It was suggested that cassia might be related to the name of the Khasi people, an Austroasiatic tribe in  North-Eastern India (union state Meghalaya) and Bangladesh.  Formerly, they inhabited a larger area in Assam, extending to Burma, and they might have been involved in ancient cassia trade. Another theory links the name to Sumerian gazi [ğ’ƒ¢, ğ’ƒ¨] (Akkadian kasÃ»), which denoted a spice variously translated as cassia, licorice oder mustard.  For the derivation of cinnamon, Zimt, cimet and similar forms, see Sri Lanka cinnamon; another group of names, exemplified by kaneel and cannelle, has an independent origin discussed under Indonesian cinnamon.  In Central Asia to North India, cinnamon spice was traditionally imported from China. Local languages do not distinguish between Chinese and other types of cinnamon, but employ the same name for all cinnamon types: Bengali darchini [à¦¦à¦¾à§œà¦šà¦¿à¦¨à¦¿], Hindi dal chini [à¤¦à¤¾à¤²à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¥€], Punjabi dal chini [à¨¦à¨¾à¨² à¨šà¨¿à¨¨à©€], Pashto dol chini [Ø¯Ø§Ù„ Ú†ÙŠÙ†Ù‰] and Farsi darchin [Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ú†ÛŒÙ†] (thence Armenian darchin [Õ¤Õ¡Ö€Õ¹Õ«Õ¶]) all mean Chinese wood; see juniper for an explanation of the element dar which means wood. The cinnamon sold and used in todayâ€™s India and Central Asia may derive from either variety; furthermore, adulteration by less-quality North Indian Cinnamomum species is common, for example by the bark of the tree that yields Indian bay-leaves.  The name was transferred to a number of unrelated languages: Turkish tarÃ§Ä±n, Turkmen dalÃ§yn, Azerbaijani darÃ§Ä±n, Kazakh darshin [Ğ´Ğ°Ñ€ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½], Arabic  ad-darsin [Ø§Ù„Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø³ÙŠÙ†] and Georgian darichini [áƒ“áƒáƒ áƒ˜áƒ©áƒ˜áƒœáƒ˜]. In these languages, the speakers are usually not aware of the literal meaning, as the element dar has no connection with wood (in Arabic, it happens to mean country). Also, the association with China is not felt, and often obscured by sound changes or orthography. For example, the Arabic name of China, as-sin [Ø§Ù„ØµÙŠÙ†] uses another sound and letter for the S, and in Turkish, the name of China has a different vowel (Ã‡in) because of the vowel harmony imposed on the Persian loanword.

hoa  Cay rum, Hong hoa  Yiddish×–×²×¤Ö¿×‘×œ×•×, ×°×™×œ×“×¢×¨ ×–×Ö·×¤Ö¿×¨×¢×Ÿ  Zeyfblum, Vilder Zafren            Safflower www.inaro.de           Safflower (dried flowers)
used-plant-part: Flowers.
plant-family-: Asteraceae (sunflower family, also known as aster family), subfamily Asteroidae.
sensory-quality: Very weak, herbaceous.
main-constituents: Safflower flowers contain carthamin, a dye of flavonoid type, but no essential oil.           Safflower head           Safflower plant, flowering pharm1.pharmazie.uni-greifswald.de   TheÂ plantÂ isÂ widely  cultivated for edible oil, which is extracted from the seeds. It contains triÂ­glycerides of the doubly unÂ­saturated linoleic acid (70%) and the triply unÂ­saturated linolenic acid (10%); the latter is, together with the comparaÂ­tively high content of vitamin E (310 ppm), responsible for the good reputation of safÂ­flower oil among nuÂ­triÂ­tion sciÂ­enÂ­tists. IoÂ­dine inÂ­dex is raÂ­ther high, rangÂ­ing from 140 to 150. See also seÂ­same for a genÂ­eral disÂ­cusÂ­sion of vegÂ­etable oils.
origin: MediÂ­terranean.
etymology: The botanical genus name Carthamus derives from the Arabic verb qurtum [Ù‚Ø±Ø·Ù…] dye, in reference to the usage of safflower flowers for textile dyeing. The word also entered some Romance tongues, e.â€‰g., Italian cartamo or Catalan cÃ rtam, probably via Spanish cÃ¡rtamo; Turkish kartam, on the other hand, is likely to be a direct loan from Arabic.  TheÂ modern Arabic name of safflower, al-usfur [Ø§Ù„Ø¹ØµÙØ±], comes from an adjective asfar [Ø§ØµÙØ±] yellow. The same root á¹¢PR  become yellow also lies behind the name saffron. That name has been transÂ­ferred into Ottoman Turkish asfur or hasbir, and entered Spanish as alazor according to the medieval AndaÂ­lusian proÂ­nunciation al-asfur (see also caper on Arabic loans in Iberic tongues).           Safflower           Safflower: Close-up to flower www.inaro.de   QuiteÂ amazingly, Arabic usfur is also the source of the name safflower and its cognates in various European languages, e.â€‰g., German Saflor, Finnish saflori and Bulgarian and Russian saflor [ÑĞ°Ñ„Ğ»Ğ¾Ñ€]. These names were derived from usfur or asfur via Old Italian asfiore (or saffiore) and Old French saffleur. By folk etymology, the name was transformed towards saffron and flower (Italian fiore, French fleur).  The botanical species name tinctorius is an adjective corresponding to the noun tinctor dyer, cf. the English verb tint. Several European names of safflower contain elements referring to dye or colour, e.â€‰g., Swedish fÃ¤rgtistel, Estonian vÃ¤rvisafloor, German FÃ¤rberdistel and Romanian pintenogÄƒ colorantÄƒ.  FÃ¤rberÂ dyerÂ in the German name FÃ¤rbersaflor is the  nomen agentis to the noun Farbe (cognate to Dutch verf) colour; dye; these words are difficult  to explain etymologiÂ­cally. A Proto-Indoâ€“European root PERá¸° coloured,  speckled is often used to denote colourful animals: (Greek perkos [Ï€á½³ÏÎºÎ¿Ï‚] sparrow-hawk, prox [Ï€Ïá½¹Î¾] deer, German Forelle trout and perhaps even English perch). It is unclear whether pork (Proto-Indoâ€“European PORá¸°O young pig) belongs to the same group, as it is more often set into relation with another but homophonous root PERá¸° dig (cf. English furrow).  Arguments against deriving Farbe from that source, i.â€‰e. PERá¸°, come from Gothic farw shape, which falls in line with Old Irish krunth and Sanskrit krip [à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¥] shape and Latin corpus body; shape (Proto-Indoâ€“European root is KÊ·REPO). The meaning colour might thus be a more recent semantic shift from shape, restricted to Germanic tongues.  But the Gothic word might also be interpreted as a loan from Arabic  farwa [ÙØ±Ùˆ] (colourful) fur; clothing.           Flower head of safflower   ManyÂ European languages name safflower as false saffron or the like, e.â€‰g., Portuguese falso-aÃ§afrÃ£o, Italian falso zafferano or French safran bÃ¢tard bastard saffron. This habit is very old: Already in Classical Greek, there is a name krokos ho akanthodes [ÎºÏá½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á½ á¼€ÎºÎ±Î½Î¸á½½Î´Î·Ï‚] spiny saffron.  Occasionally, the names for safflower and saffron are variants of each other, or the same word loaned by different routes: Croatian Å¡afranika/Å¡afran (similar in other Yugoslavian tongues), Portuguese aÃ§afroa/aÃ§afrÃ£o, Romanian È™ofrÄƒnaÈ™ (ÅŸofrÄƒnaÅŸ)/È™ofran (ÅŸofran) and Slowak azafrÃ¡n/Å¡afrÃ¡n. A rather tricky case is Azeri: Both spices may be named zÉ™fÉ™ran (from the Persian name of saffron), yet for safflower, also the Russian word for saffron, ÅŸafran, may be employed.  The Yiddish name zeyfblum [×–×²×¤Ö¿×‘×œ×•×]  means soap-flower (zeyf [×–×²×£] soap and blum [×‘×œ×•×] flower). It is hard to explain. It could be related to the oil extracted from the seeds, which can be converted into soap; but the same is true of all other oilseed plants, too.  The Greek name for safflower, knikos [ÎºÎ½Î¯ÎºÎ¿Ï‚], relates to Old Greek knekos [ÎºÎ½á¿†ÎºÎ¿Ï‚] or knikion [ÎºÎ½á½·ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î½], which also meant safflower; the oldest recorded form of that Greek name is knakos [ğ€ğ€™ğ€’] found on Mycenaean clay tablets, which, however, signified saffron. That word is of Indoâ€“European origin and related to Sanskrit kanchani  [à¤•à¤¾à¤‚à¤šà¤¨à¥€] golden, made from gold (also used as a plant name for turmeric), Old Prussian cuncan brown and English honey (Old English hunig); the underlying root can be reconstructed as K(E)NÆKO (golden) yellow. In modern botanical terminology, the genus name Cnicus denotes the blessed thistle (Cnicus benedictus), a plant with yellow to orange flowers that is losely related to safflower. note: Not to be confused with two other spices often termed bay leaves: Indian bay-leaves and Indonesian bay-leaves. See also allspice on the so-called Caribbean or West-Indian bay-leaves.          Bay leaves: lower side, upper side, old (discoloured) leaf           Dried laurel fruits
used-plant-part: Leaves. Industrially, laurel oil is prepared from the fruits, which may also be used as a spice with great success.
sensory-quality: Aromatic, pine-like and slightly bitter (see also zedoary on bitter spices).
main-constituents: The essential oil from the leaves (0.8 to 3%) contains mostly 1,8 cineol (50%); furthermore, eugenol, acetyl eugenol, methyl eugenol, Î±â€‘ and Î²â€‘pinene, phellandrene, linalool, geraniol and terpineol are found.           Unripe bay fruits           Dried laurel fruits   TheÂ dried fruits conÂ­tain 0.6 to 10% of esÂ­sential oil, deÂ­pending on proÂ­venance and storage conÂ­ditions. Like the leaves, the aroma is mostly due to terpenes (cineol, terpineol, Î±â€‘ and Î²â€‘pinene, citral), but also cinnamic acid and its methyl ester are reported.          Bay leaf shrub   FromÂ laurel fruits, a green semiÂ­solid oil (melting point about 30Â Â°C) can be exÂ­tracted, which conÂ­tains several percent of esÂ­senÂ­tial oil (main comÂ­ponents are two sesquiÂ­terpenoids, costunol and dehydroÂ­costusÂ­lacton), but is mainly composed of fixed oil: TriÂ­glycerides of lauric acid (dodecanoic acid), myristic acid (tetraÂ­decanoic acid) and oleic acid (Zâ€‘octadec-9â€‘enoic acid).
origin: Probably Asia Minor. Today, the laurel tree grows all over the Mediterranean. Turkey is one of the main exporters.  Because of its poor resistance to freezes, laurel cannot be grown outdoors in more Northern regions (except some fortunate parts of Britain, I have been told). Contrary to some other originally Mediterranean plants, the common cultivation in medieval monasteries has not lead to more hardy breeds (see also lovage).           Bay leaf shrub           Branch of Bay Leaves
etymology: English laurel is derived from the Latin name of the tree, laurus. Almost all languages of Western, Central or Northern Europe have related names, e.â€‰g., German Lorbeer, Danish laurbÃ¦r, Swedish lager, Finnish laakeri, Italian alloro, Catalan llor, Portuguese louro, Slovenian lovor and Russian lavr [Ğ»Ğ°Ğ²Ñ€].  The origin of Latin laurus is not known with certainty; it is not related to Latin laus praise. Since Latin L often corresponds to Greek (and Proto-Indoâ€“European) D, there is the faint possibility of a connection to Greek daphne (see below). A more promising theory claims a hypothetical daurus as the original form, which would then be related to the Indoâ€“European root DERU tree, in particular oak (see juniper for its affiliation). It is interesting to observe that in oldest Greece, oak (drys [Î´Ïá¿¦Ï‚]) was the tree sacred to the god Zeus, while laurel took over this place in the classical period.           Laurel (bay leaf) tree           Bay twig   InÂ theÂ ancient Greek tongue, bay was named daphne [Î´á½±Ï†Î½Î·] after the nymph Daphne, who was turned to a laurel shrub to escape Apollonâ€™s perÂ­secution. The god Apollo, then, deveÂ­loped the habit to wear bay twigs in memory of his unÂ­returned love (it may seem noteÂ­worthy that the ancients conÂ­sidered this incident a tragedyÂ â€” for Apollo, who lost the girl he was after). The hapless nymph is still remembered in some languages of Eastern Europe and West Asia: Bay leaves are called dafin in Romanian, dafni [Î´Î¬Ï†Î½Î·] in Modern Greek, dapna [áƒ“áƒáƒ¤áƒœáƒ] in Georgian, defne in Turkish and dafinÃ« in Albanian. There are also names meaning leaves of Daphne: Hebrew aley daphna [×¢×œ×™ ×“×¤× ×”], Bulgarian dafinov list [Ğ´Ğ°Ñ„Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ² Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚] and Armenian tapni derev [Õ¤Õ¡Õ¢Õ¶Õ«-Õ« Õ¿Õ¥Ö€Õ¥Ö‚].  In modern botanical terminology, Daphne denotes the genus of the toxic plant spurge laurel (Daphne mezereum, Thymelaeaceae/Thymeleanales/Dilleniidae).  The English term bay leaf (Middle English baye, Old French baie) derives from Latin bacca berry, meaning originally the fruits.

used-plant-part: Leaves. The bark may be used as an inferior subÂ­stitute of cinnaÂ­mon or cassia.
sensory-quality: Strongly aromatic, somewhat reÂ­minisÂ­cent of cinnÂ­amon or cloves. Since Indian bay leaves come usually from wild or semi-cultivated plants, flavour and intensity are quite variable. Main constituents In the essential oil from the leaves, mostly monoterpenoides were found: Linalool (50%) is the major compound, whereas  Î±â€‘pinene, pâ€‘cymene, Î²â€‘pinene and limonene range around 5 to 10% each. Phenylpropanoids appear only in traces: Newer work reports 1% cinnamic aldehyde and no eugenol, whereas older literature speaks of traces of both compounds.          Unripe fruits sometimes appear in commercially sold Indian Bay-leaves           Indian bay leaf flower cluster  Origin South slopes of the HimaÂ­layas and the mounÂ­tains of North Eastern India, exÂ­tending into Burma. The main proÂ­duction areas are Nepal and Sikkim, but most of the harvest comes from wild or half-domesticated trees. note: In some books, daun salam is called Indian bay-leaf. This name stems from the time when Indonesia was generally known as East India and is misÂ­leading, because daun salam is known only in Indonesian and Malay cooking, and it is totally different from the Indian bay-leaf that is frequently mentioned in books on Northern Indian cuisine.
used-plant-part: Leaves. The small leaves turn brown on drying. Since they are rarely traded in Europe, Indonesian cook books suggest substitution by ordinary bay leaves, although there is not much similarity between the two spices.
sensory-quality: Aromatic and slightly sour/astringent, but quite weak. According to Indonesian cookbooks, the leaves should develop more flavour after short frying; however, I cannot confirm the procedure to increase the flavour significantly.           Fresh Indonesian bay leaf           Branch with fresh Indonesian Bay-leaves
main-constitÂ­uents: It is actually difficult to get inforÂ­mation of the conÂ­stituents of this spice. From IndoÂ­nesian sources, whose meaning I am barely able to guess, I take that the leaves contain flavonoids, tannins and alkaloids. TheÂ leavesÂ containÂ only tiny amounts of an essential oil (0.2%). As main components, eugenol, methylchavicol and citral have been identified.  The yield of essential oil was best when the leaves have been withered and dried for a few days.
origin: The tree grows wild in the Western part of the South East Asian peninsular (Burma to Malaysia) and in Western Indonesia. To my knowledge, its culinary use is restricted to Malaysia and Indonesia.
etymology: The genus Eugenia was named so in honour of Prince Eugene of Savoy; the species name polyantha many flowered is derived from Greek polys [Ï€Î¿Î»á½»Ï‚] many and anthos [á¼„Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚] flower. The Indonesian folk name daun salam literally means peace leaf, but I cannot explain this name further.

used-plant-part: Fresh leaves. The blue flowers are someÂ­times tried as a food colourÂ­ant (see also annatto).
sensory-quality: Borageâ€™s taste is rather weak and very similar to fresh cucumber. In addition, the leaves provide a unique, crunchy texture.           Borage flower close-up
main-constituÂ­ents: The leaves conÂ­tain an esÂ­senÂ­tial oil (below 0.1%) domiÂ­nated by 2,6 nonaÂ­dienal, which is also a main comÂ­ponents in cuÂ­cumber aroma (cuÂ­cumber alÂ­dehyde).           Borage flowers (close-up)   SeveralÂ non-volatile comÂ­ponents have also been identified, among those the toxic pyrrolÂ­izidine alkaloids interÂ­medine, lycopsÂ­amine, amabiline and supinine. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which are extremely common in the BoraginaÂ­ceae family, are powerful hepatoÂ­toxins that cause  severe liver damÂ­age on chronic inÂ­gestion, often with lethal outÂ­come.           Borage flowers (close-up)   AlthoughÂ the total pyrrolÂ­izidine alkaloids conÂ­centraÂ­tion in borage is exÂ­tremeÂ­ly small (around 10â€‰ppm in the dried herb), it has been argued that borage is an unsafe herb when used in folk mediÂ­cine; the risks assoÂ­ciÂ­ated with casual culinary usage are probably negliÂ­gible. In the flowers, thesinine (a non-toxic pyrrolÂ­izidine alkaloid) has been found.  TheÂ fixedÂ oil obtained from borage seeds (borage oil, starflower oil) is rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids, e.â€‰g., Î³â€‘linolÂ­enic acid (20%).  PyrÂ­roliziÂ­dine alkaloids seem to occur only in negligible traces in this oil, if at all.
origin: The plant grows wild in Central and Eastern Europe; it origin is probably the Western Mediterranean.             White-flowered borage www.ruehlemanns.de            Borage (flowering plant)            Borage plant
etymology: The name borage can, by way of French and Spanish, be traced back to Medieval Latin borrago. The latter name is generally accepted to have Arabic origin; it has been proposed to derive it from Andalusian Arabic abu buraq father of sweat (standard Arabic abu araq [Ø£Ø¨Ùˆ Ø¹Ø±Ù‚]) or from abu huras father of roughness. In the first case, the motive would be the use of borÂ­age leaÂ­ves in diaÂ­phoretic mediÂ­cines, in the secÂ­ond case the rough leaf surÂ­face.  ManyÂ EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages have names related to borage: French bourÂ­rache, German BorÂ­retsch, Serbo-Croatian boraÄ [Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‡], Basque borrai, Hungarian borrÃ¡gÃ³fÅ±, Greek borantsa [Î¼Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¬Î½Ï„ÏƒÎ±], and Bulgarian porech [Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ€ĞµÑ‡]. Also the Hebrew name of borage, borag [×‘×•×¨××’], is part of that series; I suspect it is a rather young loan.  Despite the Arabic origin of borage, modern Arabic has no related plant name. Instead, borage is often named himhim [Ø­Ù…Ø­Ù…], a name shared with related rough-leaved plants like bugloss (Echium) and oxtongue (Anchusa). A more specific Arabic name is lisan athaur [Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù† Ø§Ù„Ø«ÙˆØ±], which transparently means tongue of the bull (lisan [Ù„Ø³Ø§Ù†] tongue and thaur [Ø«ÙˆØ±] bull), obviously in reference to the thick, uneven leaves. The Semitic root TWR bull is remarkably similar to many Indoâ€“European terms for bull, e.â€‰g., archaic English steer (Old English steor), German Stier, Latin taurus and Greek tauros [Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚]. The reconstructed Proto-Indoâ€“European form, (s)taur-, is likely a loan from an ancient Semitic tongue.          Borage plant           Borage flowers   TheÂ characÂ­teristic cuÂ­cumber aroma of borage gives rise to names like Swedish gurkÂ­Ã¶rt, German GurkenÂ­kraut, Dutch komÂ­kommerÂ­kruid, Finnish kurkkuÂ­yrtti, BelaÂ­rusian aguroÄnik [Ğ°Ğ³ÑƒÑ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ½Ñ–Ğº] and Russian ogurechnaya trava [Ğ¾Ğ³ÑƒÑ€ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ°], all meaning cucumber herb; conÂ­cerning the second elements in these names, see mugwort  (-wort, -wurz, -Ã¶rt) and savory (-kraut, -kruid). Evidently, also the Baltic names (Lithuanian agurklÄ—, Latvian gurÄ·umÄ“tras, and Estonian kurgirohi) contain a cucumber element.           Borage flowers           Borage flower   ItÂ isÂ quiteÂ amazÂ­ing that GerÂ­manic lanÂ­guages have two different names for cucumber, which despite their similarity cannot be proven to be related.  EnglishÂ cuÂ­cumÂ­ber and Dutch komÂ­kommer can be traced back to Latin cucumis cuÂ­cumÂ­ber; that name canÂ­not be explained further, but is has surÂ­vived into modern botanical nomenÂ­clature, where the vegÂ­etable cuÂ­cumÂ­ber is known as Cucumis sativus. ComparaÂ­tively few Romance lanÂ­guages have conÂ­served the Latin word, e.â€‰g., French conÂ­combre and Catalan coÂ­gombre.  In contrast, Italian cetriolo cuÂ­cumÂ­ber derives from Latin citrullus watermelon, which in turn might be related to citrus (see lemon), and the Iberic name of cuÂ­cumÂ­ber, pepino, relates to Latin pepo pumpkin.          Borage flower   OnÂ theÂ other hand, German Gurke or NorÂ­weÂ­gian agurk derive from Late Greek anÂ­gouÂ­rion [á¼€Î³Â­Î³Î¿á½»Â­ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½] cuÂ­cumÂ­ber, which either beÂ­longs to Old Greek aoros [á¼„Ï‰ÏÎ¿Ï‚] green, imÂ­mature, or is a loan from a doubious Persian angarah melon.  The Greek word was transÂ­ferred to many Slavonic lanÂ­guages (Czech okurka, Russian ogurets [Ğ¾Ğ³ÑƒÑ€ĞµÑ†], Polish ogÃ³rek) and entered Modern German as a loan from Polish; from there, it spread to many tongues of Northern Europe: Swedish gurka, Norwegian agurk, Lithuanian agurkas, Latvian gurÄ·is and Estonian kurk. English gherkin also belongs to that group.   Quite confusingly, the German name Gurkenkraut is also used for dill, not because dill smells like cucumber (which it doesnâ€™t), but because German cooks almost automatically use dill to flavour cucumber dishes. mexican-chile-cultivars: A large number of names for different cultivars is used in Latin America, especially MÃ©xico. Fresh and dried chiles are often referred to by different names. The following table lists some of the most common types. used-plant-part: Berry fruits. Removal of seeds and veins results in a less pungent and more brightly coloured product.
sensory-quality: Sweet and aromatic. Some qualities show no pungency at all, others are fairly hot.
main-constituents: The pungent principle, capsaicin, is contained only in small amounts, as low as 0.001 to 0.005% in mild and 0.1% in hot cultivars (see chiles for details on capsaicin). Apart from capsaicin, the taste of paprika is mostly due to essential oil (<1%; with long-chain aliphatic hydrocarbons, fatty acids and their methyl esters); paprika scent is mostly due to a range of alkylmethoxypyrazines (e.â€‰g., 3-isobutyl 2-methoxy pyrazine, earthy flavour). Ripe paprika contains up to 6% sugar. Furthermore, paprika contains sizable amounts (0.1%) of vitamin C; this substance was first isolated from ripe paprika pods by the Hungarian chemist Albert Szent-GyÃ¶rgy, who later won the Nobel Prize for this work.  Paprikas derive their colour in the ripe state mainly from carotenoid pigments,  which range from bright red (capsanthrine, capsorubin and more) to yellow (cucubitene); total carotenoid content in dried paprika is 0.1 to 0.5%.  Chile cultivars which produce yellow but no or little red pigments appear yellow to orange when ripe. A small number of cultivars does not produce significant amounts of carotenoids; when chlorophyll levels decrease in the last stages of ripening, these chiles develop a pale hue often referred to as white. Due to small amounts of chlorophyll and/or yellow carotenoids, the white is, however, more precisely described as a pale greenishâ€“yellow.           Black Prince, an ornamental breed rich in anthocyanin pigments (tepÃ­n- or piquÃ­n type).   SomeÂ varieÂ­ties of paprika contain pigments of anthoÂ­cyanin type and develop dark purple, auberÂ­gine-coloured or almost black pods; in the last stage of ripening, however, the anthocyanins get decomposed, and the unusual darkness thus gives way to normal orange or red colours.  The same anthocyanins cause the dark spots which are sometimes seen on unripe fruits or particularly the stems of paprika plants and which almost all paprika varieties can develop. In other Capsicum species, anthocyanin production is a rare phenomenon (e.â€‰g., scarlet lantern, an Andean cultivar of C. chinense). Origin Since different varieties of bell peppers have been cultivated in America long before the arrival of the Europeans, their native countries cannot be unambiguously determined;  South American origin is, however, established for all species of genus Capsicum, which emerged probably in the area bordering Southern Brazil and Bolivia. Thence, the species moved to the North, being dispersed by birds.           Bolivian Rainbow chile (flowers and unripe fruits)   TheÂ threeÂ species C. annuum, C. frutescens and C. chinense evolved from a common ancestor located in the North of the Amazon basin (NW-Brazil, Columbia). Further evolution brought C. annuum and C. frutescens to Central America, where they were finally domesticated (in MÃ©xico and PanamÃ¡, respectively), whereas C. chinense moved to the West and was first put to cultivation in PerÃº; (although today it is not much cultivated in South America). Two other species were first cultivated in Western South America: C. baccatum in the Peruvian lowlands and C. pubescens at higher elevations, in the Andes (PerÃº, Bolivia, Ecuador). See chile for more information about these species.  As paprika plants tolerate nearly every climate, the fruits are produced all over the world. A fairly warm climate is, however, necessary for a  strong aroma; therefore, in Europe, Hungarian paprika has best reputation; the best comes from the Kalocsa region.  In the Unites States, California and Texas are the main producers.             Bolivian Rainbow Hybride with multicoloured fruits            An ornamental named Peter Pepper              Black Namaqualand, a South African ornamental containing anthocyanins            Prairiefire, an ornamental of piquin type. Â© Sabine Amtsberg   Etymology In many European languages, the name of this spice is somehow derived from the name of pepper, owing to the many confusions of pepper with other spices (for another example, see  allspice).  A rather common designation of paprika is sweet pepper: Spanish pimiento dulce, French piment doux, Kazakh qÄ±zÄ±l burÄ±ÅŸ [Ò›Ñ‹Ğ·Ñ‹Ğ» Ğ±Ò±Ñ€Ñ‹Ñˆ] and Arabic fulful halu [ÙÙ„ÙÙ„ Ø­Ù„Ùˆ]. Note that in most of these languages, the word for pepper may also mean chile, so it would perhaps be more accurate to translate these names by sweet chile or sweet chile pepper. In the same spirit, Chinese tian jiao [ç”œæ¤’] literally means sweet Sichuan pepper (not to be confused with gan jiao [ç”˜æ¤’], which has the same literal meaning but refers to allspice).  YetÂ otherÂ tonguesÂ have names for paprika that mean red pepper, e.â€‰g., Turkish kÄ±rmÄ±zÄ± biber, Armenian garmir bghbegh [Õ¯Õ¡Ö€Õ´Õ«Ö€ ÕºÕ²ÕºÕ¥Õ²], Bulgarian cherven piper [Ñ‡ĞµÑ€Ğ²ĞµĞ½ Ğ¿Ğ¸Ğ¿ĞµÑ€] and Russian perets krasni [Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµÑ† ĞºÑ€Ğ°ÑĞ½Ñ‹Ğ¹]. These may lead to confusion as in a plethora of other lanÂ­guages, similar names are reserved for chiles.  OtherÂ English names are bell pepper and pod pepper because of the shape.  Most confusingly, the English plural peppers always seem to imply some sort of paprika (also vegetable bell peppers or hot chile peppers), and never true black pepper! For reasons of clarity, the term pepper for Capsicum species will be totally avoided on this page. Instead, I will use paprika throughout for mild or medium-hot varieties and chile for hot varieties.  The word paprika was borrowed from Hungarian (paprika) or Serbian (paprika [Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ĞºĞ°]); it entered a great number of languages, in many cases probably via German. In the end, also paprika is derived from a name of black pepper, in this case Serbian papar [Ğ¿Ğ°Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€]. In most languages, paprika denotes the dried spice only, though in some (e.â€‰g., German) it is commonly used for the vegetable bell pepper. The form paprika is valid in countless European languages, while examples with slightly deviating spelling include Italian paprica, Polish papryka, Bulgarian piperka [Ğ¿Ğ¸Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞºĞ°], Hebrew paprika [×¤×¤×¨×™×§×”] and Japanese papurika [ãƒ‘ãƒ—ãƒªã‚«].  The botanical species name Capsicum is a neo-Latin derivation of Greek kapsa [Îºá½±ÏˆÎ±] box, capsule and refers to the shape of the fruits. There is an alternative, though much less probable, derivation starting from a related verb, kaptein [Îºá½±Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½], translated bite. The verbâ€™s basic meaning, however, is seize, grasp; it may also mean grab using the teeth; bite, but even from this meaning itâ€™s a wide semantic shift to biting in the sense of pungent. The old German name BeiÃŸbeere biting berry for hot chiles is probably a loan translation based on the false etymology.  The genus name annuum means annual (Latin annus year). This name was chosen most unfortunately, because in the absence of winter frosts, paprika and its relatives can survive several seasons. In its natural habitat, paprika grows into large perennial shrubs. used-plant-part: Fresh leaves. The plant forms two types of leaves: The rosette conÂ­sists of up to 10 long leaves with palatÂ­able texture, while leaves on the stalks are smaller and tougher. The bracts enÂ­shrouding the flower heads are almost woody and someÂ­what spiny; they can hardly be eaten, unÂ­less purÃ©d.
sensory-quality: Aroma strong, very similar to fresh coriander leaves; taste similar, but even stronger.
main-constituents: The essential oil from the leaves of long coriander is rich in aliÂ­phatic aldehydes, most of which are Î±,Î² unsaturated. The impact comÂ­pound is E-2-dodecenal (60%), furtherÂ­more 2,3,6-trimethylÂ­benzÂ­aldehyde  (10%), dodecanal (7%) and E-2-tridecenal (5%) have been identiÂ­fied. AliÂ­phatic aldehydes appear also in other spices with coriander-like scent (e.â€‰g., VietÂ­namese coriander).  YetÂ another essential oil can be obtained from the root; in the root oil, unsaturated alicyclic or aromatic aldehydes dominate (2,3,6-trimethylÂ­benzÂ­aldehyde  40%, 2-formyl 1,1,5-trimethyl cycloÂ­hexa-2,5-dien-4-ol 10%, 2-formyl 1,1,5-trimethyl cycloÂ­hexa-2,4-dien-6-ol 20%, 2,3,4-trimethylÂ­benzÂ­aldeÂ­hyde).  InÂ theÂ essenÂ­tial oil from the seeds, sesquiÂ­terpenoids (carotol 20%, Î²-farnesene 10%), phenylÂ­propanoids (anethole) and monoÂ­terpenes (Î±-pinene) were found, but no aldehydes. Origin The plant is native to the Caribbean islands. Today, is has been introduced to large parts of South East Asia (Indochina, Malaysia, Indonesia). Etymology The derivation of culantro and racao, two names by which the plant is known in Central America, is not known to me; the former is maybe just a variant of cilantro (see coriander).  ManyÂ namesÂ in languages that are spoken outside the natural habitat of long coriander refer to the extraÂ­ordinary olfactoric similarity with common coriander. Common denominations in EuroÂ­pean languages include Mexican coriander (Hugarian MexikÃ³i koriander),  wild coriander (PortuÂ­guese coentro-bravo) and most frequently long coriander, e.â€‰g. German Langer Koriander or Slovak koriander dlhÃ½ (the adjectives are cognates, both deriving von Proto-Indoâ€“EuroÂ­pean dhlongÊ°os long). One also should mention the ill-chosen Russian name VietÂ­namski koriandr [Ğ’ÑŒĞµÑ‚Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼ÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ ĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ñ€] VietÂ­namese coriander: Inmany other laguages, that name refers to another culnary herb (also called VietÂ­namese coriander on this page) that has a better claim to that name, because while both herbs do occur in VietÂ­namese cooking, only VietÂ­namese coriander is really native to South East Asia.           Plant with flower-bearing stalk           Wild growing Long Coriander plant   NamesÂ inÂ many Asian lanÂ­guages are formed in a similar way: ExÂ­amples include Chinese ci yuan sui [åˆºèŠ«è½] pricky coriander, Nepali dhaniya vermeli [à¤§à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤²à¥€] wild coriander, Hindi ban-dhania [à¤¬à¤¨ à¤§à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾] forest coriander, Malayalam (with some geoÂ­graphic conÂ­fusion) aphrikan malli [à´†à´«àµà´°à´¿à´•àµà´•àµ» à´®à´²àµà´²à´¿] African coriander, Malay ketumbar Jawa Jawanese coriander (although I havenâ€™t seen it in Jawa) and Thai pakchi farang [à¸œà¸±à¸à¸Šà¸µà¸à¸£à¸±à¹ˆà¸‡]  foreign coriander. Note, however, that the Thai name pak chi farang may also mean parsley, which also deserves to be called foreign coriander, the similarities being more visual than olfactory; lookup errors in the dictionary may then result in long coriander being labelled as parsley in Asian supermarkts.          Wild growing Long Coriander plant   TheÂ ThaiÂ term farang [à¸à¸£à¸±à¹ˆà¸‡] foreign, Western, European has a complex history and derives, in last conÂ­sequence, from the name of a Germanic people, the Franks! In Medieval Europe, the Franks had occupied a powerful position (see also lovage for the herbal edict of CharleÂ­magne), and a large percentage of the Crusaders were Franks. So it was natural to call the continent Europe just firanja Frank country in Arabic. Modern Standard Arabic forms are ifranji [Ø¥ÙØ±Ù†Ø¬ÙŠ] (noun), faranj [ÙØ±Ù†Ø¬Ù‰] (adjective) European, where the initial variation (ifra vs. far) results from different strategies to avoid the initial consonant cluster. From Arabic, the word spread eastward, e.â€‰g. Urdu frangistan [ÙØ±Ù†Ú¯Ø³ØªØ§Ù†], Sanskrit phiranga [à¤«à¤¿à¤°à¤‚à¤—] and Kannada paramgi [à²ªà²°à²‚à²—à²¿] Europe, and Kurdish farangi [ÙØ©Ø±Ø©Ù†Ú¯ÛŒ], Dhivehi faranjee [ŞŠŞ¦ŞƒŞ¦Ş‚Ş°Ş–Ş©], and Khmer barang [á”á¶ášá¶áŸ†á„] foreigner.    English saw leaf herb (also sawtooth coriander) refers to the serrated leafs, which loosely remind to a saw blade.           Flowering long coriander   TheÂ botanicÂ­al genus name Eryngium goes back to the Greek name of the related sea holly (Eryngium maritimum), which was called eryngion [á¼ Ïá½»Î³Î³Î¹Î¿Î½]; the name is probably related to er [á¼¦Ï] spring time (cognate to Latin ver). The genus name foetidus is Latin and means stinking, bad smelling, ugly; similar names are also found in modern languages, e.â€‰g. Russian sinegolovnik vonyuchi [ÑĞ¸Ğ½ĞµĞ³Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¸Ğº Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ½ÑÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ¹] stinking eryngium or Singhalese andu kuppa [à¶…à¶³à·” à¶šà·”à¶´à·Šà¶´] stinking weed.
