main-constiÂ­tuents: In the ripe fruits, the conÂ­tent of essenÂ­tial oil is comÂ­parably low (typicÂ­ally, less than 1%); the oil consists mainly of linalool (50 to 60%) and about 20% terpenes (pinenes, Î³-terÂ­pinene, myrcene, camphene, phellÂ­andrenes, Î±-terÂ­pinene, limonene, cymene).  InÂ toasted coriander fruits, pyrazines are formed as the main flavour comÂ­pounds (see cumin).          Coriander umbel   TheÂ tasteÂ of the fresh herb is due to an esÂ­senÂ­tial oil (0.1%) that is alÂ­most enÂ­tireÂ­ly made up of  aliÂ­phatic alÂ­dehydes with 10 to 16 carbon atoms. One finds both saturated (decanal)  and Î±,Î² unsaturated (trans-2-tridecenal) aldehydes; the same aldehydes appear in the unripe fruits.  Similar compounds occur in a few other spices and herbs, all of which share corianderâ€™s flavour: Examples include long coriander, Vietnamese coriander and the Japanese chemotype of chameleon plant.
origin: Probably Eastern Mediterranean (Greece) or Asia Minor.             Coriander field            Coriander flowers            Flowering coriander plant   TheÂ coriander grown in Russia and Central Europe (var. micrÂ­ocarpum) has smaller fruits (less than 3â€‰mm) and contains more essential oil than the oriental variety var. vulgare (greater than 3â€‰mm), which is cultivated for fruits and leaves.
etymology: The names of coriander in all Western European languages can be traced back to Latin coriandrum and Greek koriannon [ÎºÎ¿Ïá½·Î±Î½Î½Î¿Î½]. The Greek name exists in several variant forms, e.â€‰g., korion [Îºá½¹ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½] in Dioskurides and koriadna [ğ€’ğ€ªğ€Šğ€…ğ€™] in Mycenaean Greek. It is usually put into relation with koris [Îºá½¹ÏÎ¹Ï‚] bug, because of the aroma of the leaves, but it is more probably a loan from an ancient MediÂ­terÂ­raÂ­nean tongue and might be disÂ­tantly reÂ­lated to Greek karon [Îºá½±ÏÎ¿Î½] cumin and Biblical Hebrew gad [×’×“] coÂ­rianÂ­der.          Coriander flowers   TheÂ German names WanzenÂ­dill (bugâ€™s dill)  and WanzenÂ­kÃ¼mmel (bugâ€™s caraway) may be loan transÂ­lations of the Greek name, but I think they perhaps arose inÂ­depenÂ­dently. The names are clearly derogaÂ­tory and reflect the critical attitude towards coriander leaves common among Central or North EuroÂ­peans.  In Latin America and also in the USA, coriander leaves are commonly known by the name cilantro. This word has the same origin as coriander, and it is difficult to explain the differing  vowel. Maybe cilantro is directly derived from a Latin variant with light vowel, e.â€‰g., Medieval Latin  celiandrum. Another explanation claims that the Spanish name was first culantro, later changed to cilantro for some reason; in any case, culantro exists in todayâ€™s Mesoamerican Spanish, but usually denotes not coriander but a similar smelling herb, long coriander. Confusingly, on some Caribbean islands, long coriander is known as cilantro and coriander as cilantrillo.          Flowering coriander plant   ManyÂ AsianÂ tonÂ­gues have interÂ­related names for coriander, e.â€‰g.,  IndoÂ­nesian ketumbar, Dhivehi kotanbiri [Ş†Ş®ŞŒŞ¦Ş‚Ş„Ş¨ŞƒŞ¨], Tamil kotaÂ­malli [à®•à¯Šà®¯à¯à®¤Â­à®®à®²à¯à®²à®¿], Telugu kustumÂ­buru [à°•à±à°¸à±à°¤à±à°‚Â­à°¬à±à°°à±], Gujarati kothmir [àª•à«‹àª¥àª®à«€àª°], Urdu kothamir [Ú©ÙˆØªÚ¾Ù…ÛŒØ±] and Arabic al-kuzbara [Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ²Ø¨Ø±Ø©]. This group seems to be of ancient origin, as it has members also in Sanskrit (kustumbari [à¤•à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤‚à¤¬à¤°à¥€]) and Akkadian (kisibirru [ğ’Šºğ’‡½]). Its relation to coriander (if any) is not known.  Another,Â perÂ­haps related, group of names originating from Middle Persian gishniz is found in Western to Central Asia: Farsi geshniz [Ú¯Ø´Ù†ÛŒØ²], Urdu kishniz [Ú©Ø´Ù†ÛŒØ²], Tajik gashnich [Ğ³Ğ°ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‡], Uzbek kashnich [ĞºĞ°ÑˆĞ½Ğ¸Ñ‡], Azeri keÅŸniÅŸ, Turkish kiÅŸniÅŸ and also Russian kishnets [ĞºĞ¸ÑˆĞ½ĞµÑ†]. The names in the Caucasus countries (Georgian kindzi [áƒ¥áƒ˜áƒœáƒ«áƒ˜], Ossetian kindzae [ĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ğ´Ğ·Ó•] and Armenian kinj [Õ£Õ«Õ¶Õ±]) are perhaps related and have been transferred, via Russian kinza [ĞºĞ¸Ğ½Ğ·Ğ°], to some more languages of the Soviet Union (Latvian kinzas). I also suspect Coptic sheshnou [Ï£Ï£â²›â²Ÿâ²©] to belong to that group.  Because of similar shape and usage, coriander leaves are named after parsley, often with a geographic epithet: Indian parsley and Chinese parsley are most often heard. The Hungarian name cigÃ¡nyÂ­petrezselyem gypsiesâ€™ parsley should also be named in this context, although I am not sure of the motivation behind.

used-plant-part: Leaves, always used fresh.
sensory-quality: The herb has a coriander-like smell with a clear lemony note. Pungency, which dominates in the closely related water pepper, is hardly present. See also lemon myrtle about citrus-scented spices.
main-constituents: In the essential oil of Vietnamese coriander, long-chain aldehydes were found, e.â€‰g., decanal (28%) and dodecanal (44%), furthermore decanol (11%). Sesquiterpenes (Î±-humulene, Î²-caryophyllene) account for about 15% of the essential oil. origin: VietÂ­namese coriander is native to penÂ­insular SouthÂ­east Asia (IndoÂ­china), where it grows in wet environÂ­ments.
etymology: The old genus name PolyÂ­gonum (English: knotÂ­weed) refers to the shape of the stem, which is composed of many joints linked together by slightly bent knots or knees: Greek polys [Ï€Î¿Î»á½»Ï‚] many and gony [Î³á½¹Î½Ï…] knee; cf. also English knotweed. The new genus name Persicaria derives from the name of peach (Prunus persica), because of similar leaf shape.  In Singapore, Vietnamese coriander is known as laksa plant (also laksa herb or laksa leaves); in Singaporean Cantonese, there is the equivalent name laksa yip [å–‡æ²™è‘‰]. These names reflects the usage of Vietnamese coriander for the Chinese-Malaysian noodle curry laksa, which in turn is apparently named for its many ingredients: The Hindi term lakh [à¤²à¤¾à¤–], also often used by Indians when speaking English, means hundred thousand or metonymically many, being  derived from synonymous Sanskrit laksha [à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·] or lakshya [à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯].  The term Vietnamese mint frequently found in English literature is botanic nonsense, as peppermint belongs to a distant plant family, Lamiaceae.

note: The IndoÂ­nesian term jeruk may equally apply to various citrus fruits (lemon, lime, orange).
used-plant-part: The peel (pericarp) of the fruit is used as a spice; also the fruit juice is culinarily valuable. Of the related citron, the thick pericarp  is used to prepare candied lemon peel (succade).           Succade (candied citron)           Lemon   DespiteÂ their strong and refreshing lemon fragrance, lemon leaves are hardly ever used in the kitchen.
sensory-quality: Lemon has a characteristic, refreshing and sour odour. See lemon myrtle for a comparative discussion on lemon fragrance. The fruit juice is very sour. A fuller discussion about acidic spices is given with mango.           Lemon flower           Nepalese citron (bimara [à¤¬à¤¿à¤®à¤°à¤¾])
main-constituents: The fruit juice mainly contains sugars and fruit acids, mainly citric acid (8%).  LemonÂ peel consists of two layers: The outermost layer (pericarp, zest) contains an essential oil (6%), that is mostly composed of limonene (90%) and citral (5%) plus traces of citronellal, Î±-terpineol, linalyl and geranyl acetate. The inner layer (mesoÂ­carp), on the other hand, contains no essenÂ­tial oil but a variety of bitter flavone glycoÂ­sides and coumarin derivÂ­atives.
origin: Origin of all Citrus species is unclear because of their ancient cultivation (see also orange); C. limon is thought native in Central Asia; there is rumour that some wild populations of citron can still be found in Iran.  Today, lemons are cultivated in many tropic or subtropical countries. The USA and MÃ©xico are the main producers; MÃ©xico, due to its tropic climate, mostly accounts for limes. In Europe, most lemons actually stem from Spain or Italy.  CitronÂ isÂ of comparaÂ­tively little economic value. It is mostly grown in Sicily, Greece and Corsica.              Three-leaved lemon, Poncirus trifoliata, flower. Because it is largely frost-tolerant, this species is often grafted with the more delicate edible citrus cultivars.            Three-leaved lemon flowers www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de            Three-leaves lemon fruits  Fruit is inedible, abut highly aromatic. www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de            Three-leaved lemon, Poncirus trifoliata.              Citron flower            Unripe citron            Ripe lemon
etymology: Citrus is, in last conÂ­sequence, derived from Greek kedromelon [ÎºÎµÎ´ÏÎ¿Â­Î¼á¿†Î»Î¿Î½] apple of cedar (Greek melon [Î¼á¿†Î»Î¿Î½] is cognate to Latin malum apple); this name, however, did not signify  lemon, but citron whose cultiÂ­vation in Egypt is reported by Greek travelÂ­lers.  The Romans, then, shortened the Greek name to citrus.  Names for lemon in a large number of European tongues derive from Latin citrus, e.â€‰g., German Zitrone, French citron, Finnish sitruuna, Latvian citrons, Czech citrÃ³n, Polish cytryna, Hungarian citrom, Yiddish zitstrin [×–×™×¦×˜×¨×™×Ÿ] and Armenian gidron [Õ¯Õ«Õ¿Ö€Õ¸Õ¶], all of which mean lemon. Some languages have similar names for the more ancient fruit, citron, which should not be confused with lemon: Croatian Äetrun, Polish cytron, French cÃ©drat, 	Italian cedro, Russian tsedrat [Ñ†ĞµĞ´Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚] and Greek kitro [ÎºÎ¯Ï„ÏÎ¿].  English lemon, and a number of other names for that fruit, derive from Arabic al-limun [Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ…ÙˆÙ†] lemon; see lime for more. The botanical species epithet of citron, medicus, alludes to the Medes, a Persian tribe, who are supposed to have introduced citron to the Mediterranean countries. This is modelled on the Classical Greek name of citron, melea he Medike [Î¼Î·Î»á½³Î± á¼¡ ÎœÎ·Î´Î¹Îºá½µ] Median apple (also melea he Persike [Î¼Î·Î»á½³Î± á¼¡ Î ÎµÏÏƒÎ¹Îºá½µ] Persian apple) for citron. There is no etymological connection to medicine (the Linnean species epithet for that would have been medicinalis), which derives from the same root as measure and meter.           Citron fruit (ornamental) www.desert-tropicals.com           Buddhaâ€™s hands, an ornamental citron variety www.zitrusgaertnerei.de           Edible citron http://www.isolotto.com   TheÂ someÂ­what puzzeling German name ZitronatÂ­zitrone  citron is a simple tatpuruÂ­sha comÂ­pound (primÂ­ary word Zitrone leÂ­mon, deterÂ­minaÂ­tive  eleÂ­ment Zitronat sucÂ­cade) meanÂ­ing lemon whose peel is used for making sucÂ­cade; the same holds for HunÂ­garian cÃ©drÃ¡tÂ­citrom, and also Finnish sukaatti seems to be derived from sucÂ­cade. In Dutch, citron is called muskusÂ­citroen musky lemon; see nutÂ­meg on the word musk.  IÂ wasÂ notÂ able to find a definitive etymology for the term succade candied citron peel. I guess that it is derived from Hebrew sukkot or sukoth [×¡×•×›×•×ª] which refers to the Jewish Feast of TaberÂ­nacles, a religious rite involving, among others, citron fruit (etrog [××ª×¨×•×’]) and myrtle branches (hadas [×”×“×¡]). Some sources, however, trace the name back to Latin succus juice. A third possibility is to relate succade to sugar or a cognate (e.â€‰g., French sucre). Names of sugar in almost all European tongues come, via Old Italian zucchero, Late Latin saccharum, Greek sakcharon [Ïƒá½±ÎºÏ‡Î±ÏÎ¿Î½] and Persian shakar (today Farsi shakar [Ø´Ú©Ø±]) from Sanskrit sharkara [à¤¶à¤°à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¾] sugar, which originally meant pebbles or grit and was also used to denote crystallized sugar, which was a genuine Indian invention.  In India, lemon is not much known, as the tropcal climate favours lime as the sour citrus fruit. Yet, in the Himalaya, true lemon is grown together with lime. The two fruits are both called nimbu in Hindi; if desired, a distinction can be made between bara nimbu [à¤¬à¥œà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚] big nimbu (lemon) and chota nimbu [à¤›à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚] small nimbu (lime). Lemon-like fruits are also found in North-Eastern India: In the Khasi and Garo Hills, and in the states bordering Burma.

sensory-quality: Fresh and lemon-like, with a hint of rose fragrance. See also lemon myrtle on lemon fragrance. MainÂ conÂ­stituents The essential oil of lemon grass (0.2 to 0.5%, West Indian lemon grass oil) consists mainly of citral. Further terpenoids in lemon grass oil are nerol, limonene, linalool and Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene. The content of myrcene is low, but still enough to make the oil susÂ­ceptÂ­ible to oxidaÂ­tive polyÂ­meriÂ­zaÂ­tion.  CitralÂ isÂ aÂ mixtureÂ of two stereoÂ­isomeric monoÂ­terpene aldeÂ­hydes; in lemon grass oil, the trans isomer geranial (40 to 62%) domiÂ­nates over the cis isomer neral (25 to 38%).  EastÂ Indian lemon grass oil is distilled from a related species, C. flexuosus. It consists of alcohols (20 to 30% citronellol, geraniol) and aldehydes (15% geranial, 10% neral, 5% citronellal). This species is domiÂ­nantly used in the perfume industry as it contains less myrcene and, thereÂ­fore, has a longer shelf life.          Lemon grass stem base   TwoÂ further species have conÂ­siderÂ­able releÂ­vance for the perfume industry: The so-called palmaÂ­rosa oil is diÂ­stilled from CymboÂ­pogon martini (Roxb.) J.F. WatÂ­son var. martini (native to India, cultiÂ­vated also in Jawa) and contains mainly geraniol (75%) and geranyl acetate (12%). Also worth mentioning is citronella grass  (Cymbopogon winterianus Jowitt) which also stems from India, but is today grown throughout the tropics; its main constituents are citronellal (35%), geraniol (25%) and citronellol (10%) plus minor amounts of geranyl acetate (5%).          Lemon grass plant kanchanapisek.or.thÂ Â Â Â Â Â  Â© Thai Junior Encyclopedia           Base of the stem of lemon grass  Origin The genus has about 55 species, most of which are native to South Asia, SouthÂ­east Asia and AustraÂ­lia. The so-called East-Indian lemon grass (CymboÂ­pogon flexuosus [Nees ex Steudel] J.F. Watson) is native to India, Sri Lanka, Burma and ThaiÂ­land; for the related West-Indian lemon grass (C. citratus [DC] Stapf), a Malesian origin is generally asÂ­sumed. You might note that the epiÂ­theta East and West are here applied quite randomly. Both species are today cultivated throughÂ­out tropical Asia.          Base of the stem of lemon grass           Lemon grass plant   AlthoughÂ the two species can almost be used interÂ­changeÂ­ably, C. citratus is more releÂ­vant for cooking. In India, it is cultiÂ­vated as a medical herb and for perÂ­fumes, but not used as a spice; in the rest of tropical Asia (mostly South East Asia, more marÂ­ginally in Sri Lanka), it is an imporÂ­tant culiÂ­nary herb and spice.           Lemon gras stems           Lemon grass plant  Etymology The botanical genus name CymboÂ­pogon is derived from Greek kymbe [Îºá½»Î¼Î²Î·] boat and pogon [Ï€á½½Î³Ï‰Î½] beard; it refers to the boat-shaped spathes and the many-eared infloresÂ­cences which reÂ­mind to a beard.  TheÂ speciesÂ name citratus obviously relates to the proÂ­minent lemon fraÂ­grance of that plant. Similarly, most EuroÂ­pean names of lemon grass are either adapted from local names of lemon (citroÂ­nella) or are comÂ­pounds meaning lemon herb (Finnish sitruunaÂ­ruoho, Portuguese  erva-cidreira, Turkish limon otu, Chinese ning meng xiang mao [æª¸æª¬é¦™èŒ…] lemon-flavoured plant) or particularly often lemon-grass (Danish citrongrÃ¦s, Lithuanian citrinÅ¾olÄ—, Czech citrÃ³novÃ¡ trÃ¡va, Estonian sidrunhein, Hungarian citromfÅ±). Similar compounds are Russian limonnoe sorgo [Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ½Ğ¾Ğµ ÑĞ¾Ñ€Ğ³Ğ¾] lemon-sorghum and Spanish te de limÃ³n lemon tea. The various names of lemon are further explained under lemon and lime.  Arabic hashisha al-limun [Ø­Ø´ÙŠØ´Ø© Ø§Ù„Ù„ÙŠÙ…ÙˆÙ†] contains hashish [Ø­Ø´ÙŠØ´] grass, which is known as a euphemistic term for cannabis in the West. The arabic name for water pipe, shisha [Ø´ÙŠØ´Ø©], may be related, although others derive it from Farsi shisheh [Ø´ÛŒØ´Ù‡] glass in reference to the material the pipe is made from. The latter would be analogous to Persian nargileh (see coconut for its derivation).           Lemon grass plant           Leaves of lemon grass   TheÂ EnglishÂ word grass and its Latin cognate gramen (from older grasmen) (grass)-blade, stalk canÂ­not be exÂ­plained easily. It is probably conÂ­nected to an Proto-Indoâ€“EuropeanÂ­pean root reÂ­ferÂ­ring to plant growth (GÊ°REHâ‚‚ or GÊ°RÄ’ project out, sprout, grow, with grow and green as close English kin); in German, the basic meaning is preÂ­served in Grat ridge, crest and GrÃ¤te fish bone. On the other hand, given the imporÂ­tance of grass as an animal fodder, it is hardly coÂ­inciÂ­denÂ­tal that a similar Proto-Indoâ€“EuropeanÂ­pean root, GRAS, means devour, digest (see cress for more inforÂ­mation on this root).  The mediÂ­eval English name squinant is a corÂ­ruption of earlier schoenanth and derives from two Greek words, schoinos [ÏƒÏ‡Î¿á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚] rush, grass (see also chives) and anthos [á¼„Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚] flower.  Another name of that period is Dutch kamelhewe and Yiddish kemlhey [×§×¢××œ×”×²] camelâ€™s hay which refers to the caravans that transported dried lemongrass on the back of camels from tropical Asia to Europe (spice route). Lemon grass was used for beer brewing (see gale) and preparation of spiced wines.  It is an open question whether lemon grass was already known in antiquity, as many aromatics of ancient texts have not yet been identified. A possible candidate is the Biblical qaneh [×§Ö¸× Ö¶×”] which appears to denote a kind of grassy plant or reed; if often occurs in the meaning branch.  Yet on some occasions, it is listed among aromatics (e.â€‰g., in the Song of Songs) and there are not so many grass-shaped aromatic plants to chose from. Conservative wisdom has it translated calamus, but lemon grass would also appear a possibility. The mediÂ­eval English name squinant is a corÂ­ruption of earlier schoenanth and derives from two Greek words, schoinos [ÏƒÏ‡Î¿á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚] rush, grass (see also chives) and anthos [á¼„Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚] flower.  Another name of that period is Dutch kamelhewe and Yiddish kemlhey [×§×¢××œ×”×²] camelâ€™s hay which refers to the caravans that transported dried lemongrass on the back of camels from tropical Asia to Europe (spice route). Lemon grass was used for beer brewing (see gale) and preparation of spiced wines.  It is an open question whether lemon grass was already known in antiquity, as many aromatics of ancient texts have not yet been identified. A possible candidate is the Biblical qaneh [×§Ö¸× Ö¶×”] which appears to denote a kind of grassy plant or reed; if often occurs in the meaning branch.  Yet on some occasions, it is listed among aromatics (e.â€‰g., in the Song of Songs) and there are not so many grass-shaped aromatic plants to chose from. Conservative wisdom has it translated calamus, but lemon grass would also appear a possibility. note: The IndoÂ­nesian term jeruk may equally apply to various citrus fruits (lemon, lime, orange).
used-plant-part: Juice and fruit skin (pericarp). The fruits are almost always picked when unripe (green), and are usually consumed before they reach the ripe state (yellow).
sensory-quality: Limes have an odour similar to lemon, but more fresh (see also lemon myrtle). The juice is as sour as lemon juice, but more aromatic.
main-constituents: Lime pericarp contains an essential oil (7%), whose main components are citral, limonene, Î²-pinene and fenchone (up to 15%). Further aroma comÂ­pounds are terpineol, bisabolene and other terpenÂ­oids.           Lime flower www.csdl.tamu.edu           Lime flower           Lime flower www.csdl.tamu.edu
origin: In conÂ­trast to the more subÂ­tropical lemon, lime requires tropical climate. It probably stems from SouthÂ­east Asia, where many more related species grow wild (e.g, kaffir lime).  Today, many difÂ­ferent lime varieÂ­ties are known and cultiÂ­vated. Small-fruited cultiÂ­vars are often more aroÂ­matic; in the US, they are called key limes, since they are (or were) grown on Key West. Limes cultivated in tropical Asia have similar fruits: They are small, spherical and rather smooth. Large-fruited cultivars (Tahiti, Bearss) are often regarded inferior.  Lime juice resembles lemon juice it its content in citric acid (8%), but it contains much less ascorbic acid (VitaminÂ C) than the latter.             Lime twig with prickles            Unripe lime on tree            Ripening limes           Ripening lime  Etymology On the botanical genus name Citrus, see lemon. The species name aurantiÂ­folius orange-leaved is derived from an outdated botanical name of orange, Citrus aurantium.  TheÂ English term lime has many relatives in other European languages, for example German Limette, Dutch limoen, Polish limetka, Italian lima or limetta, French limon or limette, Greek and Hebrew  laim [Î»Î¬Î¹Î¼, ×œ×™×™×] and also Japanese raimu [ãƒ©ã‚¤ãƒ ]. Yet very similar names exist in some languages for the lemon, e.â€‰g., English lemon, Portuguese limÃ£o, Italian limone, Croatian limun, Slovenian limona, Albanian and Georgian limoni [áƒšáƒ˜áƒ›áƒáƒœáƒ˜], Bulgarian and Hebrew limon [Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ½, ×œ×™××•×Ÿ] and also Japanese remon [ã‚Œã‚‚ã‚“, ãƒ¬ãƒ¢ãƒ³].  All these names originate from Arabic limun [Ù„ÙŠÙ…ÙˆÙ†] and Persian limou [Ù„ÛŒÙ…Ùˆ] lemon which can both also be used for limes (the two fruits have a long and not yet finished history of mutual confusion). The further origin of the word is dark, but one can safely assume a connection to Sanskrit nimbu [à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚] or nimbuka [à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚à¤•] lime; some have also assumed a derivation from Chinese ning-meng [æª¸æª¬] lemon, but this itself looks rather like a loanword to me.  Limes, being essentially tropical fruits, have not much of a tradition in Europe; thus, their name is often formed from the name of lemon by adding an adjective reflecting some typical property of lime: Yiddish grine limene [×’×¨×™× ×¢ ×œ×™××¢× ×¢] and Romanian lÄƒmÃ¢ie verde green lemon, Spanish limÃ³n agria sour lemon, Turkish tatlÄ± limon sweet lemon, and Romanian lÄƒmÃ¢i mexican Mexican lemon. I am unable to explain the motivation behind the Turkish name.  In India, the tropical climate favours lime as the sour citrus fruit over lemon, a much less known fruit. Yet, in the Himalaya, both lemon and lime may grown side by side. The two fruits are both called nimbu in Hindi; if desired, a distinction can be made between bara nimbu [à¤¬à¥œà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚] big nimbu (lemon) and chota nimbu [à¤›à¥‹à¤Ÿà¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚à¤¬à¥‚] small nimbu (lime). I have also seen lime being referred to as lebu [à¤²à¥‡à¤¬à¥], a name probably not valid outside of the mountain dialect (Pahari) of Hindi.          Ripening limes           Ripening lime   TheÂ English name lime must  not be conÂ­fused with its homoÂ­nym meaning calcium oxide (a building material  produced from limeÂ­stone, calcium carbonate), which is related to loam  or slime and derives from an Proto-Indoâ€“European root (S)LEI with general meaning  smear, glue (cf. German Lehm clay). Lime stone is not often used for culinary purposes, Mexican masa harina (tortilla flour) and South-East Asian betel bits being the only appliÂ­cations I know of.  ByÂ chance, English lime (or linden) has yet another meaning, referÂ­ring to the trees of genus Tilia (Malvaceae). Cf. for example the half-line lind wiÃ° lige the linden (=the wooden shield) against the fire (of the dragon) in the Beowulf poem.  That name linden has coÂ­gnates in Germanic, Baltic and SlaÂ­vonic tongues, e.â€‰g., LithuaÂ­nian liepa, Norwegian lind, Czech lÃ­pa and Russian lipa [Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¿Ğ°]. It is probably derived from an Proto-Indoâ€“EuroÂ­pean root LENT flexible, referring to the soft wood of linden trees often used for wood-carving. Cf. also Latin lentus flexible, slow, Polish lÄ™t whip, Sanskrit lata [à¤²à¤¤à¤¾] creeping plant and Old Norse linni snake, German Lindwurm dragon. used-plant-part: The leaves, which have a characÂ­terÂ­istic shape due to their winged petioles, which almost look like leaves themÂ­selves; if availÂ­able, the fruits, especially the fruit skin, may also be used.
plant-family: Rutaceae (citrus family). Within the genus Citrus, kaffir lime belongs to subgenus Papeda and is, therefore, less closely related to those species yielding the popular citrus fruits.
sensory-quality: Strongly lemon-like. Although many people judge the fragrance crude, dominating  and penetrating on first contact, most will find it uniquely refreshing after having grown accustomed to it, especially if blended with other flavours.
main-constituents: The compound responsible for the characteristic aroma was identified as (â€“)-(S)-citronellal, which is contained in the leaf oil up to 80%; minor components are citronellol (10%), nerol and limonene.          Kaffir lime fruits   FormÂ aÂ stereoÂ­chemical point of view, it is remarkable that kaffir lime leaves contain only (â€“)-(S)-citronellal, whereas the enantiomeric form (+)-(R)-citronellal is found in both lemon balm and (to a lesser degree) lemon grass, (note, however, that citronellal is only a trace component in the latterâ€™s essential oil).  Kaffir lime fruit peel contains an essential oil comparable to lime fruit peel oil; main components are limonene and Î²-pinene. Origin South East Asia.           Kaffir limes on a market  Etymology See also lemon and lime.  Frankly, I do not know why the kaffir lime is called so. The word kaffir, in English and many more EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages, is used as an ofÂ­fenÂ­sive term for Blacks in general; historiÂ­cally, it was partiÂ­cularly aÂ­pplied to the Xhosa, a people indiÂ­genous in South Africa, in a xenoÂ­phobic way. It comes from Arabic kafir [ÙƒØ§ÙØ±] infidel, non-Muslim, via obsolete Spanish and PortuÂ­guese cafre barbarian. The ultimate source is a Semitic root KPR village, with a deÂ­rogaÂ­tory conÂ­notaÂ­tion of backÂ­wardÂ­ness. ApÂ­parentÂ­ly, the meaning inÂ­fidel arose from an impliÂ­cation of reÂ­tarded or inÂ­complete IslamiÂ­zation in remote villages. Distantly related is Turkish gÃ¢vur infidel, which was entered English as an exotism giaour. Cf. also the German term Kaff (derogatory for remote place, small village), which might have Yiddish sources, although others derive it from Romany gÄw village.  The species name hystrix (Greek hystrix [á½•ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¹Î¾] porcupine) refers to the many thorns of the plant. used-plant-part: Seed tissue (endosperm), used fresh or dried.  The sour liquid inside the young seed (coconut water) is a common refresher in tropical countries; it must not be confused with coconut milk (see below). Coconut water is rarely used for cooking.           Drinking coconuts           Shelled and split coconuts
sensory-quality: The endoÂ­sperm has a pleasant, mild and nutty fragrance and a typical taste, with a hint of sweetÂ­ness.
main-conÂ­stituents: Khopra (desiccated coconut) contains about 60 to 70% coconut oil. Coconut oil is composed, as might be inferred by its high melting point of over 32Â Â°C, mostly of triglycerides of saturated fatty acids. Lauric (dodecanoic acid;  40 to 55%) and myristic acid (tetradecanoic acid; 15 to 20%) dominate, but several other fatty acids are found at concentrations of 5 to 10%: The two short-chain acids caprylic (octanoic) and capric (decanoic) acid (which are responsible for the smell of overaged coconut oil), the long-chain palmitic acid (hexadecanoic acid) and oleic acid, which is the only unsaturated fatty acid found at significant amounts. Consequently, the iodine index is very low (typically, below 10). See also sesame on the topic of plant oils.           Coconut palm           Coconuts are sometimes sold with the hard shell removed   TheÂ typical coconut flavour is caused by several Î´-lactones of aliphatic hydroxy-carboxylic acids, ranging in chain length from 8 to 14; 5-decanÂ­olide (5-pentylÂ­oxan-2-one) is the most important single compound. Synthetic coconut flavourings often contain a homologous Î³-lactone, 4-nonanÂ­olide (pentylÂ­oxolan-2-one), which is not found in coconuts. Toasting coconuts leads to pyrolysis of maltose and glucose, whereby  new fragrant compounds are formed: maltol (2-hydroxy 3-methyl Î³-pyrone) and cyclotene (cyclopentenolone, 2-hydroxy 3-methyl 2-cyclopenten-1-one), respectively. Furthermore, a great number of alkylpyrazines were identified (pyrazine, methyl pyrazin, dimethyl pyrazines, vinyl pyrazin, isopropyl pyrazin).          Coconuts are sometimes sold with the hard shell removed  Origin The coconut tree stems from the Southeast Asian peninsular (probably Malaysia), but is cultivated in tropical regions all around the world. Older books often speculate about a Polynesian or even American origin of coconut, but recent developments have shown this view almost certainly wrong. In all probability, the coconut tree was first cultivated by peoples of India or Southeast Asia; emigrants from these countries then introduced the coconut tree to almost everywhere in the tropics of Asia and Oceania. There is no proof of coconuts having grown in America before the arrival of the Spaniards; this is curious, however, since the closest relatives of the coconut palm are of American distribution.           Coconuts           On germination, the young coconut plant breaks through one of the three marks  Etymology Coconut and its reÂ­latives in other EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages goes back to Spanish coco spectre, goblin, with refÂ­erÂ­ence to the three marks on each  cocoÂ­nut which make it look like an eerie face.  TheÂ botanical species name nucifera is a neo-Latin formation meaning  bearing nuts (nux nut and ferre bring, carry, bear).  AlmostÂ all names of coconut in Indic languages are related, e.â€‰g., Hindi nariyal [à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤²], Urdu nariyel  [Ù†Ø§Ø±ÛŒÙ„], Punjabi narial [à¨¨à¨¾à¨°à©€à¨…à¨²], Gujarati nariyel [àª¨àª¾àª°àª¿àª¯à«‡àª³], Marathi naral [à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤³], Bengali narokel [à¦¨à¦¾à¦°à¦•à§‡à¦²] and Telugu narikelamu [à°¨à°¾à°°à°¿à°•à±‡à°³à°®à±]; cf. also Mongolian nargil [Ğ½Ğ°Ñ€Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ»]. These and other names go back to Sanskrit narikela [à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥‡à¤²], whose origin, however, is not Indoâ€“European. The first element resembles several AustroÂ­nesian names of coconut, e.â€‰g., Tagalog niyog, Malaysian nyiur and Hawaiian niu. In Tamil, the related word ney [à®¨à¯†à®¯à¯] has the generalized meaning semi-solid fat, paralleling similar constructions for other oilseeds (olive, sesame).  FarsiÂ hasÂ a related name for coconut, nargil [Ù†Ø§Ø±Ú¯ÛŒÙ„], which lies behind the Persian term nargileh [Ù†Ø§Ø±Ú¯ÛŒÙ„Ù‡] for water pipe, since coconut shells can be used as pipe bowl. The word entered many languages as an exotism for oriental tobacco pipes.  Some names of coconut, e.â€‰g. Maltese Ä¡ewÅ¼a taâ€™ l-Indja and Armenian hentgagan engouz [Õ€Õ¨Õ¶Õ¤Õ¯Õ¡Õ¯Õ¡Õ¶ Ô¸Õ¶Õ¯Õ¸ÕµÕ¦], literally mean Indian nut; note that some languages use similar designations for nutmeg, although both plants actually do not originate from India. note: These three plants, only two of which are botanically related, have been combined into one document for their almost equal culinary merits. The term cress will henceforth be used for all three plants described in this document.  Despite its name, paracress (para cress) is a herb wholly apart, and not related botanically nor culinarily to any of the cresses.

used-plant-part: Fresh leaves. Unripe nasturtium fruits can be pickled and used as a substitute for capers.             Garden cress (left: leaves, flower and unripe fruits), water cress (middle: upper and lower side) and nasturtium (right: upper side)            Flower of garden cress
plant-family: Water and garden cress belong to  Brassicaceae (cabbage family); nasturtium belongs to TropaeoÂ­laceae,  a botanically not related family of  its own.
sensory-quality: Cress and its relatives display a spicy aroma and a refreshing, peppery-pungent taste lasting only a few seconds.
main-constituents: Similar to many other members of the cabbage family (black and white mustard, horseradish, wasabi, rocket), all cresses owe their aroma to isothiocyanates. The isothiocyanates are formed from inactive precursors called glucosinolates as a reaction to injuries.           Garden cress flowers           Garden cress flowering top   WaterÂ andÂ garÂ­den cress contain glucoÂ­nasturtiin, which yields the 2-phenylÂ­ethyl isoÂ­thiocyanate (C6H5â€“CH2â€“CH2â€“NCS). In contrast, the pungency of nasturtium leaves comes from benzyl isoÂ­thiocynate, (C6H5â€“CH2â€“NCS), which is created from glucoÂ­tropaeolin (benzyl glucosÂ­inolate); yet in nasturtium seeds, another glucosinolate was found (glucoÂ­putranjivin), which yields isopropyl isothiocyanate on enzymatic hydrolysis. Benzyl isothiocyanate is  closely related to the pungent principle of white mustard, but much more volatile and, thus, less persistent.  Since all these isothiocyantes are volatile and much susceptible to heat and moisture,  cress aroma is most delicate; thus, cress leaves are always used fresh, never  dried,  and should not be boiled, baked or otherwise heated.           Garden cress: Flowering stalk with unripe fruits in the lower half           Garden cress flowering top             Garden cress in Nepal            Garden cress
origin: Garden cress probably stems from WestÂ­ern or CenÂ­tral Asia, where it is still found in the wild state. It is easy to cultiÂ­vate and tolÂ­erÂ­ates nearly every climate.  TheÂ cosmoÂ­politan water cress  is similar in taste and can, thus, be subÂ­stituted by ordinary garden cress; its aroma, howÂ­ever, is someÂ­times deÂ­scribed suÂ­peÂ­rior to other cress species. Although water cress was one of the herbs which CharleÂ­magne orÂ­dered to be grown in ImÂ­perial gardens (see lovage), it is not grown comÂ­merÂ­cialÂ­ly in our days. It might be available on markets, either from small-scale backÂ­yard cultiÂ­vation of from collections in the wild.  Nasturtium stems from Southern America, probably PerÃº, and was introduced to Europe by Spanish conquistadores. It is a common ornamental, but less used for cooking.
etymology: The Greeks knew a plant with pungent leaves which was of Persian origin; also the Greek name of that plant, kardamon [Îºá½±ÏÎ´Î±Î¼Î¿Î½], was a loan from the conÂ­tempoÂ­rary lanÂ­guage of Persia. Though the exact botanÂ­ical reÂ­lations are unÂ­clear, that word has surÂ­vived, in the form of karÂ­damo [ÎºÎ¬ÏÂ­Î´Î±Î¼Î¿], as the New Greek name of garden cress (yet carÂ­damom has the same name!). Cf. also the botanÂ­ical name of the related genus CarÂ­damine (bitter cress), which conÂ­tains the Cuckoo Flower or Ladyâ€™s Smock, CarÂ­damine pratense.            Garden cress in Nepal            Garden cress    EnglishÂ cressÂ (from Old English cÃ¦rse) is not related to that. Instead, it is usually put into relation with the otherÂ­wise isoÂ­lated Latvian griezÄ«gs sharp; another theory derives it from the Proto-Indoâ€“European root GRAS devour whence also  Old Norse kras delicacy, Sanskrit grasati [à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿] he eats, Greek gran [Î³Ïá¾¶Î½] gnaw. See also the etymoÂ­logy of grass  (lemon grass).  Comparatively few lanÂ­guÂ­ages take the obÂ­vious choice to name cress as pepper-grass or pepper-herb, e.â€‰g., YidÂ­dish feferÂ­gros [×¤Ö¿×¢×¤Ö¿×¢×¨×’×¨×Ö¸×¡], HunÂ­garian borsÂ­fÅ± and Japanese koshÅ-sÅ [èƒ¡æ¤’è‰, ã“ã—ã‚‡ã†ãã†, ã‚³ã‚·ãƒ§ã‚¦ã‚½ã‚¦]. Only the third one is really a standard name, the former two are more regional variants. Possibly, also Georgian câ€™icâ€™matâ€™i [áƒ¬áƒ˜áƒ¬áƒ›áƒáƒ¢áƒ˜] has a similar backÂ­ground (câ€™icâ€™akâ€™a [áƒ¬áƒ˜áƒ¬áƒáƒ™áƒ] chile). Note that some languages have a name of pepper-herb type that refers to savory; in HunÂ­garian, borsfÅ±  may actuÂ­ally deÂ­note both plants.           Water cress           Water cress plant (Nasturtium officinale) Â© Birgit Wende   TheÂ classical Latin name nasÂ­turtium (used by the Romans for several cress-like plants, mostly garden cress) probably derives from nasi-tortium nose pain (from nasus nose and the verb torquere torment) and refers to the sharp, pungent aroma. The term Nasturtium has become the botaniÂ­cal genus name for water cress; yet, in English, it is commonÂ­ly used for Tropaeolum, a plant of new-world origin that was obÂ­viousÂ­ly unÂ­known to the RoÂ­mans. Clearly, this is a source of confusion.  WaterÂ cress bears, in most lanÂ­guages, an attribute meaning water (IndoÂ­nesian air, Finnish vesi, German Wasser, Italian acqua, Russian voda [Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ°], Greek nero [Î½ÎµÏÏŒ]) or well; fountain (German Brunnen, French fontaine), referring to its frequent growth in silent water.  About the etymology of water, see water pepper.           Nasturtium flowers (Tropaeolum majus) www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de   SomeÂ namesÂ of nasÂ­turtium relate to its origin from Latin America, e.â€‰g., French cresson dâ€™Inde or Swedish indianÂ­krasse (AmeriÂ­can) InÂ­dian cress. These names, however, should not be confused with designations like Brazil cress which refer to a culinarily distinct plant commonly known as paracress.          Water cress plant (Nasturtium officinale) Â© Birgit Wende   OtherÂ names of nasturtium refer to its import by members of Catholic Christian orders, e.â€‰g., Turkish  lÃ¢tin Ã§iÃ§eÄŸi Latin flower Bulgarian latinka [Ğ»Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½Â­ĞºĞ°] and Kurdish ladan [Ù„Ø§Ø¯Ø©Ù†]; in these names, Latin hints not at the language but alludes to Rome as the center of the Roman Catholic Church. Names like German KapuzinerÂ­kresse, French capucine, Dutch capucienerÂ­kers, Italian cappuccina, Arabic nabat al-kabbusin [Ù†Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø§Ù„ÙƒØ¨ÙˆØ³ÙŠÙ†] and Russian kaputsin-kress [ĞºĞ°Ğ¿ÑƒÑ†Ğ¸Ğ½-ĞºÑ€ĞµÑÑ] are motivated by the same association with Catholic monks, and in addition by the similar shapes of nasturtium flowers and the cowl of Capuchin monks. The name of the Capuchin order derive from  Italian cappuccio hood; especially a monkâ€™s cowl, related to English cap. The same motive is found in Hebrew kova ha-nazir [×›×•×‘×¢ ×”× ×–×™×¨] monk's cap and gargir ha-nazir ×’×¨×’×™×¨ ×”× ×–×™×¨ monk cresss.           Nasturtium flowers (Tropaeolum majus) www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de   TheÂ botanical genus name of nasÂ­turtium, TropÂ­aeolum, was coined from Greek tropaion [Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î±Î¹Î¿Î½ or Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€Î±á¿–Î¿Î½] trophy, by which the anÂ­cients meant parts of the deÂ­feated enemyâ€™s armour pubÂ­licÂ­ly disÂ­played as a sign of vicÂ­tory. The reÂ­ference is both to the shield-formed leaves and the flowers which resemble a helmet if viewed from the side. Tropaion itself derives from trope [Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï€á½µ] change, turning (also the turning point when a fight is lost) and is thus related to many English words like tropic (the parallels of latitude where the sun turns from the zenith) or catastrophe (the moment when fate turns to evil). The Proto-Indoâ€“European root behind that word is TREP turn.  English speakers, beware: Since Nasturtium is  the botanical name of water cress and not of the plant commonly called nasturtium, there is much room for confusion. Especially, gluconasturtiin does not occur in nasturtium! note: The wild thyme found in England is mostly not Th. serpyllum,  but the related species Th. drucei (common wild thyme).           Thyme sprigs           Thyme flower
another-note: In the countries of the Eastern MediÂ­terranean, there is often nor clear distinction made between a couple of aromatic herbs of the mint family: Names like Turkish kekik or Arabic zatar/satar [Ø²Ø¹ØªØ±, ØµØ¹ØªØ±] and related forms in Hebrew and Persian,  often in conjunction with qualifying or descriptive adjectives, may be applied to a varity of native herbs including, but not restricted to, oregano, marjoram, thyme and savory. Usage may vary even within a given language, depending on the region and particularly on the local flora. In Jordan, zahtar usually means a spice mixture containing such herbs (see sumac for more).
used-plant-part: Leaves. Frequently, the whole herb (leaves plus stem) is sold.           Lemon thyme sprigs, variegated variety           Lemon thyme
sensory-quality: Strongly aromatic.
main-constituents: The content of essential oil varies drastically with climate, time of harvest and storage conditions; extreme values are 0.75% and 6.5%. Main components are the phenols thymol (ca. 40%) and carvacrol (ca. 15%). In winter, phenol content is lower (but mostly thymol); in summer, more phenols (up to 70%) are found, with significant amounts of carvacrol. Further components in the essential oil are thymol methyl ether (2%), cineol, cymene, Î±-pinene, borneol and esters of the latter two.  Lemon thyme, Thymus x citriodorus, was found to contain an essential oil rich in geraniol (up to 60%); other compounds identified include geranyl esters, nerol and citronellol.  The lemon fragrance is due to citral (14%), and thymol was found in small (0.5%) yet not insignificant amounts. (Flavour Fragrance Journal, 10,  225, 1995)  The main components in Th. serpyllum (grown in Uttarakhand, Northern India) were found to be thymol and its methyl ether. (National Academy Science Letters, 35, 445, 2012) There is also a Thymus species native to that area (Th. linearis), whose essential contains thymol (60%), p-cymene (10%) and Î³-terpinene (6%), with large variation in percentages. (Natural Product Research, 24, 1890, 2010)
origin: Southern Europe. The herb is much cultivated in Eastern and Southern Europe and Northern Africa, but also in the US.           Mastic thyme, also known as Spanish wild marjoram (Th.  mastichina)           Orange thyme in full flower   OfÂ theÂ many further species of the genus Thymus, only Th. zygis (Spanish Thyme) is an accepted substitute. Its essential oil is low in thymol methyl ether (less than 0.5%), which is important for the characterization. The other species (Th. satureoides, Th. mastichina, Th. broussonetti, Th. maroccanus, Th. pallidus and Th. algeriensis) are considered inferior, because of their lower content of thymol and because some of them contain other aroma components, especially carvacrol (see savory). Th. serpyllum  (continental wild thyme, a mountain plant of temperate Europe) has only local  value as spice; its flowers are used to prepare a syrup with strong thyme fragrance. Most unusually, Th. herbaâ€“barona almost perfectly copies the scent of caraway.  Another cultivar sometimes found in markets is orange thyme (Th. vulgaris var. odoratissimus) with strong thyme fragrance and a hint of orange peel aroma.  Lastly, lemon thyme (Th. citriodorus = Th. pulegoides Ã— Th. vulgaris) exhibits an unusual flavour, combining thyme aroma with the fragrance of lemons,  but is little traded; it is best when fresh. Lemon thyme fits perfect to fish and fruity vegetables; see lemon myrtle about lemon fragrance.
etymology: The name thyme is borrowed from Latin thymus, which goes back to Greek thymon [Î¸á½»Î¼Î¿Î½] thyme. The Greek plant name is usually put in relation with thymos [Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚] spirit, originally meaning smoke (related to Latin fumus smoke; cf. perfume) and the verb thyein [Î¸á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½] smoke, cure; offer an incense sacrifice. The reference is probably the strong, smoky odour of thyme. Yet there is also another, unrelated explanation that the Greek name actually comes from Old Egyptian tham, which denoted a plant used in the mummification process.           Th. willdenowii from North Africa           Continental wild thyme, Th. serpyllum   MostÂ EuroÂ­pean languages have related names all deriving from Latin thymus. Examples are German Thymian, Italian timo, Finnish timjami, Estonian tÃ¼Ã¼mian, Dutch tijm, Russian timyan [Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼ÑŒÑĞ½], Greek thimari [Î¸Ï…Î¼Î¬ÏÎ¹] and Hebrew timin [×ª×™××™×Ÿ].  In some Balto-Slavic tongues, however, one can find a group of unrelated names that reminds of local designations for savory: Romanian cimbru, Lithuanian Äiobreliai and Russian chabrets [Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ±Ñ€ĞµÑ†]. Another group of names in Slavonic languages, exemplified by Czech mateÅ™Ã­douÅ¡ka and Bulgarian mashterka [Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ‰ĞµÑ€ĞºĞ°], appears to derive from a local term for mother, but I do not know the details.  On the German name of creeping thyme, Quendel, see savory. English creeping thyme and Swedish kryptimian both refer to the shrubâ€™s creeping shape. A similar association lies behind French serpolet, Italian serpillo, Basque txerpol and others: These derive via Latin serpullum from the Greek plant name herpyllos [á¼•ÏÏ€Ï…Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚] which in turn is related to Greek herpein [á¼•ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½] and Latin serpere creep (cf. serpent, literally the creeping one). The botanical species name serpyllum is a compromise between both the Greek and Latin forms. Yiddish feldkiml [×¤Ö¿×¢×œ×“×§×™××œ] field caraway appears motivated by the scent reminding to caraway.

used-plant-part: Seed, also called a bean.
sensory-quality: Sweet and hay-like, very strong. For other sweet spices, see licorice.
main-conÂ­stituents: To liberate the coumarin, the beans are proÂ­cessed by soaking in alcohol (rum) for 24 hours and drying, whereby a ferÂ­mentation process takes place. AfterÂ­wards, the coumarin content may be as high as 10%. Coumarin crystals are visible below the epidermis of the seed.  Coumarin glycosides occur in several plants; on wilting or drying, coumarin is liberated. For example, coumarin contributes to the pleasant smell of fresh dried hay. Woodruff (Asperula odorata) has high coumarin content and  is sometimes used to flavour alcoholic drinks in Western Europe and the US. It has come out of use, though.  Coumarin is toxic and causes serious though reversible liver damage in high dosages or if applied regularly over some time; toxic doses range around one gram, but some individuals are more suceptible. In rodents, coumarin has proven a carcinogen, yet this result does probably not hold for humans. It should be noted that some condensed coumarin derivatives act as strong antagonists to vitamin K and thus prevent blood coagulation; these compounds are used as rodenticides and as medicinal anticoagulants. Simple coumarin does not show this effect (but some molds can metabolize it to vitamin K blockers, which is why moldy hay may cause fatal poisoning in cattle). See also cassia for coumarin limits in German food laws.           Tonka tree with unripe fruits www.da-academy.org           Tonka leaves www.da-academy.org
origin: Northern South America (Guyana, Orinoco region). Main proÂ­ducers today are VeneÂ­zuela  and also Nigeria.
etymology: The word tonka is taken from the Galibi (Carib) tongue spoken by natives of French Guayana; it also appears in Tupi, another language of the same region, as the name of the tree. The old genus name, Coumarouna,  was formed from another Tupi name of the tonka tree, kumarÃº.  The latter also lies behind the name of  tonkaâ€™s main constituent,  coumarin.  The modern genus name is Greek (dis-  prefix double- from dyo [Î´á½»Î¿] two; pteryx [Ï€Ï„á½³ÏÏ…Î¾] wing) and refers to the special two-winged  shape of the fruits. The species name is a Latin participle (from odor scent) and means scented.

used-plant-part: Stigma, also called style (central part of a flower, female sexual organ). Approximately 150000 flowers are needed for one kilogram of dried saffron; typically, one would need 2000â€‰m2 field area per kg harvest. Less expensive qualities include also the yellow stamina (male sexual organ), which do not have any taste of their own.           Flowering saffron plant           Saffron growing in the Swiss mountains www.zunft-zu-safran.ch
sensory-quality: Very intensively fragrant (remiÂ­niscent of iodoform, but much more pleasant), slightly bitter in taste. By soaking saffron in warm water, one gets a bright yellowâ€“orange solution.
main-conÂ­stituents: The intensive colour of saffron is caused by pigments of carotÂ­enoid type. Although saffron contains some conÂ­ventional carotÂ­enoids (Î±- and Î²-carotene, lycopin and zeaÂ­xanthin), its staining capability is mostly caused by crocetine esters; crocetin is a dicarboxylic acid with a carotenoid-like C18 backbone which is formed from carotenoid precursors (diterpene carotenoid). Crocin, a diester of crocin with gentobiose, is the single most important saffron pigment.  In the essential oil (max. 1%), several terpene aldehydes and ketones are found.  The most abundant constituent is safranal, 2,6,6-trimethyl 1,3-cycloÂ­hexadiene-1-carbaldehyde  (50% and more); another olfactorily important compound is 2-hydroxy 4,4,6-trimethyl 2,5-cycloÂ­hexadien-1-one. FurtherÂ­more, terpene derivatives have been identified (pinene, cineol).  The bitter taste is attributed to picrocrocin, the glucoside of an alcohol structurally related to safranal (4-hydroxy 2,4,4-trimethyl 1-cyclohexene-1-carboxaldehyde ). On de-glucosylation, picrocrocin yields safranal.             Saffron flower with yellow stamina and red stigmata            Saffron threads after harvest Â© Therese Witzke    SafranalÂ and its relatives, most typically C9 or C10 isoprenoids with a cyclohexane ring, are formed from carotenoid pigments as the result of enzymatic degradation (see also pandanus leaves). Origin Saffron is the triploid form of a species found in Eastern Greece, Crocus cartwrightianus; it probably appeared first in Crete. An origin in Western or Central Asia, although often suspected, has been disproved by botanical research. (Plant. Syst. Evol., 128, 89, 1977)  Because of being triploid, saffron is necessarily sterile, and its beautiful flowers cannot produce any seeds; propagation is possible only via corms. Distribution over larger distance requires human help, and so itâ€™s surprising that saffron was known to the Sumerians almost 5000 years ago. It is not known, however, how the spice was transported from the MediÂ­terranean to Sumer in MesoÂ­potamia.  Today,Â saffron is cultivated from the Western Mediterranean (Spain) to India (Kashmir). Spain and Iran are the largest producers, accounting together for more than 80% of the worldâ€™s production, which is approximately 300 tons per year.  In Europe, saffron production is almost limited to the Mediterranean; Spanish (La Mancha) saffron is generally considered the best. In much smaller scale, saffron is also cultivated in Italy and Greece (Crete).             Dried saffron in bulk quantity            Saffron flowers in Kashmir            Flowers on a saffron field (India)   SaffronÂ does, however, quite well in cooler climates, and since the 15.th century, numerous attempts have been made to introduce saffron production to German, Switzerland, Austria and even England. For example, the town of Saffron Walden (Essex/England) got its name from local saffron production in the 16.th century. However, by the end of the 18.th century, most of the former saffron cultivation sites had become abandoned, and in our days, the only remaining saffron industry in Europe north of the Mediterranean is found in Mund, a small Swiss village in canton Wallis. In Mund, a few kilograms of saffron per year are produced in traditional way, at an elevation of about 1200â€‰m.   OfÂ theÂ Western and Central Asian cultivation areas, Iran is most productive. In recent years, yield has been enormously increased and Iran now produces more saffron than Spain. Smaller amounts are harvested in Turkey and India.  Of all the Indian provenances, Kashmiri saffron has a particularly high reputation, but is hardly available outside India; furthermore, yields and quality have decreased because of the unfortunate political situation persisting since decades. Production is confined to a small area around the village Pampore [Ù¾Ø§Ù†Ù¾ÙˆØ±Û], just a few kilometers from the summer state capital Srinagar. The fields are divided into sections one or two square meters large and are kept free from vegetation all year round. Flowers show up for a about two weeks in the end of October or the beginning of November. They are picked from the plants (to stimulate more flower formation) and separated into styles are waste afterwards. Including the final drying of the styles, all the work is done by families that use little or no modern technology. EtymologyÂ  The name saffron comes from Arabic, where the spice is known as az-za'fran [Ø§Ù„Ø²Ø¹ÙØ±Ø§Ù†]; that name is often explained to derive from a Semitic root á¹¢PR signifying be yellow or become yellow (see also safflower). This is an ancient name, as demonstrated by its Akkadian incarnation azupÄ«ru; yet it has no Hebrew cognate (see below on the Hebrew name). The Sumerian form azugna [ğ’Œ‘ğ’„¯ğ’Š•] denotes a plant that has not clearly identified, possibly saffron.             Saffron corms Â© Laura Pazzaglia in Simmarano            Saffron field (Pampore near Srinagar, Kashmir)            Saffron corm, just unearthed   DirectlyÂ orÂ via medieaval Latin safranum, the word spread from the Iberic peninsular (then under Mauric rule) to practically all European languages and even some non-European ones, e.â€‰g. (to name a few geographical extremes) Portuguese aÃ§afrÃ£o, Italian zafferano, Greek zafora [Î¶Î±Ï†Î¿ÏÎ¬], Georgian zaprana [áƒ–áƒáƒ¤áƒ áƒáƒœáƒ], Russian shafran [ÑˆĞ°Ñ„Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½] and Finnish sahrami. Similar names are also found in non-European languages, e.â€‰g., Amharic safron [áˆ°ááˆ®áŠ•], Kazakh zaÄŸÄ±paran [Ğ·Ğ°Ò“Ñ‹Ğ¿Ğ°Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½], Hindi zafran [à¥›à¤¾à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¨], Thai yafaran [à¸«à¸à¹‰à¸²à¸à¸£à¸±à¹ˆà¸™] and Japanese safuran [ã•ãµã‚‰ã‚“, ã‚µãƒ•ãƒ©ãƒ³].  TheÂ SanskritÂ names of saffron point to the ancient Indian area of saffron production: Kashmirajanman [à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤®à¥€à¤°à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥] product of Kashmir and kashmira [à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤®à¥€à¤°] the one from Kashmir; the second name, however, can also be used for other Kashmiri products, e.â€‰g., costus (putchuk), Saussurea lappa, Asteraceae. Such names are rare in todayâ€™s Indian languages, an example is Malayalam kashmiram [à´•à´¾à´¶àµà´®àµ€à´°à´‚].  SeveralÂ superÂ­ficially similar Indic names of saffron (Sanskrit kesaravara [à¤•à¥‡à¤¸à¤°à¤µà¤°], Hindi kesar [à¤•à¥‡à¤¸à¤°], Punjabi keshar [à¨•à©‡à¨¶à¨°], Urdu kisar [Ú©ÛŒØ³Ø±]) are, however, not related but derive from Sanskrit kesara [à¤•à¥‡à¤¸à¤°] hair, eye-brow, which refers to the thin, almost hairlike saffron threads. Yet note that the analogous Tibetan name gaser [à½¦à¾’à¼‹à½¦à½ºà½¢] means turmeric.  The earliest Greek name of saffron is found in LinearÂ B tablets: knakos [ğ€ğ€™ğ€’, also written logographically as ğ‚”], which in the classical era became knekos [ÎºÎ½á¿†ÎºÎ¿Ï‚] or knikion [ÎºÎ½á½·ÎºÎ¹Î¿Î½] and was used to denote other orange-flowering plants, e.â€‰g., safflower (see there for its affiliation). In India, Sanskrit kunkuma [à¤•à¥à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤®] and Kashmiri kung [Ú©ÙˆÙ†Ú¯] probably belong to the same kin. That name even spread to Burma, where the plant is known by the (suspected) Indian loanword kunkum [á€€á€¯á€¶á€€á€¯á€™á€¶].  The knakos-type names fell into disuse after the collapse of the Mycenean civilization; from Homerâ€™s time one, saffron was invariably called krokos [ÎºÏá½¹ÎºÎ¿Ï‚] in Greek language.  In the Iliad, Homer used that word as a metaphor for the golden colour of dawn (see also poppy). The origin of that name is not known, but is is usually assumed pre-Greek and not Indoâ€“European.  Except in Modern Greek, this name has not survived to any contemporary language, but cf. also Old English crog saffron. In its Latin form Crocus, the name appears as the botanical genus name of saffron.  The etymology of krokos is not known with certainty, but maybe there is a connection to Old Hebrew language.           Group of saffron plants   TheÂ OldÂ Hebrew name for saffron is karkom [×›×¨×›×] and appears frequently in the Old Testament (see pomeÂ­granate). In Modern Hebrew, karkom was abandoned in favour of safran [×–×¢×¤×¨×Ÿ] which is directly derived from Arabic za'fran [Ø²Ø¹ÙØ±Ø§Ù†].  The Arabic cognate of Hebrew karkom [×›×¨×›×] is kurkum [ÙƒØ±ÙƒÙ…], originally also with the meaning saffron. This is probably not a Semitic word, as is has close relatives in unrelated languages, e.â€‰g., Middle Persian kurkum and Sanskrit kunkuma [à¤•à¥à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤®]. Arabic kurkum is no longer used for saffron, but denotes another yellow spice, turmeric. Many languages, particularly European ones, have names for turmeric that relate to the Arabic, e.â€‰g., curcuma (English is a rare exception here). Of the whole kin of karkom and kurkum, only Armenian kerkoom [Ö„Õ¨Ö€Ö„Õ¸Ö‚Õ´] is still alive with the meaning saffron. In Modern Hebrew, karkom was abandoned in favour of safran [×–×¢×¤×¨×Ÿ] which is directly derived from Arabic za'fran [Ø²Ø¹ÙØ±Ø§Ù†].  The Arabic cognate of Hebrew karkom [×›×¨×›×] is kurkum [ÙƒØ±ÙƒÙ…], originally also with the meaning saffron. This is probably not a Semitic word, as is has close relatives in unrelated languages, e.â€‰g., Middle Persian kurkum and Sanskrit kunkuma [à¤•à¥à¤‚à¤•à¥à¤®]. Arabic kurkum is no longer used for saffron, but denotes another yellow spice, turmeric. Many languages, particularly European ones, have names for turmeric that relate to the Arabic, e.â€‰g., curcuma (English is a rare exception here). Of the whole kin of karkom and kurkum, only Armenian kerkoom [Ö„Õ¨Ö€Ö„Õ¸Ö‚Õ´] is still alive with the meaning saffron. note: The above list contains only names that either refer to pumpkin in general, or to oilseed pumpkin in special. The numerous names for other cultivars used as vegetables (marrow, squash, pattison, zucchino, courgette and many more) have not been included.
used-plant-part: Seeds, dried and toasted, and the oil extracted therefrom.
aroma: Toasted pumpkin seeds have an intense, spicyâ€“nutty fragrance. The flavour of pumpkin seeds oil is so strong that people often have to grow accustomed to it.
main-constituents: Pumpkin seeds contain sizable amounts of protein (35%) and approximately 50% fixed oil, whose fatty acid profile is dominated by unsaturated fatty acids, namely linoleic and oleic acid. There are many trace constituents like tocopherols (0.1%) and phytosterols (total 0.1 to 0.5%); of the latter group, many are specific for the family of even the species.  The dark green colour of pumpkin seed oil is caused by carotenoids (15â€‰ppm, mostly lutein) and even more by porphyrines (13â€‰ppm, mostly chlorophyllÂ b and pheophytinÂ a). Pumpkin seed oil stains have terminated the career of many garments, particularly shirts and ties; the stains, however, pale quickly (though not always completely) in direct sunlight. See also annatto about vegetable colourings.           Pumpkin field in Styria   The flavour of pumpkin seeds and pumpkin seed oil develops in a toasting procedure, which is applied to the seeds immediately before extracting the oil. In this process, a multitude of volatile, flavourful compounds forms via the Maillard reaction. There is little scientific research in that field, but it seems that the most important flavour contributions come from pyrazines, e.â€‰g., 2,6-dimethylpyrazine.
origin: Pumpkin, Cucurbita pepo, is native to Central America, especially MÃ©xico, where it has been cultivated for millennia.  After the Spaniards had discovered America, pumpkin was imported into Europe and Asia, where it was welcomed as a cheap and nutritional vegetable. Pumpkin seed oil is won from a particular mutant (Styrian oilseed pumpkin, Cucurbita pepo var. styriaca) with tender, non-woody, seed hulls, which is cultivated only in South-Eastern Austria and the adjacent areas of the neighbouring countries.  Pumpkin seed oil is produced in greater scale  only since the begin of the 20.th century.

note: Although cumin is amongst the most used spices, world-wide, it is nevertheless surprisingly difficult to take photos of the cumin plant: In the three years which I spent in India, I have seen only once a herb that could have been a cumin plant. It fits the description very well, apart from the somewhat too broad leaflets, and it has a strong fragrance reminiscent of p-cymene. All photos on this page (excepting the one obtained from Ben-Erik van Wyk) show this single plant, which grew on a roadside in Imphal. Unfortunately, at that time my camera lens suffered from deadjustment and needed repair. In case some of my readers know the cumin plant, I should be glad about feedback.          Cumin fruits (often called cumin seeds)  (perhaps)
used-plant-part: Fruits (frequently called seeds). Although the entire herb has a fresh and spice, very agreeable, scent, it is not used in any kitchen I know.
plant-family: Apiaceae (parsley family).           Cumin plants have a suberect habit (perhaps)           Cumin umbels have bracteoles at their base (perhaps)
sensory-qualÂ­ity: Strongly aromatic; the aroma is characÂ­teristic and gets easily modified by frying or dry toasting.
main-constituents: The fruits contain 2.5 to 4% essential oil. In the essential oil, cumin aldehyde (p-isopropyl-benzaldehyde, 25 to 35%), furtherÂ­more perilla aldehyde, cumin alcohol, Î±- and Î²-pinene (21%), dipentene, p-cymene and Î²-phellandrene were found.  In toasted cumin fruits, a large number of pyrazines has been identified as flavour compounds. Besides pyrazine and various alkyl derivatives (particularly, 2,5- and 2,6-dimethyl pyrazine), 2-alkoxy-3-alkylpyrazines seem to be the key compounds (2-ethoxy-3-isopropyl pyrazine, 2-methoxy-3-sec-butyl pyrazine, 2-methoxy-3-methyl pyrazine). Also a sulfur compound, 2-methylthio-3-isopropyl pyrazine, was found. All these Maillard-products are also formed when fenugreek or coriander are toasted. (Nahrung, 24, 645, 1980)
origin: Western Asia, where it is cultiÂ­vated since Biblical times (see pomeÂ­granate). Main proÂ­duction countries today are India, Iran, Indonesia, China and the South MediÂ­terranean.
etymology: English cumin comes from Latin cuminum, which was borrowed from Greek kyminon [Îºá½»Î¼Î¹Î½Î¿Î½] (Mycenaean Greek kuminon [ğ€“ğ€–ğ€œ]). The word's further origin may be Semitic: Aramaic  kamuna [ÜŸÜ¡Ü˜Ü¢Ü], Old Hebrew kammon [×›××Ÿ], Egyptian kamnini, Akkadian kamÃ»nu. Modern Semitic tongues often show similar forms: Arabic al-kamoun [Ø§Ù„ÙƒÙ…ÙˆÙ†], Hebrew kamon [×›××•×Ÿ] and Amharic kemun [áŠ¨áˆ™áŠ•]. The ultimate origin is maybe Sumerian gamun [ğ’‚µğ’µ, ğ’·ğ’Œ, ğ’Œ], transmitted via Akkadian kamÃ»nu. See also onion for Ancient Babylonian cooking.           Cumin inflorescences are compound umbels; the sub-umbels are borne by rays of different length. (perhaps)   Other names that belong to the same kin are common in many (predominantly European) languages, e.â€‰g., Portuguese cominho, Lithuanian kuminai, Basque komino, Greek kimino [ÎºÏÎ¼Î¹Î½Î¿], Armenian kimon [Ö„Õ«Õ´Õ¸Õ¶] and also Chinese ku-ming [æ¯èŒ—]. Note, however, that many languages have very similar names signifying not cumin but caraway. This  may lead to considerable confusion. For example, in Russian, cumin is kmin [ĞºĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½] and caraway is tmin [Ñ‚Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½]; but in Ukrainian, kmyn [ĞºĞ¼Ğ¸Ğ½] means caraway; moreover, in the related Bulgarian language, cumin is kimion [ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ¾Ğ½] and caraway is kim [ĞºĞ¸Ğ¼]!  Confusion between cumin and caraway has a particularly long record in German-speaking countries, where caraway is known as KÃ¼mmel.  The German name of cumin is derived from that of caraway, indicating that German cooks see cumin as an exotic variety of their well-known caraway: KreuzkÃ¼mmel cross-caraway, yet what motivates the cross element I cannot say.           Withering cumin plant  Photo: Ben-Erik van Wyk (Food Plants of the World, Briza Publications)   InÂ mostÂ counÂ­tries of Northern and Eastern Europe, cumin is of little importance as a traditional flavouring, and conÂ­sequently, is seen as an alien spice comparable to but distinct from the native spice caraway (foreign caraway). Often, the languages make poor distinction between the both, which may lead to troublesome confusion in cooking; more often, cumin is named as a foreign or oriental variety of caraway: Turkish caraway (Romanian chimion turcesc), Eastern caraway (Slovenian orientalske kumin) or even Egyptian caraway (Hungarian egyiptomi kÃ¶mÃ©ny). In countries where cumin is favoured over caraway, the same system often works in the opposite direction, and caraway is then named German cumin or similar.  In Italian cuisine, cumin has little use; yet cumin is named Roman caraway in many European languages (Russian rimskij tmin [Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ñ‚Ğ¼Ğ¸Ğ½], Finnish roomankumina, Czech Å™Ã­mskÃ½ kmÃ­n). These names refer to the fact that cumin became known in Northern Europe, like many other plants of more Southern origin, only as a result of Charlemagneâ€™s herb edicts (see lovage). So, cumin was viewed as a Mediterranean or Italian type of the native caraway.  In Sanskrit tongue, many late names of cumin appear related to a verbal root jri [à¤œà¥„] signifying cause decay, consume, e.â€‰g., jarana [à¤œà¤¾à¤°à¤£], jirana [à¤œà¤¿à¤°à¤£], jirna [à¤œà¥€à¤°à¥à¤£]. The root jri may also mean digest, which might be linked to the digestive properties of cumin.  Related words for cumin are today found in a vast area from the Caucasus to Central Asia to South East Asia: Georgian dzira [áƒ«áƒ˜áƒ áƒ], Azeri cirÉ™, Kazakh zere [Ğ·ĞµÑ€Ğµ], Farsi zireh [Ø²ÛŒØ±Ù‡], Urdu zirah [Ø²ÛŒØ±Û], Hindi jira  [à¤œà¥€à¤°à¤¾], Gujarati jiru [àªœà«€àª°à«], Punjabi jira [à¨œà©€à¨°à¨¾], Bengali jira [à¦œà¦¿à¦°à¦¾], Telugu jilakarra [à°œà±€à°²à°•à°°à±à°°], Tamil jiragam [à®šà¯€à®°à®•à®®à¯], Dhivehi dhiri [Ş‹Ş¨ŞƒŞ¨], Burmese ziya, Thai yeera [à¸¢à¸µà¹ˆà¸«à¸£à¹ˆà¸²] and even Chinese ziran [å­œç„¶] (which entered the language as an adaptation of Uighur zire).  Sanskrit sugandha [à¤¸à¥à¤—à¤‚à¤§] cumin, also used for a variety of other aromatics (marjoram, lime, zedoary, civet, lotus), literally means well-smelling, indicates that cumin was highly popular in ancient India.  Another, more frequent Sanskrit name of cumin is ajaji [à¤…à¤œà¤¾à¤œà¥€].  In Chinese herbal medicine, cumin is commonly referred to as xiao hui xiang [å°èŒ´é¦™] little fennel, which is rather the opposite of fennel being named as sweet cumin in several South and South East Asian tongues.  Note on pronunciation (for non-English speakers): cumin is more or less pronounced as come in, but stressed on the first syllable.

umbels
note: In large parts of Asia, fennel and anise given the same name (see below).          Dried fennel fruits (often called seeds)
used-plant-part: Fruits (usually mistermed seeds) . Other than most of their relatives, they retain a green colour after drying. As a rule of thumb, a bright green colour indicates a good quality.  In Italy, there is also small-scale usage of fennel pollen as an expensive and rather extravagant spice. Also known as Spice of the Angels, fennel pollen is also produced in California as a small-scale exotic crop.  The leaves and stalks of fennel can be eaten as a vegetable. Italian breeds with fleshy stem and leaves to be used as a vegetable are often referred to as Florence Fennel or Finocchio in English, but the name finocchio may mean any type of fennel in Italian.
plant-family: Apiaceae (parsley family).             Fennel plants with flowers            Fennel plants with flowers              Sterile fennel plant            Sterile bronze fennel plant
sensory-quality: Sweet and aromatic, similar to anise. For other sweet spices, see licorice.  Fennel pollen, also known as spice of the angels, has a subtle fennel flavour, lacking some of the sweetÂ­ness but with a distinct note of pine needles (though others might disagree with this asÂ­sociaÂ­tion of mine). The dried fruits of wild fennel (traded only in small scale) have a similar scent.
main-conÂ­stituents: The content of essential varies strongly (0.6 to 6%); fruits in the center of an umbel are generally greater, greener and stronger in fragrance. Time of harvest and climate are also important. The essential oil of the most important fennel variety (var. dulce) contains anethole (50 to 80%), limonene (5%), fenchone (5%), estragole (methyl chavicol), safrole, Î±-pinene (0.5%), camphene, Î²-pinene,  Î²-myrcene and p-cymene. In contrast, the unÂ­cultivated form (var. vulgare) contains often more essential oil, but since it is characÂ­terized by the bitter fenchone (12 to 22%), it is of little value.          Sterile fennel plant
origin: MediÂ­terraÂ­nean. The plantâ€™s popuÂ­larity spread northÂ­wards during the Middle Ages, when it was grown in monasÂ­teries (see lovage).
etymology: The genus name foeniculum (Latin for little hay) probably refers to  the aroma of fennel and is the source of the name of fennel in many conÂ­temporary EuroÂ­pean languages. Examples are German Fenchel, Italian finocchio, Portuguese funcho, Swedish fÃ¤nkÃ¥l, Dutch venkel, Finnish fenkoli and Russian fenkhel [Ñ„ĞµĞ½Ñ…ĞµĞ»ÑŒ]. There are, however, a couple of similar names referring to fenugreek in some European tongues that likewise derive from the same Latin word foenum hay.          Sterile bronze fennel plant   SomeÂ languages do not distinguish clearly between fennel and anise. For example, in Amharic, the name insilal [áŠ¥áŠ•áˆµáˆ‹áˆ] may stand for fennel, anise and even dill. In Hebrew tongue, the term shumar [×©×•××¨] fennel may also used for anise, although there is a separate name for the latter, anis [×× ×™×¡]. Moreover, dill has a very similar name: shamir [×©××™×¨]Â â€” to make things worse, ash-shamir [Ø§Ù„Ø´Ù…Ø±] is the name of fennel in Arabic!  Also in Romanian and Turkish languages, one finds identical or very similar terms for fennel and anise, which might fool a cook (or cookbook writer). Some European languages name fennel as a pharmaceutical variant of dill, e.â€‰g., Estonian apteegitill and Russian aptechnyi ukrop [Ğ°Ğ¿Ñ‚ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ ÑƒĞºÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¿] pharmacy-dill. On the other hand, a Yiddish name of fennel is italienisher koper [××™×˜×Ö·×œ×™×¢× ×™×©×¢×¨ ×§×Ö¸×¤Ö¼×¢×¨] Italian dill.           Young fennel shoots           Sterile fennel plant, reddishâ€“brown cultivar (Bronze fennel)   InÂ theÂ Hindi tongue, anise and fennel are often synÂ­onymously called saunf [à¤¸à¥Œà¤‚à¤«] although of the two spices, only fennel is common in Indian cuisine. To make a clear distinction between the both, fennel may also be called moti saunf [à¤®à¥‹à¤Ÿà¥€ à¤¸à¥Œà¤‚à¤«] thick fennel, because its fruits are somewhat larger. Similar relations between the names of these two spices are also found in some other Indian languages, but the Urdu tongue closely related to Hindi has distinct names for fennel (saunf [Ø³ÙˆÙ†Ù]) and anise (anisuan [Ø§Ù†ÛŒØ³ÙˆØ§Úº]).  Many other Indic names of fennel derive from a word for sweet, e.â€‰g., Oriya modhuri [à¬®à¬§à­à¬°à­€], Bengali mouri [à¦®à§Œà¦°à¦¿] and Sanskrit madhurika [à¤®à¤§à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾] See licorice and bearâ€™s garlic for details on the Proto-Indoâ€“European root MEDÊ°U sweet. In Sri Lanka, there is an apparently similar name maduru [à¶¸à·à¶¯à·–à¶»à·”], but I doubt whether it belongs to the same kin: There is an alternative Sinhala name maha-duru [à¶¸à·„à¶¯à·”à¶»à·”] large cumin, of which maduru could be a contracted form.  A curious outsider among the Indian names is Kashmiri badyan [Ø¨Ø§Ø¯ÛŒÙ†], which almost everywhere else stands for star anise.  The Indonesian name jintan manis sweet cumin (also applied to anise) reflects the much greater importance of cumin, of which fennel is thought to be a variety, in Indonesian cuisine. Analogous formations are French aneth doux or Russian sladkij ukrop [ÑĞ»Ğ°Ğ´ĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ ÑƒĞºÑ€Ğ¾Ğ¿] sweet dill and Hungarian Ã©deskÃ¶mÃ©ny sweet caraway. All these spices (anise, cumin, dill, caraway) belong to the same plant family (Apiaceae)  and, in varying degree, resemble each other in shape and fragrance. See also cicely.           Fennel umbels www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de   TheÂ Modern Greek name for fennel, maratho [Î¼Î¬ÏÎ±Î¸Î¿], can be traced back to Ancient Greek marathon [Î¼á½±ÏÎ±Î¸Î¿Î½] (the oldest recorded form is maraÂ­thuwon [ğ€”ğ€¨ğ€¶ğ€º] on the Linear B tablets); possibly, there is a connection to the Indic names mentioned in the previous paragraph.   Names derived thence are found in Coptic (malatron [â²™â²â²—â²â²§â²£â²Ÿâ²›]) and in a small cluster of South East European languages: Albanian maraja, Bulgarian morach [Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‡] and Romanian mÄƒrar; the latter, however, has changed its meaning to dill, again emphasizing the widespread confusion between those two plants.  Marathon [ÎœÎ±ÏÎ±Î¸á½½Î½] (Modern Marathonas [ÎœÎ±ÏÎ±Î¸ÏÎ½Î±Ï‚]) is also the name of a famous site in Attica, where the Greeks defeated the Persians in 490, thus laying the foundation for the later glory of the classical era. The placename is said to refer to the abundance of wild fennel growing there. The island capital of Madeira, Funchal, certainly got its name from the abundant fennel plants (Portuguese funcho).  Another group of related names can be spotted in the tongues of Western Asia: Turkish rezene (hence Bulgarian rezene [Ñ€ĞµĞ·ĞµĞ½Ğµ] and Macedonian razijan [Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¸Ñ˜Ğ°Ğ½]), Kurdish dhaziana [Ø°Ø§Ø²ÛŒØ§Ù†Ø©] and Farsi razianeh [Ø±Ø§Ø²ÛŒØ§Ù†Ù‡]. I do not know anything about the origin of these names.
