The direct progenitor of English nutmeg is Middle English notemugge.          Ripe nutmeg split open pharm1.pharmazie.uni-greifswald.de   The term musk refers to an aroma obtained, since antiquity, from the musk deer, a dog-sized animal native to the Himalayas. The name musk comes, via Latin muscus, from Greek moschos [Î¼á½¹ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Ï‚] which itself was borrowed from Persian musk (modern Farsi moshk [Ù…Ø´Ú©]). The origin is probably Sanskrit mushka [à¤®à¥à¤·à¥à¤•] testicle, as musk is produced only by the male musk deer, in special glands that were often compared with and even equated with testicles.          Nutmegs on a tree   InÂ theÂ same spirit as Latin nux muscatus, nutmeg is called al-jouz at-tib [Ø§Ù„Ø¬ÙˆØ²Ø© Ø§Ù„Ø·ÙŠØ¨] fragrant  nut in Arabic.  TheÂ Chinese name rou dou kou [è‚‰è±†è”»] consists of rou flesh, meat and dou kou  carÂ­damom. That name, puzzling at first, makes perfectly sense since nutmegs look quite similar (in colour, size and shape) to Chinese types of black carÂ­damom; yet while carÂ­damom pods contain separate seeds, nutmegs have a compact interior (endosperm), thus they are fleshy cardamoms           Unripe nutmeg fruit           Nutmegs on a tree           Ripe nutmeg split open pharm1.pharmazie.uni-greifswald.de   SomeÂ languÂ­ages name nutÂ­meg Indian nut, alÂ­though it does not stem from there, but was just transÂ­ported from its homeÂ­land to Central Asia and Europe via South India. In cenÂ­turies past, such names were common in many more lanÂ­guages, but have largely been abanÂ­doned since then. Examples of names of that type still in use are Turkish hindistanÂ­cevizi, Bulgarian indijsko orekhche [Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¹ÑĞºĞ¾ Ğ¾Ñ€ĞµÑ…Ñ‡Ğµ] and Farsi jowz hendi [Ø¬ÙˆØ² Ù‡Ù†Ø¯ÛŒ]. Note that an analogous name in Armenian means not nutmeg but coconut; in modern English, Indian nut is sometimes used to denote a Central Asian variety of pine nuts, while the same name in German mostly refers to cashew nuts, although these stem from South America.  See also turmeric for the etymology of India.          Unripe nutmeg fruit           Nutmegs on a tree   MaceÂ andÂ reÂ­lated forms (e.â€‰g., German Macis, Estonian maasis, Spanish macia, Hebrew mays [××™×™×¡]) go back to Greek makir [Î¼á½±ÎºÎ¹Ï] or makeir [Î¼á½±ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï], which appears in Dioskurides denoting an Oriental product described as a kind of bark; today, it is not much believed that this was identical to mace, the main argument being that there are no conÂ­tempoÂ­rary records of anything like nutmeg. Some suggest a relation to Sanskrit magha [à¤®à¤˜à¤¾], which means a kind of herbal medicine, while others derive the name from the name of the ancient trading port Malao (todayâ€™s Somalia).           Nutmeg flowers and unripe fruit           Ripe nutmeg fruit   ManyÂ EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages name mace flower of nutmeg (German MuskatÂ­blÃ¼te, Swedish muskotÂ­blomma, Czech muÅ¡Â­kÃ¡tovÃ½ kvÄ›t or French fleur de  muscade). AlÂ­though this is botaÂ­nically inÂ­corÂ­rect, the mace was supÂ­posed to be the flower of the nutmeg tree  during the Middle Ages; even Marco Polo proÂ­pagated this error in the 14.th century.  Note  that English is actually one of the few European langages that does not use names of this kind. Rather, the English term nutmeg flower may mean a completely unrelated plant, nigella.  TheÂ genusÂ naÂ­me Myristica derives from Greek myron [Î¼á½»ÏÎ¿Î½] balm, chrism, ointment, which might be a Semitic loan and thus related to Hebrew mor [××¨] myrrh, which derives from a Common Semitic root MRR bitter. Some other fragrant plants bear similar scientific names, e.â€‰g. Myrtus (myrtle), Myrrhis (cicely) or Myrica (gale). Possibly, also rosemary belongs to that series. Cf. also the Arabic name of bitter almonds, lawz murr [Ù„ÙˆØ² Ù…Ø±].  The species name fragrans also refers to good smell: It is a participle smelling, aromatic of the Latin verb fragrare, smell. used-plant-part: Fresh leaves and flowers.
sensory-quality: The plant has a pleasant anise-like scent (see also licorice), copying almost perfectly the fragrance of tarragon. The leavesâ€™ taste is similar and very intense.
origin: Mexican marigold grows in the South of the USA and in MÃ©xico.
etymology: The botanical genus name Tagetes is in reference to a Roman deity, Tages (which, probably, was originally an Etruscan god of prophecy, but was later adopted as a son or grandson of Jupiter by the Romans). The species name lucidus bright (cf. lux light) refers to the bright orange flowers.  In English marigold Maryâ€™s gold, the second element is probably also motivated by the orange flowers displayed by all members of the genus. I do not know, however, why several Tagetes species are associated with Mary, a significant figure in Latin American Catholic mythology.  See tarragon for the derivation of the name tarragon.

used-plant-part: Unripe fruit, alÂ­ways dried and mostÂ­ly ground.
sensory-quality: Sour and astringent, with a slight, resinous overtone.
main-constituents: Citric acid and related compounds are responsible for the sour taste. Several terpenes (ocimene, myrcene, limonene), aldehydes and esters have been found in the dried unripe fruits. FurtherÂ­more, unripe mangoes contain proteolytic enzymes. In ripe mangoes, volatile compounds (40Â to 70â€‰ppm) are ocimene, limonene, Î±-terpineol, 3-carene, Î²-selinene and myrcene. The yellow colour is due to about 30â€‰ppm Î²-carotene.           Unripe mangoes on the tree           Sacred mango tree in the Ekambaranathar temple [à®à®•à®¾à®®à¯à®ªà®°à®¨à®¾à®¤à®°à¯ à®¤à®¿à®°à¯à®•à¯à®•à¯‹à®¯à®¿à®²à¯] in Kanchipuram
origin: South and SouthÂ­east Asia. Wild mango trees are known only from North-East India and Burma, and so it appears plausÂ­ible that the species evolved there. Etymology The name mango, almost identical in countless languages, is derived from Tamil, the most important language of Southern India, and was transferred to the West by the Portuguese. The general term for mango in Tamil is mamaran [à®®à®¾à®®à®°à®®à¯], but the fruit is usually referred to either as manpalam (also transcribed mambazham [à®®à®¾à®®à¯à®ªà®´à®®à¯]) ripe mango fruit or mangai [à®®à®¾à®™à¯à®•à®¾à®¯à¯] unripe mango fruit. It appears that the latter term was picked up by Portuguese sailors who encountered the fruits at harbours and markets; perhaps, mangoes were dominantly traded in the unripe state at that time.  The North Indian names for mango derive from Sanskrit amra [à¤†à¤®à¥à¤°], itself probably a Dravidian loan and thus related to the Tamil words noted in the previous paragraph, and even to English mango. Only Hindi amchur (also transcribed aamchoor) [à¤†à¤®à¥à¤šà¥‚à¤°] refers to the dried spice, whereas Hindi am [à¤†à¤®] means the fresh fruits.  Sanskrit names like madhulaka [à¤®à¤§à¥‚à¤²à¤•] refer to the sweet taste (madhu [à¤®à¤§à¥] sweet). See licorice and bearâ€™s garlic for related words.  The genus name Mangifera (bringer of mango) contains Latin ferre carry, bring (see also asafetida), cf. Lucifer bringer of light or Christopher he who carries Christ. etymology: The name mango, almost identical in countless languages, is derived from Tamil, the most important language of Southern India, and was transferred to the West by the Portuguese. The general term for mango in Tamil is mamaran [à®®à®¾à®®à®°à®®à¯], but the fruit is usually referred to either as manpalam (also transcribed mambazham [à®®à®¾à®®à¯à®ªà®´à®®à¯]) ripe mango fruit or mangai [à®®à®¾à®™à¯à®•à®¾à®¯à¯] unripe mango fruit. It appears that the latter term was picked up by Portuguese sailors who encountered the fruits at harbours and markets; perhaps, mangoes were dominantly traded in the unripe state at that time.  The North Indian names for mango derive from Sanskrit amra [à¤†à¤®à¥à¤°], itself probably a Dravidian loan and thus related to the Tamil words noted in the previous paragraph, and even to English mango. Only Hindi amchur (also transcribed aamchoor) [à¤†à¤®à¥à¤šà¥‚à¤°] refers to the dried spice, whereas Hindi am [à¤†à¤®] means the fresh fruits.  Sanskrit names like madhulaka [à¤®à¤§à¥‚à¤²à¤•] refer to the sweet taste (madhu [à¤®à¤§à¥] sweet). See licorice and bearâ€™s garlic for related words.  The genus name Mangifera (bringer of mango) contains Latin ferre carry, bring (see also asafetida), cf. Lucifer bringer of light or Christopher he who carries Christ.

This Italian cultivar has an exceptionally intensive flavour.           Fresh leaves of oregano: left a yellow-coloured cultivar (gold marjoram or gold oregano), right regular oregano
note: In the countries of the Eastern MediÂ­terranean, there is often nor clear distinction made between a couple of aromatic herbs of the mint family: Names like Turkish kekik or Arabic zatar/satar [Ø²Ø¹ØªØ±, ØµØ¹ØªØ±] and related forms in Hebrew and Persian,  often in conjunction with qualifying or descriptive adjectives, may be applied to a varity of native herbs including, but not restricted to, oregano, marjoram, thyme and savory. Usage may vary even within a given language, depending on the region and particularly on the local flora. In Jordan, zahtar usually means a spice mixture containing such herbs (see sumac for more).
used-plant-part: Leaves.  The dried herb is often more flavourful than the fresh (see also thyme on this phenomenon).          Fresh leaves of oregano: left a yellow-coloured cultivar (gold marjoram or gold oregano), right regular oregano
sensory-quality: Aromatic, warm and slightly bitter. Oregano largely varies in intensity: Good quality is so strong that it almost numbs the tongue, but the cultivars adapted to colder climate have often unsatisfactory flavour.           Crete oregano with flowers, O. dictamnus
main-conÂ­stituents: The essenÂ­tial oil (max. 4%) may contain variable amounts of the two phenols carvacrol and thymol (see also thyme and savory); furthermore, a variety of monoterpene hydrocarbons (limonene, terpinene, ocimene, caryophyllene, Î²-bisabolene and p-cymene) and monoterpene alcohols (linalool, 4-terpineol) are reported.          Crete oregano with flowers, O. dictamnus   InÂ Mexican oreÂ­gano  (Lippia graveÂ­olens) an esÂ­senÂ­tial oil of very similar conÂ­stituÂ­tion is found. A typical anaÂ­lysis is as folÂ­lows: 50% thymol, 12% carvÂ­acrol, 9% p-cymene and a number of further monoÂ­terpenoids (1,8 cineol, Î³-terpinene, terpinene-4-ol and terpinene-4-yl acetate) in amounts between 1 and 5%.
origin: Several species of genus Origanum are native to the MediÂ­terranean, all of which are traded as a spice. The influence of climate, season and soil on the composition of the essential oil is greater than the difference between the various species.             Oregano plant with flowers            Flowers of Nepali oregano            Oregano native to Nepal   TheÂ mostÂ imporÂ­tant species are O. vulgare (pan-EuroÂ­pean, Asian), O. onites (Greece, Asia Minor) and O. heraÂ­cleoticum (Italy, Balkan penÂ­insular, West Asia). A closeÂ­ly related plant is  marÂ­joram from Asia Minor, which, howÂ­ever, diffÂ­ers signiÂ­ficantly in taste, because phenolic comÂ­pounds are missing in its esÂ­sential oil. Some breeds show an flavour interÂ­mediate between oregano and marÂ­joram (gold marjoramÂ = gold oregano).  Mexican Oregano stems from the plant Lippia graveolens (Verbenaceae) and is closely related to lemon verbena. Although only loosely related to oregano, Mexican oregano displays a flavour very similar to that of oregano, albeit stronger.  It is increasingly traded, especially in the US. Its strong aroma makes it an acceptable substitute for epazote leaves if the latter are not available; this wouldnâ€™t work the other way round, though.  ThereÂ isÂ aÂ sigÂ­nificant taxoÂ­nomic confusion about the term oregano in Mexican cooking. Several plants are named thus in different parts of MÃ©xico, and there is little clear information about those. Some plants that have been identified as Mexican Oregano are Poliomintha longiflora, Lippia berlandieri and Plectranthus amboinicus (syn. Coleus aromaticus).          Oregano native to Nepal  Etymology The Greek name oriÂ­ganon [á½€Ïá½·Â­Î³Î±Î½Î¿Î½] might well contain oros [á½„ÏÎ¿Ï‚]  mounÂ­tain, and the verb ganouÂ­sthai [Î³Î±Î½Î¿á¿¦Â­ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹] delight in, beÂ­cause oregano  preÂ­fers higher altiÂ­tude in MediÂ­terraÂ­nean climate. Some ScandiÂ­navian names also contain an element of that kind: NorÂ­wegian bergmynte and Icelandic bergÂ­minta mounÂ­tain mint and  Finnish mÃ¤kiÂ­meirami hill marjoram; a parallel formaÂ­tion exists in Farsi, avishan kuhi [Ø¢ÙˆÛŒØ´Ù† Ú©ÙˆÙ‡ÛŒ] mountain marjoram. Oregano  is indeed related to mint and marjoram, beÂ­longing to the same plant family LamiaÂ­ceae.  Yet that explanation also has its faults. First, the ancient plant called origanon [á½€Ïá½·Î³Î±Î½Î¿Î½] is not clearly identified; it could well have been a related species, e.â€‰g., marjoram, as the two have often been confused in the course of history. Second, a pre-Greek origin of origanon has also been suggested (possibly dervied from a Semitic tongue of Western Asia or Northern Africa). Confusingly, rosemary bears names with the element mountain in Arabic and Farsi.  Names for Oregano in the large majority of European languages are very similar, or even the same: The spice is named oregano not only in English, but also in German, Danish, Polish and even Hebrew (written ××•×¨×’× ×•). Minor spelling modification occur some other languages, e.â€‰g., Czech oregÃ¡no, Spanish orÃ©gano, Icelandic oreganÃ³, Italian origano, Catalan orenga, Irish Gaelic oragÃ¡n and Portuguese orÃ©gÃ£o. Only a few languages have the name significantly changed: Maltese riegnu and Greek rigani [ÏÎ¯Î³Î±Î½Î·], which was transferred to Albanian (rigon) and Bulgarian (rigan [Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ³Ğ°Ğ½]).  Many tongues name oregano as wild marjoram, e.â€‰g., German wilder Majoran, Swedish vild mejram, Hungarian vadmajorÃ¡nna, Polish dziki majeranek, ProvenÃ§al majurano fero and French  marjolaine sauvage and  marjolaine bÃ¢tarde (bastard marjoram). This is botanically incorrect, because although oregano and marjoram are indeed closely related, one cannot identify the former as the wild form of the latter. From left to right peppermint, Eau de Cologne mint (M. citrata), Japanese mint (M. arvensis var. piperascens, also known as var. japonica), horsemint or silver mint (M. longifolia), Moroccan green mint (M. spicata), pineapple mint (M. suaveolens) and Carinthian mint (M. carinthiaca = M. arvensisÂ x M. suaveolens)             Turkish mint (nane)           Peppermint
note: The term VietÂ­namese mint does not refer to pepperÂ­mint or one of its relaÂ­tives, but to VietÂ­namese coriÂ­ander, a plant botaniÂ­cally not related at all.
used-plant-part: Leaves. For culinary purposs, mint leaves should be used fresh in almost all cases; dried leaves are restricted to a few untypical applications only.
sensory-qualÂ­ity: CharacÂ­teristically pure and refreshing odour, pungent and burning taste.  The typical mint scent is most pure in pepperÂ­mint, JaÂ­panese mint (Mentha arvensis var. piperascens) and some varieÂ­ties of green mint (Mentha spicata, but not spearÂ­mint), whereas in most other mints addiÂ­tional flavour comÂ­ponents are disÂ­cernible; for example, crispate or curly mint (Mentha crispa), though minty, someÂ­what reminds of caraway. The doubleÂ­mint flavour of spearÂ­mint is difficult to deÂ­scribe; itâ€™s minty but not pungent.           Pineapple mint (sterile twig)           Spearmint, a characteristically scented variety of M. spicata           Pineapple mint (sterile twig)   ThereÂ are,Â howÂ­ever, yet other mint cultivars whose fragrance bears no similarity with tradiÂ­tional mint aroma: Orange mint (M. citrata, also called Eau de Cologne mint,        similar to the bergamot orange used to        flavour Earl Grey tea), apple mint (M. rotundifolia =        M. longifolia Ã— M. suaveolens,        very mild, slightly minty, not reminiscent to apples), ginger mint (M. gentilis =        M. arvensis Ã—  M. spicata,        neither minty nor ginger-like at all) and pineapple mint (M. suaveolens, weakly pineapple-like) These plants are more used as tea herbs than for culinary purposes; still,  gifted cooks may  find effective applications.
main-constituents: The essential oil of peppermint (up to 2.5% in the dried leaves) is mostly made up from menthol (ca. 50%), menthone (10 to 30%), menthyl esters (up to 10%) and further monoterpene derivatives (pulegone, piperitone, menthofurane). Traces of jasmone (0.1%) improve the oilâ€™s quality remarkably.  Menthol and menthyl acetate are responsible for the pungent and refreshing odour; they are mostly found in older leaves and are preferentially formed during long daily sunlight periods. On the other hand, the ketones menthone and pulegone (and menthofurane) have a less delightful fragrance; they appear to higher fraction in young leaves and their formation is preferred during short days.           Japanese mint           Pineapple mint with flowers   TheÂ worldâ€™sÂ most imÂ­porÂ­tant source of menthol is, howÂ­ever, not pepperÂ­mint but field mint. Field mint is the only mint species that became naturalÂ­ized in tropical Asia; there are many difÂ­ferent cultiÂ­vars, some of which are grown for direct conÂ­sumpÂ­tion, others for the distillaÂ­tion of essenÂ­tial oil. The JaÂ­panese variety of field mint (Mentha arvensis var. piperÂ­ascens Malinv. ex Holmes), now grown in many Asian countries, may contain up to 5% of essential oil in its tips; more common, however, are 1 to 2%. Chief comÂ­ponent of the oil is menthol (50 to 70%, in rare cases up to 90%). After parts of the menthol have been removed from the oil, the oil is marketed as (dementholized, rectiÂ­fied) Japanese peppermint oil; it typically contains 30 to 45% menthol, 17 to 35% menthone, 5 to 13% menthyl acetate, 2 to 5% limonene and 2.5 to 4% neomenthol. Other terpenes occur but in traces (piperitone, pulegone, Î²-caryophyllene, Î²-caryophyllene-epoxide, Î±-pinene, Î²-pinene, germacrene D, 1,8-cineol, linalool, menthofurane, camphene). A trace component characteristic for this species and missing in other mints is Î²-hexenyl phenylacetate.          Pineapple mint with flowers   TheÂ oilÂ ofÂ this so-called Japanese pepperÂ­mint is often attriÂ­buted with an inÂ­credible wealth of useful medical properties; it is even more inÂ­credible, though, that it never failed to help me in a number of difÂ­ferent inÂ­conveÂ­nient conÂ­ditions like nausea, mild stomach upset or cold.  The menthol obtained as a by-product in the rectiÂ­fication of Japanese pepperÂ­mint oil is used for medical products and for chewing gum. A comÂ­parativeÂ­ly small fraction goes in the proÂ­duction of menthol-flavoured cigarettes, which have been quite popular in Western Europe a few decades ago. See tonka bean for more on flavoured tobacco products.           Pennyroyal (M. pulegium) was a popular culinary herb in ancient Rome (see also silphion)           Moroccan green mint (sterile plant)   WheneverÂ highÂ­ly concentrated menthol is used, one must consider that menthol is toxic to infants; there are rumors that it can induce apnoea.  OtherÂ mints may contain rather difÂ­ferent conÂ­stituents: Mentha pulegium (pennyÂ­royal) conÂ­tains 80% pulegone, and M. crispa (crispate mint) conÂ­tains 50% carvone. Another famed cultivar, spearÂ­mint, owes its phantastic aroma to carvone, limonene, dihydroÂ­carvone, menÂ­thone, puleÂ­gone, 1,8-cineol and Î²-pinene.
origin: PepperÂ­mint is a (usually sterile) hybrid from water mint (M. aquatica)  and spearmint (M. spicata). It is found sometimes wild in Central and SouthÂ­ern Europe, but was probably first put to human use  in EngÂ­land, whence its cultiÂ­vation spread to the EuroÂ­pean conÂ­tinent and Africa; today, Northern Africa is a main cultiÂ­vation area. Other mint species are indiÂ­genous to Europe and Asia, and some are used since millÂ­ennia. Cultivars in tropical Asia always derive from field mint and are, thereÂ­fore, botaniÂ­cally not closely related to EuroÂ­pean pepperÂ­mint, although they come close to pepperÂ­mint in their culinary value. Mints from Western and Central Asia, however, are comÂ­parable not to pepperÂ­mint but to horseÂ­mint and appleÂ­mint.  All species of genus Mentha are aromatic, although not in all of them the aroma is that pure than in peppermint. As a rule of thumb, any mint can be substituted by peppermint, but not always vice versa.           Curly mint, M. spicata var. crispa           Flowering horsemint, M. longifolia           Water mint, M. aquatica
etymology: The names for mint are fairly uniform in most EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages: German Minze, Danish and NorÂ­wegian mynte, Dutch munt, Basque menda, Estonian mÃ¼nt, Finnish minttu, Czech mÃ¡ta, Polish miÄ™ta, Russian myata [Ğ¼ÑÑ‚Ğ°], Lithuanian mÄ—ta, Latvian mÄ“tra, French menthe and Italian menta. All these names derive from Latin mentha mint.  The Latin name mentha itself was borrowed from Greek minthe [Î¼á½·Î½Î¸Î·], whose origin is, however, unknown. It is already found in Mycenaean, the earliest recorded version of Greek, as mintha [ğ€–ğ€²].          Flowering horsemint, M. longifolia   TheÂ EnglishÂ hoÂ­moÂ­nym meaning place where coins are proÂ­duced or the corÂ­responÂ­ding verb are not at all related to the name of the plants; rather, they derive (together with the more familiar money) from the epoÂ­nymous Latin noun moneta, itself being derived from an epiÂ­thet of the godÂ­dess Juno, in whose temple coins were minted.  The pepper-element in peppermint, found in many other languages and also in the botanical species epithet, piperita, refers to the  peppery and pungent taste of this specific mint type.  See also long pepper for the etymology of pepper.          Water mint, M. aquatica   InÂ theÂ New TestaÂ­ment, the mint is called hedyÂ­osmon [á¼¡Î´á½»Â­Î¿ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Î½] (see also pomeÂ­granate). This comÂ­pound means the sweet smelling one: hedys [á¼¡Î´á½»Ï‚] sweet, pleasant (see licorice for more inforÂ­mation) and osme [á½€ÏƒÎ¼á½µ] smell, related to English odour, cf. Latin olere to smell. In modern lanÂ­guages, names deÂ­rived thence have the meaning green mint, spearmint, not pepperÂ­mint, e.â€‰g., Greek diosmos [Î´Ï…ÏŒÏƒÎ¼Î¿Ï‚] and Bulgarian giozum or dzhodzhen [Ğ´Ğ¶Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¶ĞµĞ½].  In Semitic tongues, closely similar names for mint may be observed: Arabic an-na'na' [Ø§Ù„Ù†Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ø¹], Aramaic nanea [Ü¢Ü¢Ü¥Ü] Hebrew nana [× ×¢× ×¢], Maltese nagÄ§niegÄ§ and Tigrinya naenae [áŠ“á‹•áŠ“á‹•]; there are also similar forms in languages outside the Afro-Asiatic family, e.â€‰g., Turkish nane, Albanian  nenexhiku, Pashto nauna and Farsi nana [Ù†Ø¹Ù†Ø§Ø¹]. I donâ€™t know about the exact origin of that group of words, yet it is of ancient origin as testified by Akkadian nÄ«nÅ«. synonyms: botanicalPiper sanctum  DanishMexikansk Peber-blad  EnglishSacred pepper, Root beer plant, Eared pepper  FrenchPoivre mexicain  GermanMexicanischer Blattpfeffer, GeÃ¶hrter Pfeffer, Ohrenpfeffer  HungarianMexikÃ³i borslevÃ©l  LithuanianAusytasis pipiras  RussianĞœĞµĞºÑĞ¸ĞºĞ°Ğ½ÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµÑ‡Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ»Ğ¸ÑÑ‚  Meksikanski perechnyi list  SpanishHoja santa, Yerba santa, Acuyo, Anisillo            Mexican pepper leaf
used-plant-part: Fresh leaves. They can grow to sizes of 30â€‰cm and more. Since dried or fresh leaves are hard to get outside of tropical MÃ©xico, cooks often will need a substitute for Mexican pepperÂ­leaves. The best option is to grow the plant, which turns out rather decorative and surprisingly robust.          Mexican pepper leaf plant   TheÂ canonical substitute for pepper leaves that is widely used even in MÃ©xico are avocado leaves, but only Mexican avocado types (Persea drimyÂ­folia) have scented foliage; avocados from other regions are mostly Persea americana with insipid leaves.  Curiously, many Mexican cookbooks targeted to an English audience suggest this substitution and argue with the potential toxicity of pepper leaves. Indeed, their safrole content is rather high and not completely without risk, although Mexicans donâ€™t care much about it. Yet scented avocado leaves contain exactly the same chemical, and thus offer no health advantage: If they are as fragrant as the authentic pepper leaves, then they are as toxic, too.          Shrub of Mexican Pepper   MexicanÂ tarraÂ­gon or even ordinary French tarÂ­raÂ­gon will work well as substitutes in recipes that use purÃ©ed leaves, but will of course fail for recipes that use Mexican pepper-leaves as wrappers for fish, poultry or tamales; in the latter case, Thai basil (horapha type) can be tried, although those leaves are much smaller.           Shrub of Mexican Pepper           Mexican pepper leaf plant
sensory-quality: Aromatic and pleasant, loosely reÂ­minisÂ­cent to anise, nutmeg and black pepper. The flavour is strongest in the young stems and veins, which have additionally a pleasant warming pungency. See also cicely on the topic of anise fragrance.
main-constituents: The essential oil from the leaves (0.2%) is rich in safrole (up to 80%), a substance with pleasant odour. Furthermore, a large number of mono- and sesquiterpenoids have been found.          Twig with flowers   SeeÂ sassafrasÂ aÂ­bout the poÂ­tenÂ­tial health hazards of safrole. Besides in P. auritum, safrole apÂ­pears in several other neoÂ­tropic pepper species. At least one of them, Piper hispidiÂ­nervium (syn. P. franguaÂ­num), is curÂ­rently grown in Brazil for extracÂ­tion of safrole (pimenta longa). Black pepper contains only traces of this toxic substance.
origin: Tropic Mesoamerica (Southern MÃ©xico, Guatemala, PanamÃ¡, Northern Colombia).           Twig with flowers           Mexican pepperleaf (hoja santa), plant with flower
etymology: See pepper. The species name auritus derives from Latin auris ear and means (long)-eared, referring to the leavesâ€™ cordiate shape.  TheÂ (rare)Â English term eared pepper is open to misÂ­underÂ­standig, because English ear has two distinct meanings organ for hearing and infloresÂ­cence/infrutesÂ­cence of various plants, particularly cereals. The two are actually chance homonyms and derive from difÂ­ferent Proto-Indoâ€“European roots: Hâ‚‚EUS ear (for hearing) (cf. aural), but Hâ‚‚Eá¸° sharp, pointed (cf. acute or acid).          Mexican pepperleaf (hoja santa), plant with flower   InÂ theÂ caseÂ of Mexican pepper, actually both interÂ­pretaÂ­tions would make sense: The infloresÂ­cence conÂ­forms to the botanical definiÂ­tion of ear (it is compact along one stem), and the leaves blades have two large lobes directed backÂ­wards which is comÂ­monly referÂ­red to as eared (thus, all heart-shaped leaves are eared). As can be seen from the Latin species epithet auritus, the latter meaning is the intended one (the other meaning of ear would be expressed by spicatus in Latin, from spica ear (of grain), from Proto-Indoâ€“European spei sharp).  I cannot explain the Spanish name hoja santa sacred leaf; maybe this hints at cultic use of this plant in Aztec rituals. The English name root beer plant is motivated by the olfactory similarity to sassafras, which is used to prepare the US softdrink root beer. Vayser zeneft, Vayse gortshitse, Vayse mustarde             Flowers and ripening fruits of white mustard           White mustard seeds
used-plant-part: Seeds (1Â to 2â€‰mm diaÂ­meter). Although called white mustard, the seeds are actually tan to light brown.
sensory-quality: The dried seed do not have any fragrance, but exhibit a pungent taste after some time of chewing.
main-constituents: Besides proteins (28%) and fixed oil (35%), white mustard seeds contain approx. 2.5% sinalbin, a thioglycoside-like compound of glucose and p-hydroxybenzyl isothiocyanate (HOâ€“C6H4â€“CH2â€“NCS). On cell damage, the enzyme myrosinase hydrolyzes the sinalbin and produces free p-hydroxybenzyl isothiocyanate, a pungent and non-volatile substance. Isothiocyanates are also the main ingredients in black mustard, horseradish, cress, rocket and  wasabi, all of which belong to the same plant family.           White mustard flowers and unripe fruits           White mustard flowers
originÂ: White mustard probÂ­ably origÂ­inates from the MediÂ­terraÂ­nean region, but various cultivars are grown in NorthÂ­ern, Central and Eastern Europe. Related species are Chinese Mustard, S. cernua (syn. Brassica cernua), from China and  rocket, Eruca sativa (syn. Brassica eruca), from Southern and Eastern Europe.
etymology: See black mustard.  Most names for white mustard contain an element white, bright which distinguishes white mustard from its black relatives. In some languages, the epithet is yellow instead, e.â€‰g., Arabic hardal asfur [Ø®Ø±Ø¯Ù„ Ø§ØµÙØ±] (see also safflower), Finnish keltasinappi and Hungarian sÃ¡rga mustÃ¡r. Yet, in most of these languages, both denominations yellow mustard and white mustard are valid.  The colour adjective white is common to all Germanic languages (Old English hwÄ«t, German weiÃŸ, Old High German hwÄ«Ê’, Yiddish vays [×°×²Ö·×¡], Icelandic hvÃ­tur, Swedish vit). The Common Germanic root is HWEITA white, which itself can be related to an Proto-Indoâ€“European root á¸°WEI or á¸°EU shine. The name of the cereal wheat comes from the same root and refers to the bright white colour of wheat flour. In North Germanic tongues, the names of garlic involve a white element.           White mustard (flowers and dry fruits)           White mustard, flowering plants           White mustard plants bearing ripening fruits   Also,Â the Slavonic lanÂ­guages feature closely related words for white: Polish biaÅ‚y, Slovak biele, Russian bielyj [Ğ±ĞµĞ»Ñ‹Ğ¹], BelaÂ­rusian bely [Ğ±ĞµĞ»Ñ‹], and BulÂ­garian byal [Ğ±ÑĞ»] all have a ComÂ­mon SlaÂ­vonic root form BELâ€™ white. The Baltic terms LithuaÂ­nian baltas and Latvian balts belong to the same group, as do the English toponyms Baltic (perhaps from a desigÂ­nation White Sea for the Baltic Sea) and Belarus (white Russia). Also in English, related words are found, which donote colours in wider sense: bleach, blond, blue (see also blue fenuÂ­greek) and even, most surÂ­prisingly, black (see nigella). The Proto-Indoâ€“European root can be reconÂ­structed as BÊ°EL fire, shine. TheÂ Romance forms Italian bianco, Portuguese branco, French blanc and Spanish blanco are actually Germanic loans. The Common Germanic root BLANKA shiny is still found in Modern English in words like blink, blaze or blank (meaning empty, as white is devoid of colours). Traced further back, the terms are seen to derive from the versatile root BÊ°EL discussed in the previous paragraph.  The original Latin term for white was albus, which is conserved only in the East Romance tongues (Romanian alb). The Proto-Indoâ€“European form can be reconstructed as Hâ‚‚ELBÊ°O white; yet it has exclusively Western distribution, being found in toponyms like the river Elbe and the Alps mountains,  moreover Old Greek alphos [á¼€Î»Ï†á½¹Ï‚] white leprosity (cf. Albino) Therefore, it has been suspected to be rather a loan from an Old European tongue. The word also underlies Old Norse Ã¡lfr and Old English Ã¦lf frightening supernatural creature and its Modern English translation elf. Elves seem to have been associated with fog, thus the whitish name. In the German Nibelungenlied, there is a character Alberich belonging to a group of dwarves (generally similar to elves in Nordic mythology) called Nibelungs (Old Norse njÅl, Latin nebula fog, mist).  Elves appear often in pre-Christian Germanic traditions; they were considered a powerful, dangerous race harrassing humans, as exemplified by Old English ylfa gescot sudden pain or illness (literally elf-shot, as if caused by an invisible elven archer) and German Albtraum nightmare (literally elf-dream, invoking the image of a powerful sprite sitting on a sleeperâ€™s chest).  A negative and condemning view on elves is found in the Beowulf poem, where eotenas ond ylfe ond orcnÄ“as giants and elves and evil spirits are numbered among the descendents of Cain, the primeval murderer.  English elf almost went extinct over the centuries, and was revived in the 16.th century, at the same time shifting in meaning to friendly, small-sized spirit. Yet even these diminished later elves have linguistic ties to their more powerful cousins of old: Cute Oberon, the Elvish King in Shakespeareâ€™s Midsummer Nightâ€™s Dream, still carries the same name as the more warlike Alberich (Old French Alberon). used-plant-part: Around the MediÂ­terraÂ­nean, mostly the fresh or dried leaves are used; the dried berry fruits are also aromatic and have been tried as a substitute for black pepper.
sensory-quality-: The leaves exemanate an aromatic and reÂ­freshing  smell someÂ­what reminisÂ­cent to myrrh or eucalypt; the taste is very intenÂ­sive, quite disÂ­agreeÂ­able and strongly bitter.
main-constituents: The most important constituents of myrtle oil (up to 0.8% in the leaves) are myrtenol, myrtenol acetate, limonene (23%), linalool (20%), pinene (14%), cineol (11%), furthermore, p-cymene, geraniol, nerol and the phenylpropanoid, methyleugenol. There is considerable variability in the composition of oil from different locations.
origin: The plant grows abundantly in the North Western to Eastern Mediterranean; its multiple occurrences in the Old Testament testifies its significance to West Asian peoples (see also pomegranate).           Myrtle flowers           Myrtle flower www.botanikus.de
etymology: Myrtle has closely related names in most European and even some non-European languages; besides English myrtle, we have German Myrte, Estonian mÃ¼rt, Spanish mirto, Scottisch Gaelic miortal, Modern Greek mirtia [Î¼Ï…ÏÏ„Î¹Î¬], Russian myrt [Ğ¼Ñ‹Ñ€Ñ‚], Armenian mrdeni [Õ´Ö€Õ¿Õ¥Õ¶Õ«] and Farsi mourd [Ù…ÙˆØ±Ø¯]. All these names relate to Old Greek myrtos [Î¼á½»ÏÏ„Î¿Ï‚] or myrsine [Î¼Ï…ÏÏƒá½·Î½Î·] and were typically transmitted via Latin  myrtus. The Greek term entered the language probably as a Semitic loan; see also nutmeg.  Besides the Greco-Latin mirto, Spanish has another term for myrtle, which is of Arabic origin: ArrayÃ¡n is a medieval loan from Andalusian Arabic ar-raihan [Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙŠØ­Ø§Ù†] the myrtle; this term is still valid in modern Arabic, but in the Arabic-speaking countries of the Eastern Mediterranean and of Asia, it has changed its meaning to basil, while the denotation myrtle is conserved only in North African Arabic; cf also Maltese riÄ§an myrtle.  Raihan derives from the Arabic noun rih [Ø±ÙŠØ­] odour. See also caper for Arabic loanwords in Iberic languages. Selected Links chemikalienlexikon.de: Linalool Die Myrte (Jens Rathke)

Rozmarin            Rosemary, sterile shoot           Flowering rosemary
used-plant-part: The small needle-like leaves.
sensory-quality: Strongly aromatic (reminiscent to camphor or eucalyptus), resinous and slightly bitter.
main-constitÂ­uents: The leaves contain about 1 to 2.5% essential oil. Therein, 1,8-cineol (30%), camphor (15 to 25%), borneol (16 to 20%), bornyl acetate (max. 7%), Î±-pinene (max. 25%) and others contribute to the complex taste. On the tannin content see hyssop and on bitterness in general see zedoary.
origin: Mediterranean. Rosemary was one of the plants that, according to the Capitulare de villis, was grown in medieval monasteries (see lovage). However, its poor resistance to freezes limited its popularity, especially in regions north of the Alps. Freeze-tolerant rosemary cultivars (e.â€‰g., Arp) are a relatively new invention.           Rosemary plant www.rz.uni-karlsruhe.de           Rosemary (flowering branch)   Today,Â roseÂ­mary is cultivated in nearly all countries around the MediÂ­terranean Sea, furtherÂ­more in England, the US and MÃ©xico.
etymology: In Latin tongue, the plant was called rosmarinus; most sources interpret this as made from ros dew (akin to Sanskrit rasa [à¤°à¤¸] sap, juice) and marinus belonging to the sea (from Latin mare sea, derived from the Proto-Indoâ€“European root MORI water; lake; cf. marine and mermaid).  Truly, rosemary often grows at low altitude and therefore near the sea. It does, however, not typically populate the coast, where the spray of sea water might motivate the name dew of the sea. Possibly, the name refers not to the habitat but to the sea-blue flowers of rosemary. It has been argued that rosmarinus itself is a product of folk etymology. Possible candidates for the original  name are Greek rhops [á¿¥á½½Ïˆ] shrub and myron [Î¼á½»ÏÎ¿Î½] balm,  which make a good name for the aromatic plant, but pose more linguistic  problems (see also nutmeg for the etymology of myron). Lastly, the Greek name of sumac, rhous [á¿¥Î¿á¿¦Ï‚], is sometimes set into relation with rosmarinus.  Most European languages have names for rosemary that still much resemble the original Latin rosmarinus: German Rosmarin, Finnish rosmariini, Italian ramerino, Spanish romero, Basque erromero, Albanian rozmarinÃ«, Serbo-Croatian ruÅ¾marin [Ñ€ÑƒĞ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½], Bulgarian rozmarin [Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ¼Ğ°Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ½] and Greek rozmari [ÏÎ¿Î¶Î¼Î±ÏÎ¯]. In Greek, however, it is more common to call rosemary dendrolivano [Î´ÎµÎ½Ï„ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯Î²Î±Î½Î¿], which literally mean incense tree:  livani [Î»Î¹Î²Î¬Î½Î¹] incense und dendro [Î´Î­Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿] tree. See also juniper for the linguistic affiliation of the latter.             Sterile rosemary shrub            Rosemary             Rosemary flowers   ArabicÂ al-iklil al-jabal [Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙƒÙ„ÙŠÙ„ Ø§Ù„Ø¬Ø¨Ù„] and Persian  eklil kuhi [Ø§Ú©Ù„ÛŒÙ„ Ú©ÙˆÙ‡ÛŒ] both mean crown of the mounÂ­tain, but I cannot get what these names is referÂ­ring to. ShortÂ­ened to  al-iklil [Ø§Ù„Ø¥ÙƒÙ„ÙŠÙ„] the crown, the Arabic name is the source of the modern PortuÂ­guese name of roseÂ­mary, alÂ­ecrim. See also caper for further Iberic loans of Arabic plant names.  StrangeÂ­ly, there is a related herb whose name is also often conÂ­nected to mountain without conÂ­vincing semantic exÂ­planation: oregano is often suspected to derive Greek oros [á½„ÏÎ¿Ï‚] mountain.

used-plant-part: The fruit (a drupe), which is pale green when unripe and purple to black when ripe. Most olive fruits are harvested for the extraction of olive oil; only a small fraction goes into the production of pickled olives.  The leaves of the olive tree are used medicinally for their hypotensive qualities.
sensory-quality: Raw unripe olives are very bitter; to make them palatable, the bitter constituents are reduced by treatment with lye. Ripe olives, on the other hand, can be directly preserved in salt or brine.           Olives in various stages of ripening homepage.bluewin.ch   OliveÂ oilÂ has a very variÂ­able flavour. The best oils can have mild or strong flavour that ranges someÂ­where between floral, fruity or fresh. Poor qualities have pungent, acidic, rancid or even no aroma.
main-constituents: In leaves and fruits of the olive tree, a phenolic seco-iridoid called oleuropein is found; it is the hypotensive principle. Before pickling olives, the oleuropein is removed either by treatment with lye or by lactic fermentation; the remaining residues of oleuropein are sometimes said to prevent diseases resulting from high blood pressure.          Olive branch with unripe fruit   OliveÂ oilÂ is obÂ­tained from the mesoÂ­carp (pulp) of special varieties of olives with rather small fruits; the mesoÂ­carp contains about 55% of oil.  In the past, olive oil was extracted in hydraulic presses, like most other vegetable oils (see sesame); from that time stems the term cold-pressed for the first fractions with best flavour, which were extracted at low temperature and less than 50â€‰bar pressure (Italian olio extra vergine di oliva, Greek partheno elaiolado [Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸Î­Î½Î¿ ÎµÎ»Î±Î¹ÏŒÎ»Î±Î´Î¿]).           Olive branch with unripe fruits           Olive branch with unripe fruit   Today,Â howÂ­ever, olive oil is almost exÂ­clusively obtained by centriÂ­fugation, which allows much better yield without applying elevated temÂ­perature. ConÂ­sequently, almost all olive oil in the food sector is cold-pressed olive oil.  The very best quality (dripping oil) is produced without centrifugation, by sedimentation only; it is rare and expensive. The best quality produced in mass scale is called native olive oil extra in the countries of the European Union; native extra loosely corresponds to the more historic term extra vergine. Both native olive oil extra and the next quality class, native olive oil, must be produced without applying heat, and must not be refined. Products called simply olive oil, however, have usually been refined and often contain small amounts of native oils to improve the flavour.  Olive oil is composed, like all vegetable oils (see also sesame), of fatty acids bound to the alcohol glycerol. Typically, the following fatty acids are found in olive oil: 66% oleic acid, 12% linoleic acid, 9% palmitic acid, 5% eicosenoic acid and 5% palmitoleic acid. Olive oil may contain up to 1.5% of an acyclic triterpene hydrocarbon, squalene.           Ripe olive           Flowering olive branch   TheÂ mostÂ imÂ­portant parameter for the quality of olive oils is the content of free fatty acids, which must be below 0.8% for native olive oil extra, but may be up to 2% for native olive oil. Free fatty acids are formed in the ground olive paste by action of enzymes (lipases) contained in the olive fruits. The only way to control their formation is cooling and quick extraction. Free fatty acids are unwanted because they lower the smoke point and contribute off-flavour.  The desired flavour of olive oil is dominated by aldehydes (hexanal and 2-hexenal). Furthermore, higher aldehydes, primary alcohols (mainly C6 compounds like hexanol, 2-hexene-1-ol, 3-hexene-1-ol) and their acetic acid esters contribute to the characteristic olive oil aroma. Lastly, hemiterpenoid volatiles were found (3-methyl butanal, 4-methoxy-2-methyl-butanethiol, ethyl esters of 2- and 3-methyl butyric acid). The flavour components, however, depend on variety and geographic origin of the oil.  The typical olive oil colour is due to plant pigments of the carotenoid series (Î²-carotene, phytofluene, Î¾-carotene, lutein, auroxanthin, luteoxanthin, violaxanthin, neoxanthin, neochrome), which contribute a yellow hue, and greenish to brown porphyrines (chlorophyllÂ a and b, and pheophytineÂ a and b). Chlorophyll content may be as high as 10â€‰ppm.
origin: Cultivation of the olive tree is known in the Eastern MediÂ­terranean since five millennia. Whether the plant really stems from these regions or is a native to Central Asia is subject to debate.           OlivenblÃ¼ten           Olive flowers
etymology: Olive is a loan from Latin oliva olive; olive tree, which itself was derived from Greek: elais [á¼Î»Î±á½·Ï‚] olive tree and elaia [á¼Î»Î±á½·Î±] (from older elaiva [á¼Î»Î±á½·ÏÎ±], Mycenaean elaiwa [ğ€ğ€¨ğ€·, ğ€ğ‰ğ€·, ğ‚]) olive; olive tree; furthermore elaion [á¼”Î»Î±Î¹Î¿Î½] (Mycenaean elaiwon [ğ€ğ€¨ğ€º, ğ€ğ‰ğ€º, ğ‚•]) olive oil.  These words are not Indoâ€“European in origin; it is generally accepted that they were transferred to Greek by some Eastern Mediterranean language, often assumed to be Semitic. Yet as we donâ€™t know the botanical origin of the olive tree, the name could, together with the tree, have travelled from more distant Eastern regions. There is a curious connection to the Dravidian languages which are today spoken in Southern India: Sesame, an important local source of vegetable oil, bears names that are remarkably similar to Greek elaia, e.â€‰g., Tamil ellu (pronounced yellu [à®à®³à¯à®³à¯]). Sometimes, both words are suspected to derive from a common ancestor, e.â€‰g., Akkadian ellu flower, fruit, olive.          Olive flowers   MostÂ ofÂ the conÂ­tempoÂ­rary EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages have a word for olive that derives, directly or inÂ­directly, from Latin oliva. ExÂ­amÂ­ples are German Olive, Polish oliwka, Slovenian oljka, Frisian oliif, Latvian olÄ«vas and Dutch olijf. In some languages, the name got slightly modified, e.â€‰g., Lithuanian alyvos and Albanian ullir.  The medieval German terms for olive were Old High German oliberi (10.th century) and Middle High German Ã¶lber oil-berry, which were obviously formed under the influence of Latin oliva (Old High German oli oil is an old Romance loanword from Latin oleum and attested since the 8.th century). Modern German Olive is a much younger loan (16.th century). The Middle High German term has vanished from the language, but was conserved in Yiddish as eylbirt [××²×œ×‘×™×¨×˜], which, however, is today also used to denote other oilseed plans, e.â€‰g., sunflower.  Only in the languages of the Iberic peninsula, the Latin name was superseded by an Arabic loan: Spanish aceituna and Portuguese azeitona both come from Arabic az-zaytun [Ø§Ù„Ø²ÙŠØªÙˆÙ†] the olive; on the other hand, Spanish oliva and Portuguese oliveira refer to the tree, not to the fruit. See also capers for more examples of Arabic loans in Iberic languages.           Olive branch with unripe fruits           Very young olives, shortly after pollination   TheÂ Arabic word zaytun [Ø²ÙŠØªÙˆÙ†] is cognate to Hebrew zayith [×–×™×ª], Aramaic zayta [Ü™ÜÜ¬Ü] and perhaps also Coptic jeeit [Ï«â²‰â²‰â²“â²§] olive and might derive from a Common Semitic root signifying to be prominent; on the other side, it might also have been borrowed from a language of Mesopotamia (Sumerian zirdum [ğ’¢ğ’…•ğ’Œˆ], Akkadian serdu). Due to the spread of IslÃ¢m, the word was subsequently transferred to many more languages, from the Mediterranean (Portuguese azeitona) to Africa (Swahili zeituni) and Asia, which features related names in a wide area from the Caucasus to the South Asian tropics: Georgian zetis [áƒ–áƒ”áƒ—áƒ˜áƒ¡], Armenian jiteni [Õ±Õ«Õ©Õ¥Õ¶Õ«], Kazakh zÃ¤ytun [Ğ·Ó™Ğ¹Ñ‚ÑƒĞ½], Kurdish zaitun [Ø²Ø©ÛŒØªÙˆÙˆÙ†], Farsi zeitun [Ø²ÛŒØªÙˆÙ†], Punjabi and Hindi jaitun [à¨œà©ˆà¨¤à©‚à¨¨, à¥›à¥ˆà¤¤à¥‚à¤¨], Tamil saidun [à®šà¯ˆà®¤à¯‚à®£à¯], Dhivehi zaithooni [Ş’Ş¦Ş‡Ş¨ŞŒŞ«Ş‚Ş¨] and even Mongolian chidun [Ñ‡Ğ¸Ğ´ÑƒĞ½]. Another, more distantly related word is Maltese Å¼ebbuÄ¡ which is suspected to derive from a term for olive in the Berber language, which also belongs to the Semitic language subfamily.  Due to the enormous importance of olives for both the Greek and the Roman cultures, their name entered nearly every European language via Latin oleum oil as generic word for liquid fats, e.â€‰g., English oil, French huile, German Ã–l, Italian olio, Dutch olie, Polish olej and Finnish Ã¶ljy.          Olive branch with unripe fruits   Similarly,Â the Iberic names for oil (Spanish aceite, PorÂ­tuguese azeite besides Ã³leo) derive from the local names of olive, aceituna and azeitona, respecÂ­tively.  In other parts of the world, the generic names of cooking fats may also be derived from whatever oilseed dominates local cookery. Examples are provided by coconut and sesame.  Some Slavonic names of olive, e.â€‰g., Bulgarian maslina [Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°] olive, have an exactly opposite history: Maslina derives from maslo [Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¾] oil, fat, which originally meant butter (from a Common Slavonic root MAZ- spread). Words related to Bulgarian maslina made their way into some non-Slavonic languages, e.â€‰g., Romanian mÄƒslin and Yiddish masline [××Ö·×¡×œ×™× ×¢].  The term maslo [Ğ¼Ğ°ÑĞ»Ğ¾], however, is not used for olive oil in Bulgarian, which is instead known as zehtin [Ğ·ĞµÑ…Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ½] (from Turkish zeytin olive). Vegetable oils are often called olio [Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ¾] in Bulgarian.  Occasionally, fruits of botanically unrelated trees may be called olives, often with an epithet referring to distribution. For example, the Bengali olives (or Indian olives) are the aromatic fruits of Elaeocarpus robustus; in West Bengal and Bangladesh, they are often used to prepare a chutney with delicious fruity and acidic taste. A similar case is the Thai olive ma kok [à¸¡à¸°à¸à¸­à¸] (Spondias mombin, Sp. pinnata, Sp. cytherea and others), which allegedly gave its name to Thailandâ€™s capital, Bangkok. Such designations may sometimes be used to denote true Mediterranean olives in the local language, with or without an epithet foreign.

note: In EuroÂ­pean lanÂ­guages, there is no disÂ­tinction between the South East Asian species yielding pandanus leaves and the South Asian species yielding pandanus flowers.
used-plant-part: Male flowers. They are almost exclusively used in the form of an aqueous distillate called kewra water.
sensory-quality: Kewra flowers have a sweet, perfumed odour with a pleasant quality similar to rose flowers, but kewra is more fruity. The aqueous distillate (kewra water, pandanus flower water) is quite diluted; it can be used by the teaspoon, often even by the tablespoon.
main-constituents: The essential oil from pandanus flowers is dominated by 2-phenylethyl-methylether (Î²-phenyl ethyl methyl ether, 60 to 80%); minor comÂ­ponents are the free alcohol, 2-phenylÂ­ethanol (Î²-phenyl ethyl alcohol) and its acetic acid ester; 2-phenylÂ­ethanol is also an important aroma component in rose water. Because it is well soluble in water, 2-phenylÂ­ethanol can be captured in aqueous distillates quite easily. (Indian Perfumer, 36, 93, 1992) Furthermore, monoterpenes have been found to contribute to the fragrance. The most important terpene in pandanus flowers is  terpinene-4-ol (up to 15%); furthermore,  Î±-terpineol, Î³-terpinene and dipentene have been reported.           Pandanus tree with visible stilt root           Kewra Stem   TheÂ ripeÂ fruits of P. tectorius owe their scent to an essential oil dominated by esters: Besides geranyl acetate, a couple of hemiÂ­terpenoid esters were found: isopentenyl (3-methylbut-3-enyl)  and, to a lesser degree, dimethyl allyl (3-methylbut-2-enyl) acetates and cinnamates. (PhytoÂ­chemistry, 43, 1277, 1996) Origin Various species of the genus Pandanus grow in tropical regions of Asia, Australia nad the Pacific; one of those has fragrant leaves used as spice.  The species that yields the fragrant kewra water is P. odoratisÂ­simus, which grows in large number along the Indian East coast. It is also found, in lesser quantities, along the Indian West coast and Sri Lanka. Further inland, it becomes rarer, but scattered specimen grow all over the plains of the Eastern half of North India, including the lowland of Nepal (Terai).  Some consider P. odoratissimus a fragrant subspecies of P. tectorius Parkinson, which is distributed much wider up to Australia and Polynesia.           Pandanus palm with unripe fruit           Pandanus fruits (ripe and unripe)   CultivationÂ of P. odoratÂ­issimus is almost limited to the Indian union state Orissa, more precicely, the Ganjam district in Southern Orissa. The flowers, which are most abundant during the monsoon season, are havested early in the morning, as they lose  their fragrance quickly after opening;  thereafter, they are immediately subjected to hydroÂ­distillation in one of the countless small distilleries found in the region. The distilleries mainly consist of a row of earthen pots that are filled with flowers and water, and a second, parallel rown of water basins used too cool the distillate, which is collected in copper pots immersed into that water. Distillation takes place in a closed apparatus without any control of temperature or pressure, the steam flowing from the heated erthen pot to the cooled copper pot in bamboo pipes that are sealed with mud.  The distillations yields several grades of essences: Addition of sandalwood results in a product called attar kewra which is the common grade in perfumery; the pure, rather costly essential oil is known as ruh kewra. Kewra water is a cheap byproduct of hydrodistillation suited for culinary use. Flowers of lower quality, as are common during the dry season, can be processed into kewra water only.  SomeÂ other Pandanus species are valued because of their edible fruits or their strong leaves, which can be used for plating. Etymology See pandanus leaves. The English term screw tree and its analogues in many European languages are motivated by the arrangement of leaves typical for the genus. origin: Various species of the genus Pandanus grow in tropical regions of Asia, Australia nad the Pacific; one of those has fragrant leaves used as spice.  The species that yields the fragrant kewra water is P. odoratisÂ­simus, which grows in large number along the Indian East coast. It is also found, in lesser quantities, along the Indian West coast and Sri Lanka. Further inland, it becomes rarer, but scattered specimen grow all over the plains of the Eastern half of North India, including the lowland of Nepal (Terai).  Some consider P. odoratissimus a fragrant subspecies of P. tectorius Parkinson, which is distributed much wider up to Australia and Polynesia.           Pandanus palm with unripe fruit           Pandanus fruits (ripe and unripe)   CultivationÂ of P. odoratÂ­issimus is almost limited to the Indian union state Orissa, more precicely, the Ganjam district in Southern Orissa. The flowers, which are most abundant during the monsoon season, are havested early in the morning, as they lose  their fragrance quickly after opening;  thereafter, they are immediately subjected to hydroÂ­distillation in one of the countless small distilleries found in the region. The distilleries mainly consist of a row of earthen pots that are filled with flowers and water, and a second, parallel rown of water basins used too cool the distillate, which is collected in copper pots immersed into that water. Distillation takes place in a closed apparatus without any control of temperature or pressure, the steam flowing from the heated erthen pot to the cooled copper pot in bamboo pipes that are sealed with mud.  The distillations yields several grades of essences: Addition of sandalwood results in a product called attar kewra which is the common grade in perfumery; the pure, rather costly essential oil is known as ruh kewra. Kewra water is a cheap byproduct of hydrodistillation suited for culinary use. Flowers of lower quality, as are common during the dry season, can be processed into kewra water only.  SomeÂ other Pandanus species are valued because of their edible fruits or their strong leaves, which can be used for plating.
etymology: See pandanus leaves. The English term screw tree and its analogues in many European languages are motivated by the arrangement of leaves typical for the genus.

used-plant-part: In Japanese cooking, the fresh leaves are used. The dried seeds have a strong pungency, but I have not heard of them being used in any ethnic cuisine.
sensory-quality: The plant has hardly any odour. On chewing, it is slightly bitter in the first moment, but then develops a pungent, bitingâ€“prickling heat, which lasts for a while, similar to Sichuan pepper.  See also negro pepper about pungent and zedoary about bitter spices.           Water pepper (sterile twig)
main-constiÂ­tuents: A bicyclic sesquiÂ­terpenoid, polygodial (tadeonal, an unÂ­saturated dialdehyd with a drimane backbone) has been found responsible for the pungent taste; rutin (see rue) is the source of the bitter taste impression. Polygodial also appears in an exotic Australian spice, Tasmanian pepper, and, in small quantity, in the Brazil paracress.  The plant contains an essential oil (0.5%) which is mainly made up of monoterpenoids and sesquiterpenoids: Î±-pinene, Î²-pinene, 1,4-cineol, fenchone and Î±-humulene, Î²-caryophyllene, trans-Î²-bergamotene. Carboxylic acids (cinnamic, valeric, capronic acid) and their esters were present in traces. The composition depends strongly on genetic factors.
origin: The plant grows at wet places in temperate to tropical Eurasia, North Africa and North America. The subspecies from temperate climate (ssp. hydropiper) is larger and has two-sided fruits, whereas the tropical subspecies (ssp. microcarpum) is generally smaller and produces three-sided fruits.           Water pepper twig bearing flowers           Water pepper flower
etymology: The term water pepper is motivated on one hand by the pungent peppery taste and on the other side by the plantâ€™s natural habitat; analog formations are found in other European languages (German WasserÂ­pfeffer, French poivre dâ€™eau, Serbian vodeni biber [Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´ĞµĞ½Ğ¸ Ğ±Ğ¸Ğ±ĞµÑ€] or Russian perets vodyanoj [Ğ¿ĞµÑ€ĞµÑ† Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ñ‹Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ¹]). Cf. also the English term marsh pepper and the Romanian name piper broaÈ™tei (piper broaÅŸtei) frogâ€™s pepper.  The botanical species name, hydropiper, derives directly from the classical Greek plant name hydropeperi [á½‘Î´ÏÎ¿Ï€á½³Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹], which appears in Dioskuridesâ€™ medical plant book (hydor [á½•Î´Î¿Ï] water and peperi [Ï€á½³Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹] pepper).  The word water has relatives in nearly every Indoâ€“European language: Hittitee wÄtar [ğ’‰¿ğ’€€ğ’‹«ğ’…ˆ], Greek hydor [á½•Î´Î¿Ï], Russian voda [Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ°] (vodka [Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´ĞºĞ°] is a diminutive little water), Irish uisce (whisky is shortened from Gaelic uisge beatha water of life), Lithuanian  vanduo, Sanskrit uda [à¤‰à¤¦] water, furthermore Latin unda  wave. Another related English words  are otter and possibly aurochs. At these wordsâ€™ basis lies a variable Proto-Indoâ€“European root WED- with basic meaning wet, whence WODRÌ¥ water is derived.           Water pepper   TheÂ LatinÂ word for water, aqua, lives today in the Romance languages, e.â€‰g., in Italian acqua and French eau. In Germanic tongues, we have Gothic ahva, Old High German aha, Old English ea and Old Norse a  water, Modern German Au area around a river. Possibly related words are  found in other Western Indoâ€“European tongues: Hittitee ekuzi he drinks and Tocharic yok- drink, which might all derive from Proto-Indoâ€“EuropeanÂ­pean AKÊ·Ä€ water. About the genus name PolyÂ­gonum, see the closely related Vietnamese coriander. Selected Links Sorting Persicaria names (www.plantnames.unimelb.edu.au)

used-plant-part: The interior of the pomeÂ­granate fruit is composed of many pinkâ€“red, succulent grains of pulp-like tissue, each of which contains a small seed. These grains  are usually, slightly inaccurately, referred to as pomeÂ­granate seeds.  Dried pomeÂ­granate seeds stem from sour varieties with very small fruits; their seeds cannot be eaten raw. TheÂ barkÂ ofÂ the pomeÂ­granate tree may be used as a very strong laxans (purgaÂ­tive) in some folk-medical systems, but it has several serious side-effects.
sensory-quality: The seeds of cultiÂ­vated forms of pomeÂ­granate have a fresh, sweetâ€“sour, very pleasant taste. Some strains actually taste honey-sweet, while others may display balanced sweetness and acidity; occasionÂ­ally, one meets very acidic ones.  The spice is won from plants that belong to a wild form of pomeÂ­granate. Their seeds have an aggressively acidic and astringent taste.  See Mango for a comparative discussion of sour spices.          Fresh pomegranate seeds
main-constituents: Fruit acids and sugar. Pomegranate seeds are also rich in Vitamin C. All plant parts contain astringent tannines, but the seeds of cultivated forms are free of tannines because of human selection.
origin: Central Asia, probably Persia. Now cultivated in Western and Central Asia, Mediterranean countries and Northern India. In all that area, pomegranate trees are commonly found escaped into wilderness.           Split-open pomegranate fruit   Pomegranate is a veryÂ popÂ­ularÂ fruit all over the Middle East. Though it can't be proven defiÂ­nitely, the fruit of the Tree of KnowlÂ­edge (ets ha-daat [×¢Öµ×¥ ×”Ö·×“Ö¼Ö·×¢Ö·×ª]) menÂ­tioned in the biblical history of creation most probably was meant to be a pomeÂ­granateÂ â€” though most WestÂ­erners would hardly believe it, itâ€™s noÂ­where said to be an apple! Rather, the Hebrew text uses pÉ™ri [×¤Ö¼Ö°×¨Ö´×™], an unÂ­specific term meaning just fruit. There is also a parallel in Greek mythoÂ­logy, where the earth goddess Demeter [Î”Î·Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï] lost her daughter PerseÂ­phone [Î ÎµÏÏƒÎµÏ†á½¹Î½Î·] to the underworld god Hades [á¾Î´Î·Ï‚] because of one single pomegranate grain the daughter had accepted.           Wild form of pomegranate on thorny shub            Almost mummyfied pomegranate (wild form)   TheÂ sweet cultivars of pomeÂ­granate are, thus, widely disÂ­tributed; the spice, however, is harÂ­vested from small-fruited trees that are much closer to the wild form. Thy are grown in the HimaÂ­layas, for example along the highway from Jammu to Srinagar in the JammuÂ & Kashmir state of India. The small trees or shubs bear long thorns and small fruits rarely exceeding 3Â cm diameter; their seeds are very acidic and astringent. Those plants also yield herbal medicines and textile dyes. Etymology The name pomegranate is of ancient origin. In classical Latin, the fruit was known either as malum punicum or malum granatum (also melogranatum). In these names, malum means apple, granatum derives from granum grain and means (multi)grained (alluding to the many seed grains). The adjective punicus properly refers to Phoenicia in Asia Minor, but was in Latin more frequently used  with respect to Carthage, a Phoenician colony in Northern Africa (also Romeâ€™s only source of Silphion); the Romans suspected pomegranate to be of African origin. The botanical genus name Punica is the feminine form of that adjective, as is appropriate for a fruit-bearing tree.           Pomegranate flower           Flowering pomegranate plant   NamesÂ ofÂ pomeÂ­granate in conÂ­temÂ­porary West and Central EuroÂ­pean tongues are adapÂ­tations malum granatum, for example Italian meloÂ­grano, which is a direct sucÂ­cessor of the Latin term, or milÂ­groym [××™×œ×’×¨×±×], a rare case of a Romance loanÂ­word in Yiddish. In other lanÂ­guages, the first part  usualÂ­ly gets transÂ­lated: Examples are German GranatÂ­apfel, Icelandic granatÂ­epli or Finnish granaattiÂ­omena. The English name pomeÂ­granate has a similar structure, but conÂ­tains Latin  pomum fruit, apple (French pomme apple) instead of malum; the Old English term is cornappla grain-apple. In some languages, the apple-element is dropped completely, e.â€‰g., Ukrainian granat [Ò‘Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚] and Spanish granada.  In many European languages, the weapon shell has names similar to granate or grenade. These derive from the same Latin word granum grain: The reference is to the many fragments resulting from the detonation of a shell. Remarkably, also in Hebrew the word  rimon [×¨×™××•×Ÿ] may mean both pomegranate fruit and shell. The underlying Semitic root, RMM, means high, exalted and does not refer to grainyness. The plant name is also found in Arabic (ar-rumman [Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù…Ø§Ù†]) and Coptic (erman [â²‰â²£â²™â²â²›]), but without the secondary shell meaning.  The Farsi name anar [Ø§Ù†Ø§Ø±] already existed in Middle Persian; many language from Eastern Europe to the Indian Ocean have similar or identical names, which are probably direct or indirect Persian loans, e.â€‰g., Dhivehi annaaru [Ş‡Ş¦Ş‚Ş°Ş‚Ş§ŞƒŞª], Punjabi and Kazakh anar [à¨…à¨¨à¨¾à¨°, Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ€], Armenian nur [Õ¶Õ¸Ö‚Ö€] and Turkish and Bulgarian nar [Ğ½Ğ°Ñ€]. There might be a connection to ancient languages of Mesopotamia: Akkadian nurmÃ» and Sumerian nur [ğ’‰¡ğ’Œ¨] or nurma [ğ’‰¡ğ’Œ¨ğ’ˆ£]  Some of the Indian names of pomegranate contain an element sweet derived from the Proto-Indoâ€“European root MEDÊ°U : Sanskrit madhubija [à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¬à¥€à¤œ] and Tamil madulam [à®®à®¾à®¤à¯à®³à®®à¯]. See bearâ€™s garlic and licorice for details. The adjective punicus properly refers to Phoenicia in Asia Minor, but was in Latin more frequently used  with respect to Carthage, a Phoenician colony in Northern Africa (also Romeâ€™s only source of Silphion); the Romans suspected pomegranate to be of African origin. The botanical genus name Punica is the feminine form of that adjective, as is appropriate for a fruit-bearing tree.           Pomegranate flower           Flowering pomegranate plant   NamesÂ ofÂ pomeÂ­granate in conÂ­temÂ­porary West and Central EuroÂ­pean tongues are adapÂ­tations malum granatum, for example Italian meloÂ­grano, which is a direct sucÂ­cessor of the Latin term, or milÂ­groym [××™×œ×’×¨×±×], a rare case of a Romance loanÂ­word in Yiddish. In other lanÂ­guages, the first part  usualÂ­ly gets transÂ­lated: Examples are German GranatÂ­apfel, Icelandic granatÂ­epli or Finnish granaattiÂ­omena. The English name pomeÂ­granate has a similar structure, but conÂ­tains Latin  pomum fruit, apple (French pomme apple) instead of malum; the Old English term is cornappla grain-apple. In some languages, the apple-element is dropped completely, e.â€‰g., Ukrainian granat [Ò‘Ñ€Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‚] and Spanish granada.  In many European languages, the weapon shell has names similar to granate or grenade. These derive from the same Latin word granum grain: The reference is to the many fragments resulting from the detonation of a shell. Remarkably, also in Hebrew the word  rimon [×¨×™××•×Ÿ] may mean both pomegranate fruit and shell. The underlying Semitic root, RMM, means high, exalted and does not refer to grainyness. The plant name is also found in Arabic (ar-rumman [Ø§Ù„Ø±Ù…Ø§Ù†]) and Coptic (erman [â²‰â²£â²™â²â²›]), but without the secondary shell meaning.  The Farsi name anar [Ø§Ù†Ø§Ø±] already existed in Middle Persian; many language from Eastern Europe to the Indian Ocean have similar or identical names, which are probably direct or indirect Persian loans, e.â€‰g., Dhivehi annaaru [Ş‡Ş¦Ş‚Ş°Ş‚Ş§ŞƒŞª], Punjabi and Kazakh anar [à¨…à¨¨à¨¾à¨°, Ğ°Ğ½Ğ°Ñ€], Armenian nur [Õ¶Õ¸Ö‚Ö€] and Turkish and Bulgarian nar [Ğ½Ğ°Ñ€]. There might be a connection to ancient languages of Mesopotamia: Akkadian nurmÃ» and Sumerian nur [ğ’‰¡ğ’Œ¨] or nurma [ğ’‰¡ğ’Œ¨ğ’ˆ£]  Some of the Indian names of pomegranate contain an element sweet derived from the Proto-Indoâ€“European root MEDÊ°U : Sanskrit madhubija [à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¬à¥€à¤œ] and Tamil madulam [à®®à®¾à®¤à¯à®³à®®à¯]. See bearâ€™s garlic and licorice for details. note: Several reÂ­lated plants are more or less common ornaÂ­mentals both in Europe and in NorthÂ­ern America. It is generally believed that members of genus Rhus are only mildly toxic or even mostly harmÂ­less, for examÂ­ple the ornaÂ­mental tree stagÂ­horn sumac (Rhus typhina). NeverÂ­theless, it should be borne in mind that the ornaÂ­mental varieties are not identical to the variety yielding the spice sumac, and that ingestion of those ornamentals may have adverse effects.           Danger: Japanese Laquer Tree,  Toxicodendron vernicifluum (urushi [ã‚¦ãƒ«ã‚·]), belongs to the group of poisonous sumacs           Allergenic: The fruits of poison ivy (T. radicans) are not to be touched           Sumac tree www.apinguela.com   TheÂ closely reÂ­lated genus ToxicoÂ­dendron contains  a group of trees distributed over the New World and the Pacific Rim. As can be inferred from the genus name poisonous tree, these species are highly toxic.  They have formerly been listed under genus Rhus and are often referred to as sumac in common speach: Toxicodendron radicans (Poison Ivy), Toxicodendron diversilobum (Poison Oak), Toxicodendron vernix (Poison Sumac). All those contain urushiols (3-alkyl pyrocatechol derivatives with long side chains) that are extremely powerful allergenes: If applied to the intact skin they cause painful dermatitis in sensitive people. Sensitivity is acquired on previous contact to the urushiols, without any symptoms. The toxines are effective in sub-Î¼g amounts. Lethal poisonings have been reported, particularly on ingestion or inhalation, which allows the urushiols to attack the mucous membranes of mouth, nose and intestines. Note that the fruits of Toxicodendron species are white to pale ochre, not red.  Allergenes of urushiol type (also alkyl resorcines) are commonly found in the Anacardiaceae family, e.â€‰g., in cashew shell oil or (in traces) unripe mangoes. See also pink pepper.           Dried sumach fruits             Ground sumac            Dried fruits of Rh. glabra            Sumac tree www.apinguela.com
used-plant-part: Dried fruits, usually sold ground (purpleâ€“reddish powder, often mixed with salt).  InÂ Europe, onÂ­ly Rh. coriaria is comÂ­mercially available. In North America, however, two indiÂ­genous species (Rh. glabra and Rh. aromatica) have some small market share; their dried fruits have been used by North American Indians to prepare traditional sour beverages, but are rarely used today. Sumac species from the Old and the New World have very similar flavour. PlantÂ family Anacardiaceae (cashew family).           Ripe fruits of smooth sumac, Rh. glabra           Sumac flowers           Sumac flowers and last yearâ€™s fruits  SensoryÂ qualÂ­ity Tart and sour, with slightly astringent overtones. MainÂ conÂ­stituents The astrinÂ­gentâ€“acidic flavour of sumac spice mostly goes back to two different types of conÂ­stituents: Tannines (galloÂ­tannines, together 4%) and organic acids (malic, citric, and tatric acid plus smaller amounts of  succinic, maleic, fumaric and ascorbic acid). Tannines are found in all parts of the plant, with parÂ­tiÂ­cuÂ­larÂ­ly high conÂ­cenÂ­traÂ­tions in bark and root. These plant parts were, thus, used for tannÂ­ing leather since antiÂ­quity; moreÂ­over, they are part of anti-diaÂ­rrhoeic conÂ­coctions in folk medÂ­icine.  Furthermore, the fruits contain traces of a volatile oil (0.02%) made up of aldehydes (2E-decenal, nonanal, 2E,4E-decadienal) and terpenoids (Î²-caryoÂ­phyllene, Î±-pinene, Î±-terpineol, carvacrol and the diterpene hydroÂ­carbon cembrene).  The pericarp owes its dark red colour to anthocyanin pigments, of which chrysÂ­anthemin, myrtillin and delphinidin have yet been identified. Lastly, the sumac fruits contain 15% fixed oil.             Sumach infrutescence            Smooth sumac (Rh. glabra) with fruits            Sumac flowers  Origin Several species of the genus Rhus grow around the MediÂ­terranean Sea; of these, only Rh. coriaria yields sumac spice. Rh. coriaria grows wild in Sicily, Western Asia and parts of Arabia and Central Asia. Etymology Sumac is of Semitic origin, deriving from a root  SMQ or ÅšMQ to be red. In the Aramaic language, sumaqa [Ü£Ü˜Ü¡Ü©Ü, Ü£Ü¡Ü©] both designates the colour dark red and the sumac berries, while Modern Hebrew sumak [×¡×•×××§] means the spice exclusively. The name was transported to European languages via Arabic as-summaq [Ø§Ù„Ø³Ù…Ø§Ù‚] sumac.  The botanic genus name Rhus is a latinization of the plantâ€™s Greek name, rhous [á¿¥Î¿á¿¦Ï‚], whose origin is not known to me. The species name coriarius refers to the usage of the plant for tanning (Latin corium leather). The German name Essigbaum vinegar tree (mostly used for Rh.  typhina, stagÂ­horn sumac, an ornamental common in Europe) originally referred to Rh.  coriaria and is motivated by the sour taste of the berries. A similar idea stands behind Dutch zuurkruid sour condiment.  The scientific genus name Toxicodendron is a neo-Greek compound, whose second part (meaning tree) is discussed under juniper. The first element derives from classical Greek toxon [Ï„á½¹Î¾Î¿Î½] bow, or rather the adjective toxikon [Ï„Î¿Î¾Î¹Îºá½¹Î½] of/for a bow, which was often used in the term toxikon pharmakon [Ï„Î¿Î¾Î¹Îºá½¸Î½ Ï†á½±ÏÎ¼Î±ÎºÎ¿Î½] poison for arrows (literally medicine for bows); for that reason, the stem tox- has aquired the meaning poison in modern scientific terminology (which does not follow classical habits here). The further origin of these words is not known for sure, but usually they are assumed to have been borrowed by Greek from an Iranian language, probably the tongue of the Scythians, famous horseriders and archers. Possibly, there is a distant and indirect kinship with Latin taxus yew, as yew-wood is one of the most popular materials for high-quality bows (cf. Beleg Strongbow). Left common sage, right an ornamental variety with equal scent.           Flowering garden sage           Greek sage leaf
used-plant-part: Leaves.
sensory-quality: Slightly bitter and aromatic, characÂ­teristic. See below about Meso-American sage varieties with fruity fragrance. MainÂ constituents The essential oil (1 to 2.5%) is comÂ­posed rather difÂ­ferently in difÂ­ferent species and varieties of sage. Dalmatian sage (S. officinalis ssp. minor) contains mostly thujone (35 to 60%), 1,8-cineol (15%), camphor  (18%), borneol (16%), bornyl esters, Î±-pinene and salvene. Spanish sage (ssp. lavandulifolia) lacks thujone, but contains more cineol (29%) and camphor (34%); this subspecies is regarded as inferior. Its leaves lack the bitter diterpene carnosol (see hyssop).            Mexican bush sage, Salvia leucantha           Fruit sage inflorescence, Salvia dorisiana   GreekÂ sageÂ (S.Â triloba) is more strongly aromatic, but generally not accepted as legitimate spice (at least, outside Greece). This species has an interesting, yet less subtle fragrance. The essential oil is dominated by cineol (64%) and contains small amounts of thujone (5%) and camphor (8%), but hardly any borneol. This species is furthermore characterized by a flavone called salvigenin, by which adulterations of S. officinalis with S. triloba can be detected.  See mugwort on the toxicity of thujone, which also appears in southernÂ­wood. On the bitter constituents of sage typical for the family see hyssop; see zedoary for a general discussion on bitter spices. Origin The sage varieties used as spice stem from the Mediterranean and Asia Minor. Sage is grown in Central Europe since the Middle Ages (see lovage).  Genus Salvia is not restricted to the Old World; several sage species from Central America are characterized by a sweet, fruity fragrance very dissimilar to Mediterranean sage, e.â€‰g. Pineapple sage (Salvia rutilans), peach sage (Salvia greggii),  fruit sage (Salvia dorisiana) and more. Some of these become increasingly popular for herb infusions, others are grown as ornamentals for their large flowers.           Garden sage with flowers www.csdl.tamu.edu           Pineapple sage, S. rutilans Â© Sabine Amtsberg   AlsoÂ nativeÂ to Central America is a hallucinoÂ­genic species, Salvia divinorum (sacred sage, sage of the seers), which is of old cultivated by Central American Indians and was used in religious ceremonies before the advent of the Spaniards. The psychoactive constituents were identified as diterpenoid lactones (salvinorinÂ A, divinorinÂ C and others) specific for this species. S. divinorum  is the only hallucinoÂ­genic species in the whole Lamiaceae family. Etymology The names of sage in almost all European tongues derive from the classical Latin name of that plant, salvia. This name is thought to derive from  salvere save, thus indicating the medical value of the plant.  Some examples of salvia-derived names in European languages are German Salbei, Dutch salie, French sauge, Lithuanian Å¡alavijas, Polish szaÅ‚wia, Serbo-Croatian Å¾alfija [Ğ¶Ğ°Ğ»Ñ„Ğ¸Ñ˜Ğ°], Russian shalfej [ÑˆĞ°Ğ»Ñ„ĞµĞ¹], Ukrainian shavliya [ÑˆĞ°Ğ²Ğ»Ñ–Ñ] and Georgian salbi [áƒ¡áƒáƒšáƒ‘áƒ˜].  The only European language with independent names for sage is Greek. The Modern Greek term, alisfakia [Î±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ†Î±ÎºÎ¹Î¬], can be related to a number of ancient names for not clearly identified sage species, e.â€‰g.  elelisphakos [á¼Î»ÎµÎ»á½·ÏƒÏ†Î±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚]  used by Dioscurides, sphakos [ÏƒÏ†á½±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚] used by Theophrastos and phaskoven [ğ€ğ€’ğ€¸] found on Linear B tablets. I do not know about the origin of these names, yet probably Armenian egesphak [Õ¥Õ²Õ¥Õ½ÕºÕ¡Õ¯] belongs to the same kin. main-constituents: The essential oil (1 to 2.5%) is comÂ­posed rather difÂ­ferently in difÂ­ferent species and varieties of sage. Dalmatian sage (S. officinalis ssp. minor) contains mostly thujone (35 to 60%), 1,8-cineol (15%), camphor  (18%), borneol (16%), bornyl esters, Î±-pinene and salvene. Spanish sage (ssp. lavandulifolia) lacks thujone, but contains more cineol (29%) and camphor (34%); this subspecies is regarded as inferior. Its leaves lack the bitter diterpene carnosol (see hyssop).            Mexican bush sage, Salvia leucantha           Fruit sage inflorescence, Salvia dorisiana   GreekÂ sageÂ (S.Â triloba) is more strongly aromatic, but generally not accepted as legitimate spice (at least, outside Greece). This species has an interesting, yet less subtle fragrance. The essential oil is dominated by cineol (64%) and contains small amounts of thujone (5%) and camphor (8%), but hardly any borneol. This species is furthermore characterized by a flavone called salvigenin, by which adulterations of S. officinalis with S. triloba can be detected.  See mugwort on the toxicity of thujone, which also appears in southernÂ­wood. On the bitter constituents of sage typical for the family see hyssop; see zedoary for a general discussion on bitter spices.
origin: The sage varieties used as spice stem from the Mediterranean and Asia Minor. Sage is grown in Central Europe since the Middle Ages (see lovage).  Genus Salvia is not restricted to the Old World; several sage species from Central America are characterized by a sweet, fruity fragrance very dissimilar to Mediterranean sage, e.â€‰g. Pineapple sage (Salvia rutilans), peach sage (Salvia greggii),  fruit sage (Salvia dorisiana) and more. Some of these become increasingly popular for herb infusions, others are grown as ornamentals for their large flowers.           Garden sage with flowers www.csdl.tamu.edu           Pineapple sage, S. rutilans Â© Sabine Amtsberg   AlsoÂ nativeÂ to Central America is a hallucinoÂ­genic species, Salvia divinorum (sacred sage, sage of the seers), which is of old cultivated by Central American Indians and was used in religious ceremonies before the advent of the Spaniards. The psychoactive constituents were identified as diterpenoid lactones (salvinorinÂ A, divinorinÂ C and others) specific for this species. S. divinorum  is the only hallucinoÂ­genic species in the whole Lamiaceae family.
etymology: The names of sage in almost all European tongues derive from the classical Latin name of that plant, salvia. This name is thought to derive from  salvere save, thus indicating the medical value of the plant.
